PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent-
(1) the Prime Minister moving forthwith a motion of censure on the Leader of the Opposition;
(2) the Prime Minister in moving the motion speaking for a period not exceeding 30 minutes, and
(3) the Leader of the Opposition or one member deputed by him speaking on the motion for a period not exceeding 30 minutes.

The steps taken by the Opposition yesterday are reminiscent of those in 1975. They are indicative of a political party-the Liberal Party of Australia-not believing that it will ever again have the responsibility of governing this country, which is a view that we readily accept. Those opposite wish to continue to set constitutional precedents which will make government of this country extremely difficult, if not impossible. Yet they try to laugh it away as if this has no consequences for future government by any political party. This morning, by the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders, those opposite have the opportunity to try to explain away their dereliction of duty as a political party and their extraordinary, irresponsible actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, there is no need to have a motion to suspend Standing and Sessional Orders. The Opposition happily gives leave to do so to debate this ludicrous proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Leader of the Opposition and the Opposition parties for:

(1) their hypocrisy, in that members of the Opposition parties have, on past occasions, supported the concept of an identification card for Australia and now seek flagrantly to rupture the long standing conventions of the Parliament and the Constitution, in voting in another place to declare their intention to disallow Go-vernment Regulations implementing the Australia Card legislation proposed to be lawfully enacted under the provisions of s.57 of the Commonwealth Constitution; and

(2) the offensive and gross misrepresentation that I, the Prime Minister of Australia, had fraudulently misled the Governor-General in invoking the Senate's failure, on two occasions, to pass the Australia Card legislation to obtain a double dissolution of the Parliament.
This is a motion to censure an Opposition substantially bereft of talent, totally devoid of principle and irremediably tarnished by hypocrisy.

Let me first establish the charge of hypocrisy. The key figure in this unprincipled tactic to frustrate the implementation of the Australia Card is Senator Stone, the intellectual soul mate of Premier Joh and Senator Flo. It was Senator Stone who discovered his convenient lawyer who has delivered him-and through Senator Stone, the Opposition-a most unremarkable legal opinion. I will return to that unremarkable legal opinion in a moment. Senator Stone is unequivocally on the record in support of the ID card. More than that, Senator Stone has strongly urged this Prime Minister to introduce the ID card for the very purpose that I have, in fact, introduced it. He has strongly urged me to introduce the ID card; more than that, he has personally offered me his services to help in the introduction of the ID card. Let me quote from the Australian newspaper of 29 June 1985. Under the heading `PM told how to save $2.5 bil' it states:
On the eve of the tax summit three leading Australian economists have prepared a cost-cutting list which could save at least $2.5 billion in federal spending.

Those three people are the former Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone; Professor John Hewson, now the honourable member for Wentworth; and Dr Neville Norman. That is the heading. They are urging me how to save $2.5 billion. What is the list? I will not go to it all. I need not go to it all. It starts off with family allowances on a needs tested basis, then mentions tertiary education fees and then it states:
ID cards to boost revenue by eliminating tax avoidance. Saving: $400m.

Let me quote briefly from this article to establish the monumental hypocrisy of Senator Stone, and of Professor Hewson if he has changed his position. Let me establish what they had to say. The article states:
They have proposed a business-funded group of non-government experts with a mandate to swiftly advise the PM on implementation of expenditure cuts . . .
Professor Hewson said the private industry advisory group could be modelled on President Reagan's Grace Commission into Government waste.
He said:
But it would not drag on for years and cost millions. Its mandate would be to report within a month.
It should have full access to Government accounts. I think the PM would go along with that.
He then pointed out the qualifications that he had and that he and Senator Stone would bring to bear in advising the Prime Minister how to introduce an ID card. This is what is said:
Professor Hewson suggested his seven years as economic advisor to former Treasurers, Sir Phillip Lynch and John Howard, would qualify him, as would Mr Stone's long service with Treasury.
There was Professor Hewson's advocacy of his qualifications and Senator Stone's qualifications to advise on this matter. He further said:
The ID-card savings was a nett amount and excluded the cost of an administrative bureaucracy.

I ask the House to understand exactly what is contained in that 1985 statement. What they were doing was this: they were specifically urging the Prime Minister of this country to introduce the ID card to stop the tax cheats. That is what Senator Stone and Professor Hewson were advocating: introduce the ID card, Prime Minister. Secondly, they were saying, `We offer our services'. Professor Hewson and Senator Stone said, `Mr Prime Minister, we offer you our services to introduce the ID card in this country to stop the tax cheats'. Further, they were saying, `There is no great issue in this; no problems involved. We can handle this issue within a month. We will report back to you within a month'. There was no nonsense from Professor Hewson and Senator Stone about there being no net saving in the ID card and no suggestion of some countervailing bureaucratic expense-there would be net savings of $400m.

Professor Hewson would certainly have been right in assuming the support of Mr Howard in what he said because, as Treasurer, that same Mr Howard had looked at the ID card on more than one occasion. Having been through the arguments as Treasurer, what was that same Mr Howard saying about the ID card at precisely the same time as Professor Hewson was offering his services to me to bring in the ID card? This is what, almost exactly two years ago, this Mr Howard was saying about the Australia Card. I quote him from 15 September 1985 and this is what he had to say:
I think there is some merit in giving it favourable consideration.
When he was asked how he could support the ID card when he supported deregulation he replied dismissively, almost contemptuously, in these words:

I don't think there is any inconsistency. I mean the United States has had a social security card for generations and yet the United States economy is the most deregulated economy in the world. I do not think there is any conflict at all.

That was the statement from the honest John period-the proposal merited favourable consideration; the United States had had the concept for generations. There was no suggestion from him when he endorsed the fact that the United States had had it for generations that it had involved unconscionable invasions of privacy or of civil liberties. That endorses the precise experience that I had just last Wednesday night at the Australian Financial Review dinner. At the end of it an American came up to me and he said, `Look at this, Mr Prime Minister'. He opened his wallet, took out his social security card and said, `I have no concerns about this, Prime Minister. You are right'.

Let us come up to date with Professor Hewson's more recent comments. Let us just examine what Professor Hewson has had to say. I refer to his comments in the Business Review Weekly of 3 April of this year. Professor Hewson said:
It is equally difficult to understand why John Howard and his mates have not yet released their tax policy.
This is Professor Hewson in April of this year attacking John Howard. He said, `I cannot understand why John Howard and his mates have not released their tax policy'. He said:
Against the background of the tax reform debacles of the Fraser years much more is expected of Howard this time.
He went on then to go directly to the question of the Australia Card. He said:

I believe the electorate is very concerned with Government and Opposition promises to cut welfare expenditure without having first made a reasonable effort to tighten the existing system and to minimise abuse. Surely this is one of the main reasons why most surveys showed that most Australians supported the introduction of the Australia card.

They were Professor Hewson's words in April of this year. Professor Hewson rightly referred to the `tax reform debacles of the Fraser years'. They were not just Fraser years; they were the Fraser-Howard years of tax reform debacle. He then asked what more was required at this time of John Howard. He went on to give his answer that what was required in 1987 from John Howard was `a reasonable effort to tighten the existing system and minimise abuse'. What was Professor Hewson's answer in April 1987 of what was required of John Howard to tighten the system? His answer was the ID card. Professor Hewson knows-but much more importantly than Professor Hewson knowing it, John Howard knows-the truth of that statement that what is required is the ID card. This is the measure of hypocrisy of your Howards, your Hewsons and your Stones. All of those behind Howard, Hewson and Stone acquiesce in their hypocrisy, their opportunism and their double standards because they recognise, indeed they have argued the merit and the purpose-the legitimate economic and social purpose-of the Australia Card. Then, Madam Speaker, having argued the merit and the purpose of the card, blatantly, deliberately and without conscience they have set out to pervert that majority public opinion-a majority public opinion which Professor Hewson, in April of this year, was a correct public opinion. They have set about attempting to pervert that majority public opinion-a correct public opinion-by gross, hysterical, fear-mongering representation, by arguments that Hewson, Stone and Howard know in the privacy of their own minds they would repudiate with contempt.

Madam Speaker, without any question this is a monumental hypocrisy-the manipulation of the needy by the greedy, by those greedy for power at any cost and certainly at the easily accepted cost of sacrificing their intellectual and social convictions on the altar of political expediency. The charge of hypocrisy is made, the charge of hypocrisy is established and the charge of hypocrisy is unanswerable.

But worse-much worse than the fact that the hypocrisy is there-it is a hypocrisy which in their own minds the Howards, the Hewsons and the Stones know is practised by them at a grievous cost to the people of this country. For this hypocrisy in which they engage now protects the tax cheats and it protects the welfare frauds to the tune of $1 billion per annum. That is $1 billion which would be available to cancel the public debt, to reduce tax rates or to provide programs for the most needy in our community.

Madam Speaker, I said at the outset that this was an Opposition substantially bereft of talent and totally devoid of principle. However, Opposition members do have enough talent to recognise the truth; indeed, they are on record as acknowledging the truth. So, they have enough talent to do that, but there is not a solitary principle in their make-up which will allow their knowledge of the truth to impede their pathetic political opportunism.

That, Madam Speaker, leads me to the events of yesterday. We have Senator Stone now reduced in stature from concerned intellectual to a Queensland National Party political junkie. He is the rolling stone to Sir Joh's Sisyphus. He has desperately striven now, in 1987, to find a way to stop me introducing the ID card that just two years ago he offered his services to me to introduce to stop the tax cheats in this country. So, what has he done? He has found a lawyer-`my old mate, Smithy; my old cricketing mate, Smithy-who has given him what is, as I have said, surely the most unremarkable legal opinion of all time.

Senator Stone, having got this unremarkable opinion from my old mate, Smithy, has gleefully trotted around to the office of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and the Leader of the Opposition, because he is totally devoid of political principle, has found himself totally incapable of making an honest statement about the opinion which was handed to him. Let us be quite clear about what the Leader of the Opposition says. In the very first words of his Press release yesterday, he says:
The Opposition believes that the ID card legislation is flawed . . .
The Opposition's view is based on the attached document.

It is perfectly clear that the document attached to the statement by the Leader of the Opposition does not say-for it cannot say-that the legislation is flawed. Let me read to the House the final sentence of Smithy's little opinion, which sums up the legal opinion. He says:
The conclusion is that regulations fixing the first and second relevant days are open to disallowance and the disallowance would be effective to make the Australia Card Act wholly ineffective.

That is the conclusion-there is no flaw in the legislation. The opinion does not say that there is a flaw in the legislation, because the language of the legislation is simply a replication of the practice that has been followed in this Parliament for 87 years. There is no flaw. The words in clause 32-using the traditional method of relying on regulations under the Act to assist in giving effect to the purposes and objectives of the Act-were in the Australia Card Bill on 22 October 1986, when the Bill was presented to the House of Representatives. They were in the Bill on 17 November 1986, when it was received and read a first time by the Senate; on 18 March 1987, when it was again considered in the House of Representatives; and on 26 March 1987 when it was again considered in the Senate.

Not only was the legislation drafted in accordance with the parliamentary practice of 87 years but I suggest that it is particularly instructive to look at the experience of the last 4 1/2 years. Let me acknowledge the Opposition's consistency during this period. As is known, the Opposition has opposed all the fairness measures which we have introduced to broaden the tax base and make the system function more efficiently. Its opposition, Madam Speaker, as you will well recall, more often than not has bordered on the hysteria that it is now attempting to generate on the Australia Card. Yet, I remind the House, on not one occasion after violently opposing our measures in this place and in the Senate has the Opposition sought to disallow the relevant regulations. I remind the House of 1983 and the tax on superannuation lump sums. We had the spectacle of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and others ranting and raving about what an evil change we had proposed to the tax law and saying how they would fight it to the bitter end; yet at no stage did they threaten to block the extensive regulations which underpinned that tax reform.

Honourable members will recall the prescribed payments system legislation in the same year. We were told then that it would send small business to the wall, and so on-it was the end of the world for small business. But there was not one word about the fact that the definition of a `prescribed payment' was contained not in the legislation but in the regulations. Let us look at Medicare. The entire system of deducting Medicare contributions falls to pieces without pages and pages of taxation regulations. Over $2 billion of levy receipts would disappear if the Opposition forced a disallowance motion through the Senate.

I ask this simple and obvious question: was all this legislation flawed because it depended for its effective operation on the existence of regulations? Of course not. The flaw that has been exposed by the events of yesterday is not a flaw in the legislation but a flaw in the Leader of the Opposition and those behind him. It is the flaw of expediency; it is the flaw of cynical opportunism; and it is the flaw of contemptuous disregard for the welfare of the people of Australia. It is a revelation yet again of a preparedness to tear up the unbroken practices and conventions of the past 87 years in the blatant pursuit of political opportunism. That is the flaw which has been exposed by the events of yesterday.

Let this fact be understood clearly by this House as it will be understood by the people of Australia: never before, in the 87 years existence of this nation, has an Act passed by this Parliament been effectively gutted by the subsequent disallowance of regulations which were essential to give effect to the policy and the intention of that Act. This is a deliberate and unprecedented threat to destroy the constitutional concept of a joint sitting to give effect to an electoral mandate delivered by the people. This brings me to the most ludicrous and most contemptible of the statements made yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition that I, as Prime Minister, and the Government, fraudulently obtained from the Governor-General a double dissolution and that I owe the Governor-General and the public a monumental explanation.
Opposition members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to honourable members opposite. I have already disposed of this transparent nonsense by the facts that I have outlined as to 87 years of legislative practice and as to the particular examples of the last 4 1/2 years. Madam Speaker, I remind you and the House that the recitation of the details of the presentation and the consideration of the Australia Card Bill to the two Houses of Parliament was contained in an attachment to my letter to the Governor-General of 27 May seeking a double dissolution on the grounds contained in section 57 of the Constitution. It was on that basis that the Governor-General replied to me on the same day, 27 May, in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied that circumstances such as are specified in section 57 of the Constitution exist in relation to the Australia Card Bill and that I should dissolve both Houses of the Parliament simultaneously in accordance with your advice.

That the Leader of the Opposition should insult me is of absolutely no moment and, I can assure him, of no concern whatsoever. Much more importantly, the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition are an insult to the intelligence of the Governor-General, a former judge of the High Court of Australia. Madam Speaker, I remind you of what I had to say in a distributed document attached to my election opening policy speech:
Labor has conducted the most systematic crackdown of tax avoidance and welfare cheating ever attempted.
I also said:
Those efforts will be maintained not least by the reintroduction of the Australia Card legislation.

The facts are simple; they are indisputable. The Governor-General dissolved the Parliament on this issue. I sought a mandate on this issue and I received a mandate from the people of Australia on this issue. In the desperation of his comprehensive rejection by the Australian people, the Leader of the Opposition, this supremely unprincipled opportunist, seeks to divert the people of this country from what he, Hewson and Stone know are the best interests of the people of Australia and they seek to do that by the tactics of fear, smear and hysteria.

I conclude by saying that last Saturday night this tactic of fear, smear and hysteria was shredded to pieces in my presence in a most devastating manner. I want to recall this incident to you, Madam Speaker. I hope that those opposite will have the decency to listen to this devastation of their tactics. I was in the presence of an elderly Jewish woman. She said to me, `Bob, I have an ID number'. She bared the number which was burnt into her arm while she was an inmate of the Auschwitz concentration camp. Her words to me were these: `I have nothing but contempt for those who seek by false imagery to frighten the people of this country from something which is for their great benefit'. This House should have nothing but contempt for the hypocrisy, the misrepresentation and the cynical disregard for the welfare of the people of Australia shown by the Opposition. The Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition are deserving of the censure of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a measure of the moral bankruptcy of the arguments that have been advanced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this pathetic, irrelevant censure motion that he should seek to invoke in aid of his arguments something related to the most abominable crime ever committed in this century. It is a measure of his moral bankruptcy that he should seek to invoke that. There is a great principle of our Constitution at stake in this whole debate. There is an issue of constitutional propriety. There is a convention at stake in the heart of this whole debate. But that convention is not the one that was so pathetically raised by the Prime Minister. The true convention is that a Minister who has failed ought to resign. That is the true principle that is at stake.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever we have seen a classic example of a Minister who, under the Westminster tradition, has done grievous damage to the reputation and the competence of the Government, has greatly embarrassed his Government, and is under an obligation to resign, we have seen it from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). He is the Minister who, for over 12 months, has presided over this legislation. He is the Minister who has misled the Australian public. He is the Minister who has embarrassed his Government. So if there is any convention at stake, it is not the pathetic argument of the Prime Minister; it is the simple convention of ministerial responsibility. All I can say on behalf of the Opposition on this is that, if that Minister does not resign, ministerial responsibility under the Hawke Government is as dead as the identity card Bill. It will not surprise me if he does not resign because he will join a long and dishonourable list of people who have failed in their ministerial responsibilities, but who have never resigned. He will join the Leader of the House (Mr Young), the man who leaked information in a Canberra carpark--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah!

—The honourable member says, `Ah!'. I know that he does not like it. It was a royal commissioner of this nation, appointed by the Prime Minister, who said that the Leader of the House leaked information that was potentially damaging to the national security of this country. As I listened to the Prime Minister's speech and as I noted, as no doubt you did, Madam Speaker, the tremendously enthusiastic response from his back bench, particularly from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent)-the honourable member for Hotham is a terrific supporter of the Prime Minister on this matter; he is as strong a supporter of the Prime Minister on this as is Senator Bolkus!-I thought, `Who on earth could have advised the Prime Minister to adopt this motion? Was it the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Peter Duncan, or was it Neal Blewett? Perhaps it was the Special Minister of State, Susan Ryan'. As I listened a bit harder, I looked and I suddenly discovered what the problem was. The Prime Minister was not reading from somebody else's text; he was reading from a handwritten text of his own. It is perfectly obvious that the Prime Minister's pathetic censure motion is all his own work. And well it may be, because the Prime Minister is alone on this issue. He is bereft not only of public support but also of support in his own Party. You fellas know darn well that you are rattling political death on this subject and you know perfectly well that the Prime Minister has become increasingly isolated on this particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In this very fortuitous opportunity that the Prime Minister has given me to say a few words about the whole identity card debate, let me address the one and only argument of any conceivable substance or consequence that the Prime Minister advanced during his censure motion-that is, the argument related to constitutional convention. What the Prime Minister is really saying is that, if either House of this Parliament exercises a right conferred unambiguously under section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act, an Act of the Parliament of the Commonwealth-he derides the lawyer to whom John Stone spoke and I ought to deride the lawyer to whom he spoke who gave him the absurd legal advice that something done under section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act violates an 87-year-old constitutional convention-it is acting improperly. I have never heard such constitutional rot in all my life. Let me say quite clearly on behalf of the Opposition that we reject completely any suggestion, and we will go on rejecting it, that for either House of this Parliament to exercise a right conferred under the practices, the usages and the laws of the Parliament of this Commonwealth is acting in any improper way. We reject that completely and utterly and the Australian people will reject it completely and utterly.

This censure motion is born out of one thing. It is born out of the mortal hurt that the Prime Minister feels to his ego. It is born out of the mortal embarrassment that has been done to this Government by the extraordinary revelation of a fundamental practical flaw in the legislation that has been put forward by the Government. No attempt at red herrings, no attempt at references to attitudes quoted out of context, to which I will turn in a moment, can alter the fact that this Prime Minister and this Government have been made to look stupid and foolish to the entire Australian public. In plain language, they have been caught out. They have been comprehensively disgraced and humiliated on this issue.

No amount of hectoring or frothing at the mouth by the Prime Minister will alter the fact that he has blown it in a way that has never been seen by the Australian public before. For over 12 months the Prime Minister has ranted and raved around the Australian nation. He has used the figure of $1 billion. I say to the Prime Minister, `I will tell you where that $1 billion is wrong when you tell me how you compute it. Until you tell us how it is computed and until you address your mind to all of the arguments that have been advanced against this legislation, you cannot go on doing that'.

The real level of misrepresentation and deceit in the Prime Minister's censure motion was his pathetic attempt to associate me with the ID card legislation. As, of course, is the Prime Minister's wont on so many occasions-he does this almost compulsively-he quoted not accurately or even fully but deliberately, maliciously and repeatedly out of context. I am glad that the Prime Minister referred to that interview on 15 September 1985. The measure of his deceit and of the extent to which he is prepared to go to mislead the Parliament and the Australian public is borne out when I read the full text of the comment that I made on the Sunday program of 15 September 1985. This is what I said:
I personally see some merit in having an ID card . . .
Did the Prime Minister stop there? Yes. He went on to quote something else. I ask whether he said this:
providing the civil liberties concerns that people have voiced can be looked after . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.
—`They are', he says. Come in spinner. He is Robinson Crusoe on the subject of believing that the civil liberties arguments have been looked after. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: providing the civil liberties concerns that people have voiced can be looked after and provided the Government can satisfy the community that there is some cost benefit in it.

That is what I said on 15 September 1985 and that has been the basis of the Opposition's approach to this legislation from the very beginning of it. When the proposal was put up, we joined with the Australian Democrats in sending it off to a parliamentary committee. We said then that our support for it would be conditional on being satisfied on a number of criteria and two of those criteria were those of civil liberties and cost benefit.

I remind the Prime Minister that when the report of that committee came back, it was not only the Liberal and National parties that turned the thumbs down. The honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson)-where is he now?-one of the Government's great supporters on this legislation, turned his thumbs down on the legislation. He was not prepared to buy the argument that civil liberties were looked after. He was not convinced that there was a cost benefit in the legislation. He also turned his thumbs down. So I say to the Prime Minister, `Don't you quote me out of context on this particular subject. I have had an utterly consistent position on the ID card legislation all along'. I also remind the Prime Minister that, from the very beginning, we laid it down that we could give support to this legislation only if it were satisfactory on those two particular counts. I dismiss, as indeed does the Australian public, the pathetic attempt of the Prime Minister to run the line about inconsistency so far as the Opposition is concerned.

Even more importantly, this issue raises a fundamental question about the competence of all those people sitting on the front bench on the Government side. Yesterday morning, after those opposite had that very friendly little talk in Caucus, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), that good old member, the Prime Minister's north Queensland fishing mate, spoke on the AM program. He did not know how true his statement was when he said, `There are a whole lot of lightweights on the front bench'. He did not realise what he had said. This motion and this whole debacle bring home to the Australian public the great myth of the claim by the Prime Minister that he has the most talented front bench that Australia has seen since Federation. I wonder what the people will think of that. I suppose the only thing that can be said about the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support is that he has been checkmated by his South Australian colleague, the Minister for Community Services and Health.

As I said at the outset of my remarks, the real focus of this House's attention ought to be not on the Opposition but on the poor, pathetic Minister for Community Services and Health. He is the person responsible. He has blown it in the most comprehensive way that any Minister has blown it in recent memory. This Minister has presided over a piece of legislation which has now been revealed as being fundamentally flawed and which has already cost the Australian taxpayer hundreds of thousands of dollars. It has cost countless hundreds of thousands of people great concern and worry because of the card's implications. The Minister has failed to establish to the Australian public a satisfactory argument about the security of the card. He has failed to satisfy the Australian public on the cost benefit. He has failed to satisfy the Australian public on the integrity of the figures that he uses in aid of the claim by the Prime Minister that the card will eliminate tax evasion and welfare fraud.

Let me say just a few things on welfare fraud and tax evasion. I invite the Prime Minister to look at some remarks made by the Australian Federal Police which might know a little about the operations of people involved in white collar crime. I invite him to look at some of the words of Frank Costigan and of many other people who know a great deal about the operation of white collar crime in this country. The Prime Minister will find again and again that those people say that the identity card will not be effective in fighting organised crime. The Australian Federal Police has said repeatedly that if it were given more resources to enforce to the limit the existing laws of this country that would be more effective in fighting organised crime than the introduction of an identity card.

I also remind the Prime Minister that the identity card legislation, if it were to come into operation, would not put a glove on the cash economy. The cash economy is the greatest area of tax evasion in our community. The national numbering system, the plastic tattoo that the mob opposite want, would not put a glove on the cash economy. We found in the late 1970s, when an investigation was carried out into the operation of identity card procedures in other countries, that that could fall into the hands of organised crime. So it would be the case in this country.

From the very beginning both the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have had a consistent attitude that if the Government can satisfy us that the ID card legislation meets the criteria on privacy and cost benefit, we will be prepared to consider it. On every count the Government has failed to discharge that obligation. That is why the Government is in trouble today. That is why, as each week has gone by in this debate, support for this proposal has ebbed away from the Prime Minister. That is why the document I tabled in the Parliament yesterday, and the impact of that document, not only on the ranks of Government members but also on the future of this legislation, have been greeted with universal relief and delight around the Australian community.

If the Prime Minister imagines that he is on a winner in trying to support this identity card legislation, I invite him to listen to every talk-back radio program in Australia today. I invite him to find out the attitude of the Australian people in the cities. They are absolutely delighted that the ID card will be consigned to the wastepaper-basket. That is so because the great majority of the Australian people have not swallowed the nonsense, the fear and innuendo campaign that has been waged by the Prime Minister. As I said a few moments ago, the real issue to which this Parliament and this House should be directed today is not so much the detailed argument about the ID card legislation but the very simple proposition, which is a convention of our system of government-unlike the phoney convention that the Prime Minister has tried to establish about not using a power that is conferred on a House of Parliament by the laws of this Commonwealth-of whether ever again under this Government we will see any sign at all of the great Westminster principle of ministerial responsibility.

I remind honourable members opposite of fading and slight memory of some of the things that have been said about ministerial responsibility. That great pillar of Westminster rectitude, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and Leader of the House, said a few years ago in very earnest and grave tones, `There is nothing more important than how these people who call themselves Ministers behave and carry on. There is nothing more important than the discharge of their responsibilities'. By any proper, decent test of the Westminster principle, the Minister for Community Services and Health ought to resign. He ought to resign because by any stretch of the imagination and any test at all, he has completely failed to discharge his ministerial responsibilities.

That Minister has had no more important ministerial duty over the last 12 months than the conduct of the Government's identity card legislation. Despite the vast resources of his own Department and those of the Attorney-General's Department, despite access through taxpayers' funds to private legal advice and counsel-which is inevitably available to any government- despite everything that has happened and has been said and despite the fact that the Prime Minister sought and obtained a double dissolution on the basis of this legislation, at the end of the day we find that for practical purposes the great intrusive dream of the Minister for Community Services and Health cannot be brought to fruition. He has a great dream and a contempt that he has never disavowed for private property rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The Prime Minister says, `Oh!'. There is a rule in this Parliament. If it suits the Prime Minister's convenience he can reach back many years and quote anything. But if we dare remind him of an embarrassing remark that he or one of his colleagues made, we are engaging in the politics of fear and innuendo.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us remind the House that the only person who is really in the dock today is the Minister for Community Services and Health. He had a contribution to make to political philosophy. On the question of privacy he said, `You know, we socialists ought not get too worked up about privacy because that after all is a bourgeois right related to the concept of private property'. It is no wonder that the Prime Minister put that Minister in charge of the ID card legislation. It is no wonder that he has failed miserably to meet the first criterion that I laid down more than two years ago in relation to this legislation. That criterion was: the Government should satisfy us on the privacy issue before we are prepared to look at the proposal. Our opposition to this legislation has been based on a very sound Liberal principle; that is, the most important thing about our democratic society is the importance and supremacy of each individual man and woman. Individual rights can be reduced or limited only if it can be demonstrated that there is a total public good in reducing or limiting individual rights in some way. On this particular issue, the individual right of privacy-the right of people who are not breaking the law to go about their business and do transactions without unnecessary interference-can be reduced, constrained and cut back in a nation that calls itself a liberal democracy only if those in the country who seek to cut it back demonstrate conclusively that there is a greater public good which can be served in cutting it back.

The reason the Government has failed to win our support on this issue, the reason it has lost public support on this issue and the reason it is now mortally embarrassed and mortally humiliated on this issue relates to one fundamental thing; that is, that it has totally failed to convince the Australian public that it has a valid case to introduce this proposal. Throughout the whole of this debate that has been the most overwhelming basis of our opposition and because of the Minister's total failure and his total humiliation he, and he alone, is the person who is really in the dock.

I regarded the events of yesterday as being a very welcome day for the Australian community. I can speak on behalf of every man and woman on this side of the Parliament; we regard what happened yesterday as a triumph of the interests of the Australian people over an insensitive government. We regard what happened yesterday as the Prime Minister being monumentally embarrassed and monumentally caught out. What happened yesterday occurred through the agency of a private citizen concerned, as he said, about the impact of this legislation-a man who has served governments of both political persuasions as a civil servant with immaculate professionalism. And he does not deserve the contemptuous description that the Prime Minister gave him. How dare the Prime Minister traduce the reputation of a man who honourably served both Labor and Liberal governments. How dare the Prime Minister use the cheap politics of ridicule. Use it against those who are in this chamber but do not use the sanctuary of this chamber to insult the reputation of an honest, decent man who served this country as a public servant.

It is a measure of the moral, political and logical bankruptcy of the arguments advanced by the Prime Minister, it is a monument to the tactical stupidity of bringing on this censure motion and it is a monument to how out of touch the Prime Minister is with the wishes of the Australian people on this particular proposal that he should bring in this censure motion, that he should invoke in a most erratic and illogical fashion analogies that bear no relationship at all to this particular debate but, most importantly of all, that he should seek the sanctuary of this chamber, as Prime Minister of this country, to insult the reputation of a man who I would say is the toast of the great majority of the Australian community right here and now. The Prime Minister ought to be ashamed of himself to come into this Parliament and to attack, under the cover of parliamentary privilege, the reputation of this man.

The Opposition welcomes this brilliant, devastating, earth shattering tactical move which has been brought forward by the Prime Minister! We are prostrate before the inexorable force of his rhetoric and his oratory on this occasion! He has left every last one of us absolutely devastated! I was shaking like a leaf through the whole of his speech as they all cheered him to the echo! We all sat and watched as they cheered. He talks a lot about decibel tests. I tell you what: he would have failed a decibel test absolutely pathetically.

I welcome this censure motion with great relish because not only does it enable me to reject the fallacious arguments of the Prime Minister, to nail the lies and the canards about tax evasion, and to remind this Parliament that we have been consistent and stoic in our opposition to this legislation but, most importantly of all, it allows us and the Parliament of this country to say something about ministerial responsibility. I, therefore, propose an amendment to this motion. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words-
``This House-
(1) calls on the Minister for Community Services and Health to resign for the discredit he has brought to the Government and this Parliament in his handling of the Australia Card legislation;

(2) failing his resignation, calls on the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Community Services and Health for his failure to conduct the debate on the Australia Card legislation in a fit and proper manner;

(3) censures the Government for misleading the Australian community about the purported savings to the Australian taxpayer from the use of the Australia Card (with respect to tax evasion and social welfare fraud); and

(4) condemns the Government for wasting the taxpayers, money by persisting with legislation which would abuse personal privacy beyond limits acceptable to the principle of democracy and individual rights sacred to the Australian community''.

I might well have added to that motion, `and that this House thanks the Prime Minister for his brilliant, tactical ploy this morning which has enabled the Opposition to bring before this Parliament the one and only convention that has been shattered over this issue; that is, the convention that Ministers ought to be responsible for their failures and when they fail they ought to have the decency to get out'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to respond at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a motion of censure of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for what he announced to the Parliament. For the first time in the history of this nation the Leader of the Opposition got up and told us in advance that he would direct his cohorts and colleagues in the Senate to reject substantive legislation because it was going to be disallowed by way of regulation. That has never happened in the history of this country. We heard the argument this morning that what is being done is democratic and in accordance with principle and with precedent. Never before in this country has a Leader of the Opposition got up and admitted that he is going to direct his senators to do something contrary to what would be in accordance with democratic principles. The Leader of the Opposition is running scared in this matter, for this reason: he is prepared to adopt what I say is the subterfuge of disallowing the regulation on the pretext that he is entitled to do so. If in the future any hostile Senate can disallow a regulation we will destroy most of the effective legislation now in operation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I will read to honourable members the sort of legislation that is dependent on the Senate's agreement to regulation in respect of bringing part or all of it into operation. Taxation Acts that are wholly dependent upon regulations for their existence include: all levy Acts, the Stevedoring Industry Charge Act and the livestock export charges Acts-there are many of them. These Acts have substantially depended on regulations for their effective operation. They also include Acts in the whole of the customs and excise area, the Northern Territory legislation, the Public Service Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Patents Act, the National Health Act, the Banking Act and the Companies Act-and so that list goes on.

Where is the precedent that the Leader of the Opposition suddenly found yesterday that the provision in the Bill that a relevant date-that is all-will be fixed by regulation is fraudulent, deceptive and should never have been introduced? All such Acts now in existence will fail tomorrow if the Senate disallows such regulations. The whole of government would collapse. The stupidity of the man was to come into the chamber yesterday and announce that he would guarantee such action would be taken on this Bill because he would direct senators to vote against their conscience and their better judgment because of his political animosity and stupidity in trying to gain an advantage in the public opinion polls.

Acts requiring rules of court for their effective operations such as the Judiciary Act, the Bankruptcy Act and the Federal Court of Australia Act, all depend on regulations being accepted by the Senate. This mad action by the Leader of the Opposition apparently was agreed to by his Party at a party meeting. The Liberal Party picked up the poor old National Party of Australia-a party bereft of any ideas-saying, `You'd better come with us'. They got all the senators into the room and said, `Gee whizz, we have had a brilliant idea. Senator Stone found something'. Senator Stone, who has led the Treasury, would know that half the taxation Acts depend on regulations. He would know that all the Acts I have mentioned owe their life now to regulations. The whole of the foreign exchange regulations, the air navigation regulations, the customs regulations, the navigation regulations, all the rules of the High Court and the Family Court, could now go out the window. I shall table and seek leave to have incorporated at the end of my remarks a list of those Acts-and they are only some.

Let the Leader of the Opposition make a personal explanation, if he likes, about when previously the Senate has threatened to disallow a regulation to deny substantive legislation. It has never, ever happened. Let the Leader of the Opposition give such an explanation to the Australian people. This is the issue. The Australia Card Bill was first introduced in 1986 and debated. It was opposed by the Opposition here and in the Senate. Those provisions in question were in it then. They did not offend anybody because they related to an appropriate date to be determined as and when the legislation passed. The date could not be put in in advance. There is nothing wrong or fraudulent about that. The same Bill was passed in 1987. There was no suggestion of fraud because such a suggestion could not stand up.

Because we won an election with a substantial majority we are entitled under the Constitution to hold a joint sitting of both Houses to bring the Bill into place. When there is a dispute between the two Houses there has to be some mechanism to resolve that dispute. The Leader of the Opposition is so fearful of that that he does not want to allow the normal democratic processes to operate. He does not want a joint sitting of both Houses. He does not want this legislation to come into operation. He does not use any legitimate or appropriate exercise to marshal a majority anywhere except in the Senate, where he cannot really continue to oppose the legislation because he knows that it will be passed at a joint sitting. He has used his power to use the charade of having the Bill referred to a Senate committee to be examined. There might be a few new senators, who were not involved with the previous Bills, but obviously they are prisoners of the dictates of the Liberal and National parties. Yesterday when we proposed in the Senate that the Senate, irrespective of the examination by the committee of the legislation, would not exercise its power over the regulations to deny the substantive Bill that motion was voted down by 40 to 30. Clearly, in advance, the idea of referring the Bill to a Senate committee is a fraud on the parliamentary process.

The Leader of the Opposition is pulling the wool over the eyes of all his supporters by suggesting that he has found a mistake. He should not be thanking John Stone, he should be asking him, `Why did you not think of these ideas when you were head of the Treasury? Why do you now encourage the whole of the nation to question how many other pieces of legislation are now in jeopardy because of this device?'. Are we to bring this nation to a standstill because of a rabble Opposition which will deny regulations in the Senate? It is legitimate to disapprove of the form of regulations but not to reject the very substance that would bring the Bill into operation.

And the Opposition talks about principles! It talks about ministerial responsibility! The Leader of the Opposition has left the chamber but I remind him that when he was a very influential member of the Fraser Government on many occasions Ministers did not face issues too well. Let me remind somebody of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. Its report was a complete indictment of a Minister. The royal commissioner said, `I am bound to record my view that the Minister did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively'. What happened? The standard of propriety and principle in those days was not only to say that the Minister did nothing wrong but that the Royal Commissioner was no good. That is how strong the allegations were. The matter involved the whole of Australia's meat exports. It was appropriately referred to in the Washington Post as a rather extraordinary scandal. It appeared that Australia was being run by a bunch of hucksters out to con everybody they could.

One of the problems of the Government that fell was the bunch of hucksters out to con everybody-the Bjelke-Petersen syndrome. They got Mr Sankey to charge Ministers of the Whitlam Government in a Queanbeyan court on false charges and at the same time had a special one-day sitting of the Queensland Parliament to disclose information. That same Premier is hiding from inquiry at present. His Ministers will be in the witness box. The Police Commissioner and others in Queensland are worried about what will come out of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct because it will be devastating. It will relate to corruption, the rottenness, the deception that bedevils any legitimacy of government. Precedent is of no credit to the Opposition's present position.

When in opposition we fought tenaciously and effectively about the rottenness in administration of the then Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer. Not one effort was made to deal with the tax cheats or the tax crooks. It took Mr Costigan with his Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to bring out the fact that Mr O'Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation, was giving reports to the Leader of the Opposition as then Treasurer saying, `We are losing revenue with these straw companies. What are you going to do about it?'. The Leader of the Opposition did nothing. Billions of dollars were being lost. Yet the Leader of the Opposition today says that we have to do something about this legislation; it is wrong.

This legislation is aimed at crooks, tax cheats, those who defraud. People who are honest have nothing to fear; they have no problems at all. But little John opposite would be very mindful of the fact that when he was Treasurer he had all these matters in front of him and did nothing. The crooks had a marvellous time. Because we now attempt to bring in legislation so that people at least will have to prove their identity when dealing in cash transactions or real estate or to get some payment from the nation he says that that is a dreadful thing to do. He suggests that this is fraudulent legislation and that it will be disallowed in the Senate because that is appropriate. How fraudulent is that approach! The Leader of the Opposition laughs.

If that precedent is set the Senate would be able to bring down all the legislation I have mentioned. It all depends on regulation. This naivety has been displayed because John Stone has found a friendly, well-mentioned and certainly appropriate person to say, `Any legislation which contains a provision that its effective date will be set by regulation can be disallowed by the Senate'. That is not news; what is news is that the Senate has been told in advance that for the first time in Australia's history it will disallow a substantive Bill by this device. If that precedent is set, the Opposition will bring down the whole of the taxation regime, the whole of the Customs regime and the whole of the navigation regime.

The Opposition will do nothing to legitimise its position; all it has indicated quite clearly is that it does not want to have an Australia Card which will prevent corruption. That is not a surprise to us. When we look at the extent of corruption in this country at present and look at the range of laws the present Opposition could have introduced, we see that it did nothing. During its time in government, it could have introduced extradition treaties to bring back crooks and people who sometimes had seven or eight different passports. The passport situation had to be tightened up by way of identification, verification and supportive evidence. That has now been done, and so the reason for this motion is not only to censure the Leader of the Opposition for his stupidity but also to warn the Australian people that if this is the yardstick, if we adopt the principle that the Senate can disapprove of legislation-though not by legitimately using its numbers, because we can use section 57 of the Constitution to have a joint sitting and get it through-the Opposition can deny the validity of that Constitution, can deny the will of the people by saying that the elected representatives in a joint meeting cannot pass a law because the Senate, the Opposition having exercised its dictates over its senators, will disallow regulations.

There has been no incompetence involved in the presentation of the legislation. It is extraordinary that for the first time in this country it is now being said that the Senate has supreme power over all the legislation I have referred to just by the Opposition parties exercising their majority, which they do not have on a legitimate basis but which they certainly do on a party political basis, to disallow a particular piece of legislation. I think, then, what we are saying today is that it is an extraordinary situation to have the whole principle of government brought to nought because in future the Senate will be able to disallow regulations on which all these pieces of legislation are now based and which can survive only if they have that entitlement. Accordingly, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a list of legislation that is now dependent on the very principle that this Government is entitled to uphold and for which it is entitled to censure the Leader of the Opposition.
Leave granted.
