SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pathetic government this is. How embarrassed proper, decent, ordinary Australians would be if they realised that this Government is not prepared to accept the consequences of legislation properly passed and enacted by the Parliament; that this Government is not prepared to accept, other than when it suits its own convenience, that the Parliament, or either House of it, should exercise the powers conferred in order to consider regulations brought before it. But how pathetic is this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who has come into this place and abused a totally innocent citizen; a man who served this Commonwealth well; a man who over the course of his professional career has advised governments from both sides of politics; and a man who has rendered honourably and well his duty as a public servant and who now, as a public citizen concerned with the rights of the individual and the intrusion that the identity card proposal represents, has seen fit to give advice, the accuracy of which no one disputes, which we all recognise is valid to the core of constitutional responsibility of each chamber but which in some way is now used by the Prime Minister as a vehicle to condemn and criticise that individual. I do not think there has been any more pitiful action by any individual in this place, but how much worse it is when the man is the Prime Minister, whose ego is so inflated that he cannot realise faults in himself but must find them in others.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole of this morning's proceedings, tactically and in substance, are probably some of the more inept of any that I can recall in the few years that I have been around this place. Over the course of the next little while I would like to look at a number of areas with respect to the substance of the Government's allegations. Let us look first at its complaint this morning that for us as members of the Liberal and National parties to have the effrontery to say that we will exercise the proper parliamentary authority given to us by the Acts Interpretation Act is something that is in some way constitutionally wrong. We all need to understand that section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act, under the heading `Regulations', specifically says that any regulations that are not laid before each House of the Parliament shall be void and of no effect. Sub-section (4) states:

If either House of the Parliament, in pursuance of a motion of which notice has been given within fifteen sitting days after any regulations have been laid before that House, passes a resolution disallowing any of those regulations, any regulation so disallowed shall thereupon cease to have effect.

Do not let anyone have any illusion as to the constitutional propriety of either the Senate or the House of Representatives properly exercising authority conferred on it under the Acts Interpretation Act, as I have just read out. So much for the constitutional propriety of this whole affair. The Government knows that what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said yesterday on the advice that was tendered to us by that very distinguished citizen of Australia is totally correct. It is not only constitutionally proper but also were that right not to be exercised we would not be acting in accordance with the rights and prerogatives that election to this chamber and to the other place confers upon us. So as to constitutional propriety, let us throw that back where it properly lies.

The second issue, and perhaps the one that is even more substantial, is that somehow or other as a result of action by the Liberal and National parties we are going in some way to prevent the taxpayers saving something like $1 billion simply because the processes and procedures that the identity card was going to put in place in some way apparently would have led to that degree of savings. As the Leader of the Opposition has said, the Government has not been able, let alone prepared, to present to us any argument as to where this $1 billion fictional figure comes from. For a few minutes I want to explain to the Parliament and the people that over the course of some considerable time a whole array of people have said that the ID card is not the way to go. So it is not a matter of having any definitive amount before us; it is a matter of having a number of proper alternatives. I want to say to the people of Australia that had we not stated to them that we were prepared to exercise those responsibilities, the Government, blundering along, lurching from crisis to crisis as it has over the fortnight since we resumed, would have continued in its ineptitude not to apply the proper alternatives which would have enabled the taxpayers of Australia to save that $1 billion in other and more effective ways. I commend to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett)-there are three Ministers sitting here-a rereading of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I do not think all the alternatives of saving taxpayers' money were investigated, and the Government is avoiding its responsibilities totally. On page 150, recommendation 4.58 (i) states:

That the use of the tax file number be extended to cover all the financial transactions proposed in the Government submission for use of the Australian Card number by the Australian Taxation Office, as well as for social security purposes.
So the report refers to the tax file number. It is not something new. Ken Davidson wrote quite an extensive and very commendable article on this subject on 13 November 1986. He said then:

. . . the sole purpose of the Australia Card is to pick up tax cheats and illegal immigrants . . . it is possible to achieve both goals in a more cost-effective way without incipient dangers to privacy and civil liberties.

So the first recommendation of the Joint Select Committee gives the Government a vehicle whereby it could properly use the tax file number more widely and more effectively, but the Government has not adopted that recommendation. The second recommendation states:
That all other Departments (i.e. other than Australian Taxation Office and Department of Social Security) be barred from access to and use of the tax file number.

Let us contrast that with the message from the Minister. Some honourable members might have had the opportunity to learn a little about this man whom we believe should now resign from the Ministry. There is an interesting photograph of the Minister on page 14 of the November/December 1986 edition of The Australian Private Doctor. He is dressed up in a T-shirt. It hardly says a great deal for the man. It has on it `Condom Power-Roll On Responsibility'. Underneath the photograph are the words:

Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . we shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

Here is this man, who is not concerned about privacy-the second recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card was concerned with privacy-private property, the rights of the individual and about how he can best provide administration to cope with the problems of social welfare fraud, tax fraud and tax evasion. He is concerned about trying to ensure that his ideological commitment to intrude into the rights of the citizen-getting us all to have that tattooed number-should progress. The Joint Select Committee's third recommendation stated:

That the Medicare system continue to operate as a separate identity, but that the method of issuing new Medicare numbers and cards, be they new or replacement, be altered in order to improve the integrity of the system and reduce the issuing of multiple cards.

As we all heard this morning, the Medicare card is being thrown all around the place. Apparently, it is used by the Australian Federal Police and the State police. It is used within the Federal bureaucracy to check up on the whereabouts of individuals. There is no worry about privacy. If this is what is happening with the Medicare card, what will happen with the identity card? There is an alternative. The Joint Select Committee's fourth recommendation stated:
That the integrity of the tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number based on the following premises . . .
I shall not read out those premises. The fifth recommendation stated:

That a Parliamentary Committee be established within three years of the introduction of the upgraded tax file number system with the express task of reviewing the implementation of these recommendations. The Committee to report to Parliament on these matters and to recommend further action where necessary.

That is one package of recommendations, so let us put to rest the idea of this $1 billion. There are more effective, more efficient and proper ways which protect the rights of the individual-they do not intrude on the privacy of the citizen-and which would ensure that there is no tax evasion and social welfare fraud. Those ways are more effective than any measures that the Government has introduced. Let us put to rest the suggestion that there is some fanciful $1 billion at stake. It is not at stake. There are better ways of ensuring that we can get rid of tax evasion and social welfare fraud, but this Government has done nothing about it.

Let us put to rest the suggestion that, because of the actions which we are taking, we will lose $1 billion. That is poppycock. The Government knows it; the Prime Minister knows it; the Minister for Community Services and Health knows it. There are more effective ways of dealing with the problems but this Government has failed to implement them. It has tried to delude the Australian Electorate into believing that there is only one way to overcome tax evasion and social welfare fraud. We all know that is wrong-so does the Government, but it is not prepared to admit it.

Lest one thinks that that is the end of it, there are many other things that the Government could do. There is any number of recommendations which we have put forward. I shall not go into all of them now, because I do not have the time. I have a suggestion for the Minister for Community Services and Health which he should accept when he is considering the form of his resignation, which we expect to be tendered to the Prime Minister before this day is out. If he believes that the Department of Community Services and Health is immune from the need for more effective administration, he should read the 1985-86 annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions. In case the Minister does not know where to find that document, I point out that it was presented on 17 November last year and that it is Parliamentary Paper No. 363 of 1986. In that report the Director of Public Prosecutions properly identified several areas where more needs to be done. He said that the Government's health insurance legislation was too weak successfully to attack Medicare fraud. He stated:
While there are a number of reasons for this, one significant factor is that many serious cases are not being referred to the DPP simply because they have not been investigated.

I refer the Minister to page 18 of that report. It is important that we understand that the problem lies in a failure of administration-in the incompetence and inability of those responsible for administering, under the Minister's guidance, the Medicare scheme. The report stated that there were `a number of areas of concern in investigation and prosecution of welfare fraud' and that they were not being referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions simply because they were not being investigated by the Department. Let us put to rest the idea that this incompetent Government and incompetent Minister have put an adequate procedure in place.

It is important to understand what we believe is the purpose of the censure motion. Recently, we heard the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) tell us that we are on the road to Argentina. Twelve months ago, we heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tell us that we are becoming a banana republic. Today, we heard a pathetic response from a little man-a discredited Prime Minister, flawed in his understanding of the law and the constitution of the Parliament. The proposition which has been put to us is pathetic, painful and perilous in terms of the privacy of the citizen.

We believe that the natural processes and procedures of the Australia Card Bill are such that, if the Minister believed that it was inappropriate for regulations containing this power to be made under the legislation, he should have amended it. Six months ago, the Minister told us that the first Bill had been found to be flawed. He told Parliament and all of us that there would be changes. Knowing that the legislation was flawed with respect to the degree to which it protected privacy-as we were told during the past few weeks by the Minister for Community Services and Health, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) and even the Prime Minister-the Government told us that the legislation had to be in the same form, or there could not be a joint sitting.

This Government has abused its responsibilities to the Australian people by producing and forcing through this House legislation which it knows to be wrong. The Government knows also that it was wrong with respect to the date of implementation. Clause 32 (1) refers to those `relevant' days. That is a perfectly proper way for that provision to be in the legislation. The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 gives us the power to reject the regulations made under this legislation. Similar action has been taken on many occasions by the Senate and by honourable members on both sides of the House.

There is no choice. The Minister must resign. If he will not resign, the Prime Minister should call for his resignation. The Government must forthwith cease all expenditure on its computer programs and on the implementation of the ID card. The Government must ensure that this legislation is finally put to one side.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the censure motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and to look specifically at the Opposition's attack yesterday on the Australia Card. There are three parts of that attack which fully deserve the condemnation of the House. Firstly, there is an obvious and blatant distortion of the facts. Secondly, there is an abuse of the customs and traditions which have prevailed in this Parliament for 87 years. Thirdly, there is a defiance of the spirit of the Constitution in relation to the constitutional provisions for settling disputes between the Houses. Let me deal with each in turn and first with the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday and today the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) came into this House making much use of the terms `sloppy' and `fraud' in relation to clauses 40 to 54 of the Australia Card Bill 1986. One can only say in response to the Leader of the Opposition that he was extraordinary sloppy in the use of the word `sloppy'.

If one looks at the clauses of this rather complex Bill to which the Leader of the Opposition referred as `flawed' in some way, the first thing one can say about them is that they are fairly straightforward, impeccably drafted and lucid. They are certainly not ambiguous, they are certainly not vague, they are certainly not sloppy and they are certainly not flawed. It is true that there is a provision that certain critical dates will be introduced by regulation. I point out that this is the traditional method for provisions in Bills when the actual dates are uncertain. It has been a standard procedure in hundreds and hundreds of Bills-both controversial and non-controversial-and it is a tradition which has always been respected and not misused. Indeed, it has been part of the courtesies between the Executive and the Parliament, courtesies that have never before have been abused. Again, it is a feature of our parliamentary system. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who should know much better, got up and simply quoted a particular clause from a regulation. I have to point out that we all know that we cannot make this Parliament or this system work simply by observance of the letter of the law. The whole thing--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you should resign.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition should not interject.
—Resign.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell should not interject either. I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—The whole system is dependent upon customs, understanding, tolerance and give and take on either side. For instance, if the Government had abandoned the years of established practice, that is, if we had opted to set dates by proclamation, the Opposition parties in the Senate would have been the first to protest at the withdrawal of this courtesy. I will give some evidence on that point in a moment. Instead, they have now chosen to abuse what the Government has done, and I must say that courtesies that are abused are seldom extended lightly again. If anything has been sloppy and flawed in this process, it has been the shameless tactics and posturing of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me point out that one of the very few clauses commented upon unfavourably by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in the Senate was a clause in which we had not allowed for a power of review and the power of disallowance by the Senate. The Committee pointed out that it would like to see that. Now we have the defenders of the Senate saying, `You should not have done that; your legislation is flawed'-after we did the very things that the authorities in the Senate have demanded and that for so long have been the practices and customs of this Parliament.

As I have pointed out, the Bill has been to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It found no flaws in the drafting of those sections of the Bill to which the Leader of the Opposition referred. The Bill was, therefore, drafted in a responsible way and followed in these respects innumerable Bills, both controversial and non-controversial, introduced into this Parliament in the past 87 years. There is no flaw in the legislation; the flaw is in the opportunism of the Opposition. (Quorum formed) On this occasion the Opposition was prepared to breach and to deny the customs and the traditions of the Parliament that have existed for 87 years in its obsession to deny the Government the single most effective weapon against tax and welfare cheats. Honourable members opposite are quite prepared to be parliamentary vandals on these matters. Sadly, of course, the Australian Democrats are prepared to tag along with the Opposition quite heedless of the parliamentary and constitutional proprieties.

What must be remembered and what must be repeated day after day is this: never in the 87 years of this Parliament has an entire Bill been made inoperable by disallowing a regulation associated with a Bill. Never in 87 years has the principal Act not come into effect by use of the regulatory power. The Opposition is now threatening simply to wipe away the parliamentary practices and customs of the past 87 years. The only flaw, if such there be, was the Government's failure to recognise that it was dealing with a collection of parliamentary vandals perfectly willing to jettison the practices and customs of 87 years. Opportunism once more comes before any respect for the customs and traditions of the Parliament which have served us well for the past eight decades.

This-and I say it with respect-is part of the tragedy of the Leader of the Opposition. He is a person whom in many ways I once admired and whose talents I respect. But he came to the leadership with a reputation as a man of principle and has rapidly become simply an opportunist. He had a credible economic reputation and he has shed it with a massive and inappropriate tax bribe, and he now abandons the customs of the Parliament in order to deny the Government its single most effective weapon against tax and welfare cheats.

Moreover, the Opposition goes wider than simply parliamentary custom because the framers of our Constitution provided a most elaborate mechanism for resolving deadlocks. They insisted that legislation must be twice rejected by the Senate. Then they required a double dissolution on the issue and an intervening election. Then they demanded that the Bill again go to the Senate, if rejected, and that, if rejected again, it would go to a joint sitting of the Parliament which would make the decision. That is one of the most complex and difficult deadlock mechanisms in the world and there is no doubt that the founding fathers believed that any government that got through that series of hurdles deserved to have its legislation enacted into law.

But that is not good enough for this Opposition. Despite the fact that the Government has taken this Bill twice through the Parliament, had it rejected by the Senate, sought a dissolution on the grounds of this Bill, had an intervening election, came back into this Parliament and is now proceeding to a joint session, this Opposition says, `No, that is not sufficient. We will not accept the mechanisms laid down by the founding fathers'-pretty tough mechanisms, as we all recognise-`but we will ignore the spirit of the Constitution and impose this extra requirement on the Government by using this tactic'. It is not just a matter of ignoring the practices of this Parliament over 87 years; it is a denial of the very spirit of the Constitution which provides a complex means of settling deadlocks. The Opposition refuses to accept those procedures.

The wittiest line, I suppose, that was produced by the Leader of the Opposition was: `We have been stoic in our opposition to the Australia Card'. What utter balderdash! In mid-1985 many frontbenchers of those parties were more enthusiastic about the card than the Labor Government. Their statements are on the record. Of course, the matter was referred to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I suggest that the right honourable member for New England should listen to this point, because he obviously does not understand the process that has gone on in regard to this measure. The matter was referred to the Select Committee. The Opposition forces, in order to frustrate the Government, came up with the idea of a tax file number. But within six weeks they had abandoned the tax file number. They had done their job; they had frustrated the Government on the Select Committee. These stoic individuals, with their single-minded performance, supported in the Select Committee, frustrated the Government and then abandoned their tax file number idea. This morning was the first time that we have had a real burst from any leading figure from the Opposition in favour of tax file numbers. So there is an education process going on which might achieve some success.

What about the performance of this stoic Opposition during the election campaign? We went to the Governor-General and requested a double dissolution on the basis of the rejection of the Australia Card legislation. That request was granted and we made it quite clear to the electorate that if we were returned to government we would re-introduce the Bill and have a joint sitting. What did this stoic Opposition do? There was scarcely a squeak from any of its leading figures throughout the campaign. As I have said many times, it takes two to tango. It was a bit difficult for the Government to debate the matter during the election campaign when we did not get a squeak out of the Opposition. The newspapers tell us that we did not get a squeak out of these stoic, heroic opponents because they took a deliberate decision to play down the issue because they were afraid of the electoral backlash from those who rightly recognised the Opposition as being weak on tax evasion and welfare fraud. The performance yesterday and today by this Opposition is the crowning piece of opportunism that has characterised its total behaviour in relation to the Australia Card. It deserves the condemnation of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should give the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) the mafia kiss on the cheek. That is what he deserves.
—Order!

—Let me first speak to the Minister's remarks about the powers of double dissolutions. He mentioned the founding fathers' considerations. He forgot to tell the Parliament of the reason for the requirement for a three-month gap between the first and second introduction of a Bill, when a government goes down the double dissolution road. If he were to read the constitutional debates he would find that the founding fathers included that requirement so that there could be a public debate. He can check the newspapers of this country at that time until he is blue in the face; he will find no evidence of a public debate on the issues and on the facts that have now been exposed to the Australian people, which caused 20,000 or 30,000 of them to march in Perth yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: He quoted the founding fathers. He said, `I think it is reasonable to assume that at the time the founding fathers would have presumed that the government that won an election after a double dissolution would have had the support of a majority of Australians'. It is now a matter of record that only 45.8 per cent of the community voted for the Australian Labor Party, while 52 per cent voted against it by voting for the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats. The reality is that that argument falls to the ground.

Today the Prime Minister has served notice on the Australian people that he will proceed to bludgeon them with his personal proposal of an individual numbering system. That system will even deny them the right to sell their own labour. He intends that that measure will be passed. Government members know that that is so. He has made a decision to force it through a joint sitting. Having forced it through a joint sitting, he will wait for an opportunity to ambush the Senate by virtue of a couple of lines that are hidden away in some regulation. The people of Australia will have this sword of Damocles over their heads.

For that reason we give notice to the Government that we will continue to fight it until such time as it totally withdraws this legislation, admits that it is irrelevant, and gets on with the job of governing Australia and catching up with tax avoiders and social security cheats, which it can do by using the mechanisms and laws that are presently available to it. The Prime Minister had to write his own speech. He sees himself as a modern day Napoleon, sailing across Sydney Harbour in his barge. He believes it is good for Australia. He is not concerned with what might happen to Australians. He has forgotten the basic principles of government in this democracy-that is, the Government is here to serve the people, not to be served by the people. That is the point that must be made.

Let us take a quick look at the fundamental points of the Prime Minister's juvenile argument. I never cease to be amazed by the standard of argument presented by this Government. It is very much like saying, `My dad can beat your dad'. The Government does not get down to the issues. In fact, what did the Prime Minister give us? He gave us excuses, not reasons. One heard them very plainly in his speech. He quoted a few Opposition statements that were made previously, as though that matters to the public debate. The people have now made their judgment on this legislation, because they have been buying copies of it. Mr Ewart Smith felt constrained to buy a copy the other day. There has been a record run on the print. Mr Ewart Smith did so as a concerned Australian. He did not do so to trip this Government up. He did it to stop something for which he had a total abhorrence. Many Government members also have a total abhorrence for it, but they are ground down by the Prime Minister, this modern day Napoleon.

What were the other matters of substance in his speech? He gave us a fallacious argument on cost. He mentioned the mythical $1 billion, which he never attempts to justify. As a nice rounding-off measure, he reverted to the common tactic of the Government of personal abuse and a determination not to be confused by the facts. He had to get nasty with Ewart Smith. When we discovered that a person was being employed to trail behind Clarrie Briese in Sydney, the Government chose to attack that person's personal integrity. It could not even get that right. I believe it has cost the Government money.

Let us get straight why this issue has arisen. The Government set out to ambush the Australian people on this issue. It is no secret why the Government wanted to go down the regulation road, and I quote what the Minister said this week, at page 574 of Hansard:
. . . to put down a specific date without allowing some flexibility, and of course that flexibility relates to the regulations passed by this Parliament.

It did not have to use the regulation road. It could have included something in this legislation whereby the date was declared by proclamation, by Executive decision. It wanted to use the regulation road to maximise its flexibility, so that when that regulation was brought in and it wanted to add a few little lines that further intruded on the privacy of Australians, it could sneak them in at that time. It expected that a passive Senate would accept it. Of course, that is the next point: it got hoist with its own petard. It got caught out, and now it is claiming some special precedent. There is no such precedent in the Senate disallowing various regulations that are brought before it. We know that regulations are not something that the Government has to use. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) predicted disaster because future Senates might disallow a few regulations. Regulations do not stop us making laws; they just happen to meet the convenience of the bureaucracy in bringing in the detailed proposals after the Parliament has passed the legislation. There are ever-growing doubts about that process and where it is leading us.

Honourable members who have read what I have written on this subject would know that I believe that the regulations on a threshold measure such as this should be introduced with the Bill and properly debated in the Parliament so that we remove from Ministers this ambush technique which the Government so deviously chose to use and which has caught it out. The Government cannot claim that it needs a regulation to carry a piece of legislation. That is an absolute myth. A regulation is a convenience. There is evidence of that in the Parliament. I draw the attention of honourable members to page 2039 of the Senate Hansard of 16 May 1985. Quite surprisingly, in debating a motion for the disallowance of a regulation, the now Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), the Government's specially selected Minister to conduct the Government's ID card argument, said on this other issue:
I find myself in agreement with the view that if this Ordinance were to be disallowed we would have an opportunity to look at the whole matter afresh.
Senator Ryan, the lady who is now carrying the Government's ID card argument, said, in response to another motion for disallowance in the Senate:
I find myself in agreement with the view that if this Ordinance were to be disallowed we would have an opportunity to look at the whole matter afresh.

That is certainly what the Opposition is giving the Government in this case-an opportunity to look at how the community has woken up to the proposals that it has tried to sneak through this place. The Government has never addressed the issues in this matter.

I can give other examples. A disgraceful example can be seen on page 2143 of the Senate Hansard when the Senate carried a motion relating to the Government's attempts to get itself off the hook on Mudginberri. Another appears on page 2261 of Hansard when the Senate disallowed certain regulations regarding the Northern Prawn Fishery (Special Provisions) Management Plan. That is a regular occurrence in the Senate. There is no drama about it. It is highly unusual for a government to use a regulation purely to announce a future date of commencement. If it had not done so, it would not have been caught. The Government has been caught through its incompetence. It is no good.

Day after day this week we have had evidence of the incapacity of this Ministry-this mini-Ministry and maxi-Ministry-to answer questions in the Parliament which, of course, are asked on behalf of the Australian people. The Government has got it into its head that it is born to rule and can ignore the Australian people. Day after day we see the Prime Minister on television saying, `My response to decibel democracy'-decibel democracy, by the way, means the voice of the people-`is to tell you to get lost. I'm Napoleon. I can do this. I've conned you into a situation of re-electing me and you'll get what I want to give you because I think it's good for you. Don't worry. Don't be confused by the facts'. Our Prime Minister does not get confused by the facts; he just ignores, for instance, the basic objections of the Opposition. He used to hide behind threats and accusations that Opposition members were friends of tax avoiders. He never gets to the issues or explains to people what they mean to them.

The Government made a big thing in its advertisements of the idea that honest and decent Australians would have nothing to fear from the legislation. I will tell them what they have to fear: they have to fear a $20,000 fine-up to a maximum of $100,000-if, as an employer, they commit the horrible sin of failing to ask an employee for his ID card. No fine will be imposed on an employee who seeks to get employment while he is receiving a welfare benefit. No! Honest and decent employers who have never committed a fault in their lives--
Government members-Ha, ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it, from the laughter of Government members, that they say that all employers have done so. I will see that that is duly understood in the business community. I am saying that almost all of the 16 million people in our society are very honest and do not cheat on their tax or on welfare. The Government proposes to number all those people and to demand that they do not operate a bank account unless they use their number. The Government did not tell the Australian people that in its advertisements at the beginning of the election campaign. It did not tell real estate agents that they could face a $100,000 fine for failing to enforce its legislation. It did not tell people of the inconvenience that would be caused. The Government has attempted to excuse the intrusion into their privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did the Prime Minister not spend some time today reassuring Australians instead of spending part of his speech attacking the integrity of Mr Ewart Smith? Why did he not tell people that he can guarantee the security of the computer system? I tell honourable members that when he can do so we will not need the additional taxes; we will have some technology for which the rest of the world will pay anything. The rest of the world has not managed to come up with such technology yet. When the Government gets this new beaut unforgeable laminated ID card that no criminal can forge and so assume a plastic identity, when the Government produces the card which Senator Ryan has told the people about, it will not have to bother about the taxes it will collect by that mechanism. The banking industry of the world will give the Government billions for it. The Prime Minister's mythical $1 billion will come true. The Government will not need the tax. If it can produce such an ID card, Australia has it made; there will have been a technological breakthrough.

The Government has promised the Australian people, absolutely and untruthfully, that it can give them data transmission and credit card security that nobody else in the world has yet managed to achieve-even technological giants such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. I thought that one of the Government's speakers today would have tried to explain to the Australian people some of their concerns on that issue instead of jumping up and down on a fallacious argument about the rights and wrongs of government and parliament. The Government has not learnt that there are 16 million people out there. It sees an enemy on this side of the House and if we try to represent the people it sees the people as the enemy also. The Government's position will not change because it is too carried away with the numbers. It has so perfected the factional and numbering system that it believes that if it has the numbers it has everything.

We condemn the Government for what it has done. We condemn the Prime Minister, again, for not sacking a failed Minister. This Government has the biggest list in history. The Whip has some idea what a Minister can get into trouble with the Prime Minister for: if he does something that might hurt the prospects of the Australian Labor Party he is in trouble, but if he does something that hurts the prospects of the Australian people he is defended by the Prime Minister. That is where it has ended up. The Government has failed to tell the people what it is about. It has been caught by its own deviousness on this regulation issue. The Senate is absolutely right. The precedents are a mile long. Loss of regulation does not mean loss of legislation in the normal sense; it can always be inserted in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr YOUNG
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the twenty-first year in which we have seen further disintegration of the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party, since the resignation of Sir Robert Menzies, has continued to disintegrate because of poor leadership, the poor regard it has had for the Parliament and the poor regard it has in judging the issues which come before the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate those members who have spoken from the other side of the House this morning-the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey)-because they have discovered the Australia Card since the election. Prior to the debate last week, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party had never spoken on the Australia Card. That is how important they thought it was. They did not speak about it during the election or during the previous two debates that took place in this House. No! All of a sudden they have discovered the Australia Card. They want to base their arguments on the case of civil liberties. The Leader of the National Party was a Minister in the Government which put the birthdays of 18-year-olds into a barrel. He wants to talk about civil liberties; yet his Government picked birthdays out of a barrel to send 18-year-olds to Vietnam.

One of the things that the Liberal and National parties are frantic about, and one of the reasons why they feel that they may be on to a winner in terms of the blocking of this legislation by blocking the regulations, is that they are terrified that we will be able to introduce the Australia Card-the ID card-and have it in operation for a couple of years so people will see that all the frantic arguments and fearmongering that have been going on in the community for the last month or so are not a reality. They are frightened that, given the opportunity to test the legislation and the operation of the card, the people of Australia will find that most of the arguments that have been put up against the card cannot be sustained. That is what they are afraid of.

If the Opposition thought for one instant that the card is as bad as it is saying that it is, it would let it go through and make an issue of it at the next election. It would say, `We'll repeal it after the 1990 election' and would fight the next election on it. But it does not want to fight the next election on the ID card. It wants to stop it as soon as it can if it has got the power. It does not matter if it has to dismantle all the constitutional rights of the operations of Parliament. It does not want the people of Australia to see how successful the ID card will be.

All this argument is only part of what this Government has done-what previous Liberal governments would not do-in the whole field of fraud and tax evasion. We inherited a top taxation rate of 66c in the dollar in 1972 and a top rate of 60c in the dollar in 1983, and the average wage and salary earners of this country, all the decent people of this country, were paying far more taxes than they should have been because the Liberal and National parties would do nothing at all about tax evasion and fraud.

We should ask ourselves this question. In the last 4 1/2 years what proposal that the Government has brought forward in this Parliament, that has done something to try to relieve the great burden that is being carried by the average wage and salary earner, has been supported by the Liberal and National parties? None. The Opposition did not want the $1m superannuation in the payouts going to the extremely wealthy taxed above 5 per cent. It said, `Leave it like it is'. The Government was paying out $350m so that people could have free lunches around the country and at the next election, even three years later, the Liberal and National parties were saying, `Give them back the $350m on all the fringe benefits that were taken away, taxed or had to be justified'. What did the Liberal and National parties say? It was, `This is the end of Australia. We shall see the closing down of businesses wholesale. This is the end of Australia as we know it'. Is it the end? Last 1 July, we saw the distribution of $4.5 billion from the Government back to the average wage and salary earner in tax cuts. In the Budget we saw $500m go into the family package. The Opposition could not do that and keep all the rorts going. If we want to get some decency and equity into this country, we have to rewrite the rule book as it has been left to us by the Liberal and National parties in their term of government, particularly between 1975 and 1983.

Today, the Leader of the Opposition is still telling us that if he ever becomes Prime Minister he will give them back the $2 billion. Who are the mugs who are going to have to pay? They are the average wage and salary earners, who will have to pay more tax so that all the friends of the Opposition can have their free lunches, cars, golf club fees, education fees and trips overseas. They can have all this back to satisfy the whims of the Liberal and National parties. The Leader of the Opposition does not recognise the role of the Liberal Party-that is why he will always be a failure. In grasping at the opinion that was given to him yesterday saying that the Opposition should block the regulations, which effectively may block the legislation-not part of it, not a clause, but totally-he is forgetting that he has joined forces with the Democrats and perhaps some other forces over there who will never have the responsibility of governing in this country. The Liberal Party, as part of the Australian democracy, has set another precedent. It is like Malcolm parking his car round the back of Government House. It is just the same. The Leader of the Opposition is such a pathetic political figure. He grabs at anything at all anyone serves him up. He is like a canary in a cage. He just wants to be fed through the cage-anything at all so that someone will take notice of him. Here he is, beating his chest.

The Leader of the Opposition said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not make a good speech. The Prime Minister put up several arguments, none of which the Leader of the Opposition found time to answer in his half-hour speech. Is this going to be the rule of law in this Parliament? Is the Liberal Party now committed to finding the blocking of regulations to block legislation in total? Even the honourable member for O'Connor, as dimwitted as he is, is giving explanations about how members have said that on some occasions a specific regulation ought to be looked at again as it might affect one section of the Bill. What the Liberal Party is talking about is the total blocking of legislation, and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has listed-it can be read in Hansard tomorrow-all the legislation that is dependent on regulations that go alongside or run parallel to it. These are the sorts of things that this crowd are up to now.

In bringing equity and decency into the tax system, we are the first government to do a number of things of which we can be extremely proud. A fortnight ago, a couple of people were gaoled in Sydney after living the high life in Switzerland, living off the funds of drug running and all the rest of their capers that they were up to in Australia. They had a great time under the Fraser Government. Who caught them and put them in gaol? It was the Labor Government by the establishing of the National Crime Authority. Who is going to confiscate the millions of dollars that these people have in their bank accounts spread all over the world? What did the Liberal and National parties do? Sat there and did nothing at all, and they say that the ID card will not overcome anything.

Last year, the Australian Federal Police, in dealing only with serious social security crime, had 38,000 reports of social security fraud. The Liberal Party says, `Don't do anything about that. Don't take measures. Don't take decisions that might interfere with that. We are all about civil liberties now'. It has just discovered civil liberties. The Liberal Party standing for civil liberties. One could almost put it on a comic show and sell it to David Hill.

When the Prime Minister spoke about the elderly Jewish woman on Saturday he got derided by the Leader of the Opposition. Let me remind honourable members opposite about this. I see the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) come in. He spoke at an Adelaide meeting-that is his right-to protest against the ID card. They produced a person who, unfortunately, had been sentenced to Auschwitz during the Second World War and they reduced the argument. How dare they have the audacity to compare Australia, a democracy, this country, with nazi Germany in the argument over the ID card. They are prepared to do or say anything. If one does not have a proper argument and is not able to sustain a case that one wants to sustain against the Government, one does such things.

Of course there are some people in the Labor movement who oppose the ID card, and there are people in the Liberal Party who support it. We have never reached the level of the gutter where people are prepared to compare this great country, this democracy, where, just a few weeks ago, 10 million adults went to vote, with nazi Germany in order to sustain the case against the ID card. That is what the Opposition is prepared to do and that is why it is legitimate that the Prime Minister should introduce it.

If one has a look at all the things that we have done since we have been in government, the ID card does not come out of the blue. It is not something new. It is not something that is not associated with all the other things that we have done. The direct crediting of social security did away with a lot of fraud, as did the establishment of the National Crime Authority, the appointment of the Director of Public Prosecutions and all the things that we have done. We were the first government to initiate a total and comprehensive investigation of fraud in Australia. We did not introduce it because we thought it would be the end of the world.

We all wish we had a society where we did not even need to have a police force. Two hundred years ago people argued against the establishment of police forces, saying they would interfere with civil liberties-and, of course, in some ways they have. But who is arguing today against the establishment of a police force? One hundred years ago people argued against blood transfusions because they did not understand them or because other people mounted a fear-mongering campaign against them. The Liberal Party is again reduced to this rabble. Its members are prepared to do or say anything so that the average Australian wage and salary earners keep carrying this mammoth burden of taxation which has been placed on their backs by a continuation of Liberal-National Party governments.

Those opposite ought to be able, if they have enough courage, to present their case here. But what do they do? They tell us that they will block the regulations when the time comes. But yesterday they set up a committee. What will the committee do or say? The committee is a complete charade. Why do those opposite want to waste money on the committee? Why do they not do what they say they will do? Do it today and it will all be over and done with. But no, those opposite want to have some committee because they do not have sufficient numbers of people in the Liberal Party who understand what the Party's role ought to be. They are being run by people who have an inadequate understanding of the political system here in Australia. The leader of the Opposition will grasp at anything available so that people will take notice of him. All the things the Australian Labor Party has done to eradicate social security fraud and tax evasion are making life better for the average citizen. That is what the Labor Government is about. That is why the Labor Government will be re-elected in 1990.

We understand the frustrations of those opposite a few weeks after the election. We understand that they want to be frisky and show their opposition to some of the things we are doing. But come the day when the people again have to make a judgment on their woolly ideas, their lack of understanding and their preparedness to do anything in the use and abuse of parliamentary conventions, the Australian people, again by majority, will put this Government back in power. What those opposite did yesterday in suggesting their actions to come is totally reminiscent of what they did in 1975. The Liberal Party wants to make parliament inoperable because it suits it. Those opposite should just remember that they form the only other party that can govern and that the Liberal Party is playing handies, in order to carry out its threat, with people who will never have the responsibility of government. That is what those opposite are doing. They are getting into bed with people who have no responsibility for government. Whilst they continue in that vein and with that behaviour, they will never have the responsibility of government either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has never been an issue with as great a capacity as the Australia Card to divide the Australian population. This capacity was probably amply demonstrated in Perth yesterday when a crowd estimated at between 25,000 and 40,000 people marched on the Parliament House of that State. Nobody has ever before seen such an instant reaction through the streets of Perth. But this was just a culmination of dozens of demonstrations around Australia of decent, honest Australians who do not want any part of this identification card. It was a manifestation of the anger and concern being felt out there by ordinary, decent Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: When today we hear Government speakers one by one throwing derogatory remarks not only at people in this House but at people outside because of those people's genuine concerns, we really wonder what democracy is all about and why the people really have not had the capacity to have a decent debate on this card. For so long that capacity really has been denied. It is only in the last few weeks that we have seen this tremendous ground swell of opposition to the ID card welling up within the community. That demonstration yesterday in Perth was typical of what is happening in our community today. There is a real concern and worry that an identification system for all Australians will be introduced with provisions that are the toughest of any identification systems in any Western democracy today. That is really what this is all about.

Why should the Australian people be forced into this situation? Why should they have to bare their souls? It is all very well for the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to tell us time after time and day after day that all this is about is a bit of plastic with a photograph, date of birth and expiry date. It is much more than that. This identification system is the key to governments and Big Brother knowing all that needs to be known about Australian citizens. It is all very well for the Minister in this place and for Senator Ryan in the other place to say that there will be only this basic information on the card.

We just have to look at what happened overseas, the way such cards have developed and the concern being expressed now about them around the world. The case I always cite is Sweden because we are told by this Minister time and again that our system is based on the Swedish model. Sweden has had an identity card system for 20 years. It is only now, two decades later, that we have found out what unbelievable abuse its system has been subjected to-abuse not only by the bureaucracy and government but, indeed, by private industry. There should be legitimate concern by all Australians that the same thing can happen here. That is what our objection is all about. It absolutely amazes me that in this place over the last two weeks we have been told about the tremendous achievements of the Government. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), who has just spoken in the debate, told us about some of the things the Government has achieved. But it has achieved all this without an identification system. That whole process is in play now. The provision is there now for the Government to go ahead and get those tax cheats and the social security defrauders, bring them to justice and recover that money.

We really should ask ourselves the question: why do we need the card? Australians are now asking the question: why do we need an identity system, the like of which has not been seen in another Western democracy? That is what this is all about. The concern has gone beyond Sweden. It has spread throughout the world. Let us look at the situation that has developed in Germany in the last 12 months with its identification system. The police force there is now saying that it is worried about a police state. There are other examples. What happened in Canada when it tried to introduce an identification system? There are reports of what has happened there. What has happened in the United States? Its social security system, which frankly is not half as bad as the one being proposed here, is causing concern to civil libertarians there. We have seen some of the abuses perpetrated of that system.

In town after town, throughout the length and breadth of the country, we have seen in recent weeks a build-up of opposition and concern by ordinary, honest Australians who want to know why we have to have the national identification number. If we look at the early rallies in Sydney which drew only 400 people, the early rallies in Melbourne that drew 800, the early rallies in Brisbane that drew 1,000, the rallies in Adelaide that drew 5,000 and 6,000 people and now this rally in Perth that has drawn 25,000, we see an indication of the concern. These rallies and public meetings will not stop until the identification card legislation is withdrawn from this House and thrown on the scrap-heap where it deserves to be. In the next few days alone, in places as far stretched as Perth, Cloncurry and Mount Isa, Dural in Sydney and Stafford in Brisbane, these rallies will continue to be held and people will continue to express the tremendous concern that they have about this legislation.

What has happened in this House in the last fortnight? How many names have been attached to petitions that have been presented in this place, and, indeed, in the Senate? Hundreds of thousands of names of ordinary, decent Australians have been presented to this place. Does the Government want to take any notice of this particular concern by the general population? No. It says, `We are going to proceed with it'. How many bags of mail from people who have written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) genuinely expressing their concern have been received? I bet that there have been absolutely dozens. Will the Prime Minister take any notice of this? Of course he will not. What other avenues do the people of Australia have to be able to get to a situation where the ID card legislation will be withdrawn? It has been perfectly legitimate for the Opposition parties to come here and tell the Government exactly what they are going to do because the Government's defective legislation.

Let us not forget that the Minister for Community Services and Health has been in control of this legislation. He has provided the defective legislation in this House. I do not think Australians as a whole would want to be part of any of this defective legislation. It is a legitimate right of the duly elected representatives of the House of Representatives and the senate to oppose this legislation to the best of their ability. That is exactly what we are going to do because this legislation has no part in our way of life. This legislation is more akin to what is happening in some of the Eastern bloc countries than in a free and open democracy such as Australia. Australians have always believed that democracy is the right of the people and that the Parliament is the servant of the people. We are having the complete reverse now. We have a situation where the Government will impose a number on every citizen. The people of Australia, whether they are guilty or not, will become very much the servants of the Government of this place. I believe that that is un-Australian. I believe that the vast majority of Australians want no part in it at all.

Even though we might stand here and talk about the hundreds of thousands of names that have gone through on the petitions, why do we not even look to those revered sources that the Government uses so much-the market research companies-to see what has happened in recent weeks. Sure, a lot of Australians thought an identity card system was probably fair enough in catching dole fraud and in bringing to justice people who might evade taxation. In fact, that figure was something like 68 per cent a year or two ago, but look at the dramatic fall that is going on now. Just two months ago the figures came out and there was only a 55 per cent approval rating. Look at what happened just last week on the latest market research-the approval rating was down to 39 per cent. What is wrong with the Government? It is turning around now and spending something like $100,000 on a market research program on the card legislation. What is that going to tell it? I will tell honourable members what that will tell the Government. It will tell it that the great bulk of the people of Australia want no part of an identity card whatsoever. Will the Government take any notice of that? No.

Why is the Government going against the very wishes of the population? Why is the Government saying, `We are going to proceed with this.'? Why is the Government saying, `We are going to declare all Australians guilty rather than prove their innocence.'? I think that the idea of going to another Senate inquiry is the right way to go because the big, fatal flaw in that last inquiry-even though the bulk of the members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card came out against it-was that they did not really have the legislation to enable them to sit down and analyse it. I think that the analysis by that Committee in the coming weeks in the Senate will be fascinating. Is it not a fact that Senator Bolkus from South Australia is going to chair that Committee? That will be absolutely fascinating. How many of the other members of the Government benches will now have the intestinal fortitude to come out and express their real concerns about what is involved in the ID card?

It is a fact that 32 members of the Labor Party are opposed to the ID card. That is not a bad sort of percentage within one's own ranks to be concerned about. Why have we got this continual arrogance from Government Ministers and from the Prime Minister himself who says that he is going to proceed with this legislation no matter what? It is about time that those members of the Labor Party who are genuinely concerned with civil liberties really put their money where their mouth is and come out publicly and say, `We are opposed to this'.

In recent weeks I have spoken on a number of platforms around Australia. Some fairly interesting people have been on those platforms. Since when has the Society of Labor Lawyers been insignificant within the ranks of the Labor Party because they have spoken there? Since when has the Council for Civil Liberties been diverse enemies of the Australian Labor Party because they have been there? Even some of the Labor Party's left wing mates with the Builders Labourers Federation have been on those platforms and they have expressed their concern. What has happened in Australia by virtue of this legislation is that there has been a coming together of all sections of Australian society to oppose this legislation which really is a blight on democracy in Australia. What must happen out there in the community now is that the rage must be maintained.

If the Prime Minister and the Minister for Community Services and Health are convinced that they must proceed with this legislation, then it is the duty of all fair minded democrats in Australia to let the Government know their real concern about what is really involved in this whole ID card issue. Australians who believe that this legislation is wrong must let their feelings be known.

I think that we should make an appeal today to ensure that those petitions continue to be signed. We should make an appeal today to every Australian who is opposed to the ID card to sit down and write a letter to the Prime Minister. He will not read them, but he can count the numbers. We must make sure that the Prime Minister realises the very depth of objection in the community today to this insidious piece of legislation. The ID numbering system should have no part in a democracy such as Australia; it should have no part in a country that has enjoyed its freedoms for 200 years. This identification system is the worst kind of gift that this Government could possibly impose on Australia during our Bicentennial year. The Opposition will continue to oppose the ID card legislation. We know it is dead in the water now. The Government really has only one option; that is to do the decent and honourable thing-bury the ID card straight away. It should get rid of that legislation because it has no part in a free society such as Australia.
