TALK.START.PARA: —As a courtesy, I inform the House that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is still unwell. Any questions normally addressed to Mr Keating should be directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED IDENTITY CARD: ADVICE TO GOVERNOR-GENERAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Prime Minister, when he asked for a double dissolution which could lead to the passage of the identity card legislation at a joint sitting inform the Governor-General that the legislation would be inoperative unless the Senate, having first voted against the Bill, then approved regulations to bring it into operation?
—A brilliant question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A profound question, and I thank the honourable gentleman for it. I think that it is well known that the Governor-General is an assiduous occupant of that office. He brings to it considerable experience as a justice of the High Court of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Just wait, and honourable members will get the answer. I assure the House from my experience in dealing with the Governor-General that he is assiduous in reading all the material that goes to him. All those who have had to deal with him are aware that he operates in that manner. I did not insult the intelligence of the Governor-General by raising any question concerning any assumption that the historical practice of 87 years which had continued in an unbroken fashion would be broken. I suppose that, knowing the moral bankruptcy of those opposite, I should not have given them the credit that I implicitly did.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the Government's attitude to the foreshadowed bipartisan caretaker government to be formed in Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fowler for his question. As distinct from those matters which divided the House this morning, I expect that the response which I am pleased to be able to give the honourable member will meet with the support of all honourable members.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government welcomes yesterday's announcement that a council of state is to be formed in Fiji, headed by the Governor-General, Sir Penaia Ganilau, and comprising a balance of coalition and alliance members. We believe that the announcement constitutes a fundamentally important step towards a return to full parliamentary democracy in Fiji-a goal which I believe is supported by all honourable members. I think that it is proper to observe that this position has been reached as the result of Sir Penaia's tireless and dedicated work, Dr Bavadra's willingness to negotiate and his statesmanlike behaviour in dropping the writ against the Governor-General and the significant role played by Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. We also hope that this agreement will lead to a reduction in tension in Fiji and in particular will contribute to the maintenance of law and order to the equal benefit of all the peoples of Fiji.

As you are aware, Madam Speaker, from the very beginning my Government has made clear its preparedness to respond in kind to positive developments in Fiji. Once Fiji's new government is in place-consisting of Fiji's main political parties, including the coalition which formed government after Fiji's last elections-the Australian Government will be in a position to rebuild co-operation with Fiji in the many areas of common interest. The Government welcomes this latest development. I trust that in saying that I speak on behalf of all members of this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to comments today by the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, that it was absurd of the Government to compare the Opposition's decision to block the identity card regulations with the blocking of Supply in 1975. In view of the Prime Minister's claim, repeated a moment ago, that the Opposition's action violates an 87-year-old convention-which, of course, we reject-what steps will he take to ensure that the party line is observed by all his State colleagues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The easiest way at this point to deal with this question is to refer to some statements made this morning which have just been brought to my attention. They were made by the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Reith.

ANSWER.PARA: Government members-Who?

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members are entitled to ask who he is. I had to check whether he was the shadow Attorney-General, but he is. As I said in the debate this morning, there is no flaw in the drafting. The flaw is in the Opposition in tearing up 87 years of convention. That point was effectively conceded this morning by the shadow Attorney-General on the Prue Goward program, when he correctly said:

ANSWER.PARA: Under our law we've got this very good system which says that if the Government's going to make Regulations, before they actually become operative the Parliament can have a closer look at them and say somebody's drawn it up wrongly or there's something in it that goes beyond what the Parliament may have originally intended.
Having put that position correctly, the shadow Attorney-General went on to say:
There have been many instances where Regulations have been knocked back by the Senate because they've gone too far, they've been extreme or it might be beyond what's been intended by the Parliament.

That statement is absolutely correct. The Leader of the Opposition, rather than asking his fanciful questions, might explain in terms of the statement by his shadow Attorney-General how the Australia Card regulations, which provide for a commencement date, either go too far, are extreme or are beyond what has been intended by the Parliament. The shadow Attorney-General has correctly articulated past practice. By the standards and criteria of the shadow Attorney-General, the Opposition has been guilty of breaking the practice and convention of the past 87 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to claims about the effect of the recent Budget on pensioners. Will he inform the House about the progress by the Government in reaching the target of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the strongest planks of the Australian Labor Party's platform and our most consistent election promise has been the maintenance of living standards for Australia's two million pensioners. The Prime Minister promised in his 1983 election campaign, and he repeated it in 1985 and 1987, that he would bring the pension rate up to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Labor believes that, despite the very difficult economic circumstances Australia faces, the incomes of the least well off should be protected. I am pleased to say that this target has almost been reached. As of June 1987, the pension rate equalled 24.8 per cent. Labor has wiped out the legacy of disregard for pensioners' incomes under the previous Government. The pension rate was as low as 22.7 per cent when we came to office despite the fact that we were looking at a prospective deficit of more than $8 billion. Labor will have added an extra $38.85 to the standard pension rate between December 1982 and December 1987. Substantial allocations of funds have been needed to achieve these goals. This financial year the indexation increases alone will add more than $1 billion to government outlays-more than $1 billion into the pockets of pensioners at a time of very considerable restraint in government spending and community incomes and, incidentally, at a time when this Government has achieved almost a balanced Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us not forget the contrast with the Opposition's plans to cut into pensions and benefit incomes. No one wants to return to a situation in which indexation was dropped for a year, as it was under the Fraser-Howard Government, or in which pensions drop, as they did, by 2.4 per cent in real terms. One has to remember that, at a time when this Government has achieved very significant real increases in pensioner incomes, at the end of this year we will have more than doubled the additional pension and benefit paid for children of pensioner and beneficiary families, doubled the mother's guardian's allowance, and increased supplementary payments, in terms of rent assistance, by 50c in the dollar.

In my view, it is not too much to say that, in the discussions we have had in this Parliament in the last several days, we see underlined in the clearest possible terms the difference between honourable members on the Opposition side of the House and honourable members on the Government side of the House. On the one hand, every measure that we have introduced in this Parliament and every measure that has been designed to ensure that those who can afford to, pay their taxes, has ultimately been resisted by the Opposition, including the last measure, the Australia Card. On the other hand the Opposition has made constant suggestions to us that we ought to cut back on the incomes of the very poor. The record of this Government with respect to pensioners and low income people in the community stands up well against the record of any government in this country and it certainly contrasts with the shabbiness of the Opposition's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House, firstly, what preparation has taken place to date for the introduction of the Government's ID card and, secondly, how much money has been committed or expended on its introduction?

—If the honourable member were aware of the decisions made by this House, he would know that a sunset clause on expenditure on the Australia Card came into effect at the end of December 1986. Therefore, it has not been possible for the Government to expend moneys on the card since that date and most of the planning, therefore, has ceased. But there was an allocation in this year's Budget which was based on the assumption that the Australia Card would be passing through the Joint Sitting towards the end of this year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) has been the target of criticism and cynicism recently. Does the Minister have any comment in response to those criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it very disappointing that a fair amount of cynical criticism has been pointed in the direction of the Institute of Sport in the last couple of weeks. I note that the honourable member for Fraser has a very active interest in the Institute of Sport, it being sited in his electorate. Considering that on most issues we have had a fairly bipartisan attitude towards the Institute of Sport I am sure that every member of this House would share my disappointment that obviously some anti-AIS or ill-informed members of the media have sought to point great criticism at the Institute of Sport, basically arising from Australia's lack of gold medals at the World Athletics Championships which were recently held in Rome. I might add as a sideline that almost every medal was won by athletes from behind the Iron Curtain.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is a pity that Australians are not out there shouting aloud with pride about the Institute of Sport. Only six years ago a former Liberal Minister, Bob Ellicott, to his great credit, set up the Institute of Sport and I am pleased to say that he is now a life member of that Institute, and so he should be. It has achieved remarkable success on the international stage with the athletes who have had the use of its facilities. It is certainly recognised in almost every country that has an interest in sport as being the best of its kind in the world in terms of the facilities for Australia's elite athletes and in terms of sports medicine and research. It seems to me to be a pity that the great Australian tradition of knocking seems to direct this sort of criticism at the AIS in a very unjustified fashion.

Despite all the criticism that was directed about the lack of athletics gold medals, I was very pleased to see this week that the Press reported two very significant successes, but in very muted terms. The Australian men's under-16 tennis team won the world's championship for the second time in a row, but it merited very little Press in comparison with the headlines that greeted our lack of success in athletics. At the same time, one of the young women at our squash division in Brisbane, Sarah Fitzgerald, with the advantage of having been coached by the great Heather McKay who is probably the world's greatest squash player ever, man or woman, has again won the world's junior women's championship. But again there was very little Press. This can be repeated in a whole host of activities for the 15 residential sports and for something like 45 visiting sports that bring elite athletes into Canberra.

I think the investment that this Government has made in the Institute of Sport following its inception by Bob Ellicott back in 1980 has been a marvellous investment in terms of allowing our athletes, who have brought us so much national pride over a long time, an opportunity to compete on equal terms with their peers around the world. I hope that all sections of the media will take a more positive view of something about which we should all be proud and drop that mocking attitude about Australia's lack of success in one sport.

One pertinent point should be made. It is a strict rule that the Institute of Sport in Canberra is a totally drug-free environment. I am sure that every member of this House believes, as I do, that we do not want to win gold medals if they are produced by artificial performances, resulting from the ingestion of any form of artificial stimulant. I assure every member of the House that a very strict regime of drug testing takes place at the Institute of Sport and every athlete and every coach is warned that any suggestion of any form of drug taking will lead to instant dismissal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the report on fraud on the Commonwealth which I understand is shortly to be presented to the Parliament. I ask: Will he assure the House that neither the final report nor any of the draft reports have been amended so as to delete any estimate of the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth? Will the entire report be tabled? Does this latest report establish that the more cost-effective means of combating fraud is better administration rather than the intrusive ID card?

—The fraud report has been received and is now before Cabinet. I expect that it will be tabled very soon. In respect of the particular matters that the honourable gentleman mentioned, as he would expect, fraud, of course, does take place if there can be some deviation from departmental procedures or their enforcement. The report does talk about looking at departmental procedures. Of course, that is an obvious matter. In respect of the specific question about the merits of the Australia Card, one will find on page 100 of the report that the Australia Card is given very strong support on the basis that it would certainly have a great advantage and it would have an effective benefit to cost ratio of 6 : 1.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Did the Government's information paper, The Defence of Australia, issued in March this year, state that the most important part of the United States system for early warning of ballistic missile attack in which Australia is involved is known as the defence support program (DSP), and that this program assists in reducing the risk of nuclear war and contributes to stability in the super-power relationship? Is the Minister aware of recent claims in a number of places that the capabilities of the DSP system, supported by the Australian-United States joint facilities, go beyond what is needed for early warning, and in fact give the system what are known as war-fighting capabilities? Can the Minister indicate the facts in this matter? Does the DSP have war fighting capabilities which go beyond its early warning function, or does it not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the claims that have been made. Some of them have been made by people who have made, and continue to make, a very substantial contribution to the strategic debate in this country. They require a detailed answer. The claims are based on a number of assertions about the specific capabilities of the system. While I am not prepared to indicate whether each and every statement made about the joint facilities is true or false, I assure the honourable member that a number of these assertions are incorrect. For example, the DSP satellites are said to carry: ultraviolet sensors which are able to detect the fluorescence from gases surrounding the booster or nose cones of missiles in flight, and thereby enable the missiles to be tracked; a visible light sensor which enables observers to view the plumes of intercontinental ballistic missiles as they are launched, and which might also be used for some reconnaissance purposes; infra-red equipment that can provide data on warhead energy levels and types, as well as data on warhead impact points for post-attack assessment; and nuclear detonation sensors able to determine the site of nuclear detonations to an accuracy of about 100 metres. None of these assertions is correct. As the capabilities in question are the ones which would be necessary if DSP were to have usefulness, for so-called nuclear war-fighting strategies, the conclusion logically follows that the description of the DSP in the Government's White Paper is the correct one.

ANSWER.PARA: For the record, I also point out that possible improvements in the United States' missile attack warning systems should not be taken to mean that the DSP will in future acquire these nuclear war-fighting capabilities. Some of the capabilities mentioned by some commentators too have been under development in the program once known as DSP 2, or the advanced warning system, are actually intended to form the basis of an altogether different warning system that may replace the DSP. That system was renamed the booster surveillance and tracking system and incorporated in the strategic defence initiative (SDI) research program some years ago.

The United States has not sought to involve any of the joint defence facilities in Australia in its plans for developing or operating such a system; nor, lest there still be any doubt on this point, are the joint defence facilities in Australia involved in SDI. To claim, as some have done, that the facilities are so involved simply because information that has been collected in accordance with their mission requirements may later have been used in some SDI-related applications, stretches the language and common sense seams to breaking point. Any such data collected at the Australian sites has not been collected for the purposes of SDI research, but specifically to support the early warning function of the DSP. Any other use to which the data may be put is quite incidental and does not derogate from its purpose in enhancing early warning. I repeat that the joint defence facilities in Australia do not form part of the SDI. There have been no changes to the missions, functions or manning of the facilities to assist in SDI research. The United States SDI program is an entirely separate activity with altogether different funding and staffing. The Australian Government does not participate in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. Yesterday I asked the Minister why steps were not taken on 24 March 1987 to cancel the coastal surveillance contract with Amann Aviation Pty Ltd when it became known that the Department of Aviation had very serious reservations about that company's ability to meet the terms of the contract. The Minister undertook to obtain `a report on the details of the matter'. The Minister has not done this. He has instead supplied me with a letter drawing my attention to previous comments recorded in Hansard. I now ask the Minister: Why has he misled the House for the fifth time in a week? Why did he not answer the question I asked yesterday? Why was the Amann contract not cancelled?
—I refer the honourable member to the letter that I gave him last night which addressed the matters about which he questioned me yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the Minister's self-description as the mayor of Canberra, and because this Parliament is about the only establishment in the nation's capital that remotely resembles a town hall, will the Minister urge the flying of the flag of the Canberra-Queanbeyan Raiders above this building following their win against Manly-Warringah on Sunday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: may I add to the question by asking the Minister whether he will fly the Manly-Warringah flag, should it be successful on Sunday?

—I must confess that this question was not entirely without notice. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro did have the decency to tell me that he was going to ask it. I checked with Madam Speaker. The answer is no, on a couple of grounds: the President of the Senate, of course, like the honourable member for Warringah, is an avowed Manly supporter, so that would create a difficulty. Of course, Madam Speaker is a great Hawthorn supporter. There is really a dichotomy of interests that would preclude the flying of the Raiders flag.

ANSWER.PARA: On that subject, I think that everybody in Canberra-the quarter of a million people who live here and those of us who live here temporarily-are very proud of the achievements of the Raiders this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all from Queensland.

—Nobody is perfect. We all have our difficulties. I am sure that when the Raiders run on to the Sydney Cricket Ground on Sunday they will be carrying the hopes and aspirations of a quarter of a million Canberrans. If the win of the Raiders on Sunday has the same significant psychological uplift for the people of Canberra-at a time when they are espousing independence and an identity which is singular to them-as the win Parramatta had in the early 1980s in terms of stirring up the people of the western suburbs, it will be well won. I assure the honourable member for Eden-Monaro that my wishes, and the wishes of 250,000 Canberrans, run with the Raiders on Sunday.

—I ask the Minister for Community Services and Health: Did parliamentary counsel draw the attention of the Minister to the fact that the relevant dates designated under the Australia Card Bill would be the subject of regulations when the Bill was cleared by the legislation committee of Cabinet? Was the possibility of those relevant dates being fixed by proclamation rather than by regulation specifically canvassed at any stage during the approval process of the legislation by the Government?
—The answer to the question by the Leader of the Opposition is no. At no stage was this issue brought to my attention by the officials, but of course it is important--
—Parliamentary counsel?
—Brought to my attention, yes.
—But were you at the legislation committee's meeting?
—Order!
—What I am saying, quite clearly, is that none of the officials advising the Government raised with me any problems in relation to these provisions.
—No, no, no-not a problem. That is not what I asked.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.

—All I can say is that no problems in relation to this issue were raised by any of the advisers to me on this matter. However, I have to say that it is fairly important that at that stage everybody was acting on the assumption that the rules of this Parliament would not suddenly be torn up by the Opposition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Government asked the New South Wales Government to reduce its taxes and charges on the coal industry? What assistance will the Commonwealth Government give? What progress has been made in developing a long term strategy for the Australian coal industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Macarthur for his question. He has a very great and dedicated interest in the coal industry. The Prime Minister has written to the New South Wales Premier, Mr Unsworth, asking that his Government give close consideration to the effect of State charges as they apply to mines in that State considered to be at risk.

ANSWER.PARA: Overall, our coal industry is one of the most efficient, low cost, major coal exporters in the world. What we have is a situation where, with oversupply and intense competition, prices have dropped to so low a level that the viability of individual mines is at risk. Since late last year there have been 15 mine closures and almost 2,000 retrenchments or voluntary retirements.

Reflecting the deteriorating financial position of coal companies, another major producer, Austen and Butta, reported yesterday a $16m operating loss last financial year after closing three of its mines and further rationalising its local operations. The company, like others with mines at risk, is seeking further reductions in government charges.

Over recent weeks, I and the Government have been examining closely the financial situation of the industry and one must conclude that one of the barriers to the financial viability of at-risk mines is State charges. There is not much scope for reductions in Commonwealth charges. These are minimal in the overall context and would do very little to reduce operating costs. For example, the Commonwealth has collected only about $13m in company tax from the New South Wales coal industry over the past three years. Even in the so-called free enterprise, but now known as the corrupt State of Queensland, the charges on the industry almost amount to extortion.

What the Commonwealth has proposed is to put forward for discussion a paper on a strategy for the industry which will address development, marketing, conservation and industrial relations issues. I do not imagine that the discussion of an appropriate strategy will be a quick process. We will try to achieve a common understanding of the problems and some agreement on how best they should be tackled, bearing in mind the Commonwealth Government's firm view that a national marketing authority is no solution. While that discussion is going on, industry parties should not see it as in any way removing the need for progress on industry issues, particularly productivity increases and industry costs generally but including State charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Hon. Frank Crean, a former Minister in the Whitlam Government, is present in the gallery this afternoon. On behalf of the House I bid him welcome.
—Will the Minister for Community Services and Health table in the Parliament the memorandum relating to the Australia Card Bill prepared by parliamentary counsel for the legislation committee?

—I would be prepared to lay that document before the House, but I make one point about the Leader of the Opposition's previous question. What I was saying then was that I do not recollect any problems being raised-I think that I would have even though it was about a year ago-but it may well be that there is simply a note to the effect of the clauses without it raising any issues in relation to those clauses.
—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training indicate to the House the latest trends in the rates of participation in the work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and indicate that there has been a very impressive performance as far as the labour market is concerned over the three or four years that this Government has been in office. We must remember, of course, that when we came in there was an unemployment rate of some 10.3 per cent and that, as at August this year, the rate was some 8.1 per cent. This has been achieved at a time when the participation rate in the work force has been increasing. That means that the Government's performance in being able to stimulate the labour market, thus creating in excess of 828,000 jobs, is very impressive indeed. It is one which compares extremely favourably with performances of other countries, particularly members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the major reason why at the last election the people decided that this Government's policies were the ones which were totally appropriate to the circumstances in which Australia finds itself not only as we work our way through the most massive form of structural change which is necessary but also as we have been able to do so without bringing about the sort of cataclysm which is often associated with that kind of structural change when it has occurred in other countries. Not only has our success in the last four years been an enormous achievement but also it portends extremely well for the next few years as we continue to see the success of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Have drafting instructions been given to parliamentary counsel to redraft the Australia Card legislation to accommodate a number of amendments to the existing legislation? If so, when; and along what lines?

—I know that amendments have been discussed, but I am not aware of any drafting instructions having been issued to prepare those amendments. I will certainly take this up with my colleague Senator Ryan.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: What benefits will the Government's new family package provide for low income wage earners? How do these benefits compare with claims made yesterday by the Victorian National Party that the family package will do nothing to assist low income, working families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the families package will be of considerable benefit to many low income working families. Indeed, as honourable members will be aware, there will be quite a large number of people who, while on low wages, have not been eligible for the family income supplement. Those families will become eligible for the family allowance supplement payment when it comes in in December, so many working families will find that they will be gaining as much as $22 per week per child, and those with older children could receive an extra $6 for those older children so that they could gain in respect of teenage children up to $28 a week.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some confusion, to which the honourable gent referred, in respect of the issue of what the Opposition likes to call the poverty trap. Rather than the family package creating poverty traps, it removes poverty traps associated with the loss of rent assistance and child payments on return to work. The whole design of the family package is there to ensure that there is a strong incentive for people on full or partial benefit particularly people with families, to move into the work force without loss of income. People with incomes of up to more than $400 a week will find that they are able to receive some assistance in relation to the family package.

It is also important to point out that the question of effective marginal tax rates is a somewhat different question from the question of the poverty trap. There is nothing in this package which leads people into poverty. There are concerns about effective marginal tax rates. The withdrawal rate for the family allowance supplement does not apply to each extra dollar of earnings in the same way as marginal tax rates. Income increases of less than 25 per cent will not affect the family allowance supplement entitlement for six months, so the family on $340 with two children will get $45 a week family allowance supplement. If they earn $20 a week overtime, they will pay an extra $5.80 in tax but keep the full family allowance supplement until re-assessed at the end of six months. Because increases in income up to 25 per cent will not affect entitlement for up to six months, the effective marginal tax rates will not generally have an adverse affect on disposable income changes which, for example, are influenced by short term periods of overtime.

Of course, with respect to effective marginal tax rates, it would be possible to partially mitigate that suggested problem by lowering the threshold, but to do that would be to withdraw a payment from people who are likely to benefit very little from decreases in tax rates. If one wants to assist-and the Government wants to provide assistance to low income working families-the way to do it is through the outlay side of the Budget. That is what the Government has done. It has provided significant improvements and, what is more, a substantial incentive for people on full or partial benefits to increase their participation within the work force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to the answer that he gave a moment ago to the effect that he was not aware of any amendments having been drafted. I remind him that, in a radio interview on 17 September, Senator Ryan said:

QUESTION.PARA: Those amendments, foreshadowed amendments, have been drafted after extensive consultation with civil liberties groups . . .

Can the Minister inform us exactly who is right-himself or Senator Ryan? In view of the fact that Parliament will be getting up for eight days tonight, can he give an undertaking to table parliamentary counsel's memorandum, referred to in my previous question, before the House rises tonight?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that there have been discussions between Senator Ryan and various groups about amendments. The answer that I gave a moment ago was to the best of my understanding. I was not aware that those amendments had been prepared. I indicated to the honourable member that I would seek an answer from Senator Ryan about the state of those proposals.
—What about the Parliamentary Counsel's memorandum?
—On that, I will seek to do so today.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Science and Small Business, relates to the proposed space station on Cape York in north Queensland. Can the Minister advise on the viability of such a space station, and as to whether Commonwealth subsidy would be required for the development of such stations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of reports in the newspaper from time to time about the feasibility of establishing a space port at Cape York in Queensland. The Premier of Queensland was very vocal on this matter last year and still is, marginally. Of course the Government and everybody else is aware of the proposal and the Government has taken an active interest in it. When the Premier announced the commissioning of a study in September 1986, the proposal was for a major international commercial space port. The proposed facility would be privately financed, constructed, marketed and operated, and available to an international market.

ANSWER.PARA: Phase one of the study was released in February. Its findings were that Cape York Peninsula offered a number of advantages over most operational sites elsewhere in the world: it is much closer to the Equator, only about 11 degrees south, whereas Cape Canaveral is 28 degrees north of the Equator. The closer one gets to the equator, the smaller the amount of fuel that one needs to get the package up, so the bigger the payload can be.

Following receipt by the Queensland Government of the summary report of phase two of the study, the Queensland Premier released a document soliciting proposals from commercial organisations interested in the construction and operation of that space port. Registrations of interest are to close on 30 November 1987. It is understood that a number of overseas companies have expressed interest in the space port. The Commonwealth is following progress, although it has not been privy to the result of the phase two study report on the commercial viability of the proposals. Apart from any interest in encouraging commercial proposals to proceed, the Commonwealth has a direct interest in any proposal. Before it could proceed, a range of Commonwealth issues involving Commonwealth powers would have to be discussed. They relate to legal, industrial, trade, defence and foreign affairs matters and to the need for subsidy or Commonwealth equity. These issues have been raised not by us but by others.

The Australian Space Board, a non-statutory advisory board set up to advise on space matters, is taking a close interest in the possibilities that such a development could have for space-related developments in Australian industry. A number of Australian companies will be taking a similar interest and the matter will be monitored by the Government as time goes by, particularly when the date for the close of the registration of interest draws closer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek indulgence to add to an answer given to the honourable member for Gippsland.
—Please proceed.

—I have nothing to add to what I said about development and planning work, and moneys for that, in relation to the Australia Card. However, I should have made the point that approximately $500,000 has been allocated for information programs.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, I present a proposal to relocate the Commencement Column Monument on the land axis between the old and the new Parliament House. The area is within the parliamentary zone. The views of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House are also being sought. When those views are available I shall be in a position to take further action under the Parliament Act to seek approval of the work by the House.
—Pursuant to section 215 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, I present the annual report of the Veterans Review Board for 1986-87.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—During Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) quoted from a radio interview that I gave this morning. His claim was that my opinion is at odds with the Opposition's stance on the power of the Senate to disallow a regulation under an Australia Card Act if it passes the Senate or a joint sitting. The Prime Minister's claim relies basically on two misrepresentations. The first misrepresentation relates to my views about the Senate's power. Essentially, a claim was put to me by the radio interviewer-a claim of the Government-that to disallow a regulation would be constitutional vandalism, to which I replied quite clearly that that was not a view that I shared. I may add that it is my view that the only constitutional vandalism--
—Order! The honourable member will not debate the issue. He will simply show me where he has been misrepresented.
—I will do so, Madam Speaker. The only constitutional vandalism is Labor's claim that the Senate should give up a power it has had for over 80 years.
—The honourable member is continuing to debate. He will give the second point briefly.

—The second point of misrepresentation is that the Prime Minister claimed that I support the existence of a constitutional convention. I do not support the existence of a constitutional convention. I invite the Prime Minister and his staffers to read Hansard.
—Order! That is the end of the personal explanation.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; BEALE; BURR; CAMERON; DOBIE; HALVERSON; HAWKER; HUNT; JULL; MILES; ROCHER; RUDDOCK; SHIPTON; SULLIVAN; WOOLDRIDGE
PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred,Mr Beale,Mr Burr,Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Dobie,Mr Halverson,Mr Hawker,Mr Hunt,Mr Jull,Mr Miles,Mr Rocher,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton,Mrs Sullivan and Dr Wooldridge.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; KENT; LINDSAY; LLOYD; MILTON; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Kent,Mr Lindsay,Mr Lloyd,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Downer,Mr Jull,Mr Kent and Mrs Sullivan.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Cobb,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Shack and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Lyne Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fairfax electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Dobie and Mr Fitzgibbon.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
That we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife,Mr McArthur and Mr White.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reasons for the discounting.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Halverson and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2,000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, women and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard to party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

We the undersigned small business people and supporters wish to draw attention to and protest against recent tax changes and the horrific administrative burdens which will be placed upon small businesses by these changes.
We request that Fringe Benefits Tax, Capital Gains Tax, Dividend Imputation, Negative gearing, Foreign tax credits and Substantiation legislation be immediately repealed.
We also request that the proposed legislation yet to be tabled in Parliament in respect of self assessment be discontinued.
To make up the shortfall in revenue as a result of these requests, the promised personal tax cuts should be deferred until such time as they can be funded by pruning government expenditure.
Unless the above action is taken immediately the private sector of the economy will contract and Australia will be further down the road to becoming a banana republic.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

Any proposal to establish memorials to peace, the so-called Aboriginal War and anti-war activists and other left wing causes at the Australian War Memorial at Canberra would desecrate the Memorial as a fitting and solemn monument to those who served in Australia's Armed Forces and to those who died in defence of their country.
Your petitioners humbly pray that that House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Act to prevent anything which would desecrate the nation's memorial to Australia's former serviceman and women and war dead.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small business and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBO's) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephones, and complaints in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
Mr Donald Cameron-Madam Speaker, may I draw the attention of the House to the fact that that is the second largest petition that has been presented in this nation's history, with 100,000 signatures.
Madam SPEAKER-The honourable member had my indulgence after all.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal:
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treatment of Sun Damaged Skin and Warts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the petitioners are concerned that the Minister for Health proposes to delete from the Medical Benefits Schedule those item numbers covering the treatment of sun-damaged skin and warts by specialists. They fear that those patients suffering chronically from these problems cannot always be treated successfully by a general practitioner. They protest that they will be financially disadvantaged. They also realise that their problems require early detection and expert treatment, if the petitioners are not to be exposed to increased risk of skin and other cancers.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and permit the abovementioned items in the medical schedule to be reinstated.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornographic video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory.

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and reverse its amendments to ACT legislation and Customs regulations which have resulted in Australia wide distribution of material restricted under State censorship laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose the reductions in staffing of the Department of Social Security over recent years, and deplore the plans to reduce staff further. Social Security payments are the only source of income for many Australians. It is important that these people and their dependants receive their correct entitlement in a timely and efficient manner. This has been made difficult by the effect of widespread changes in the last Federal Budget and the May Economic Statement, combined with a continued reduction in staff. We believe that people who are dependent upon the Department of Social Security for their most basic needs of food and rent should not be expected to put up with inefficiencies in the Department caused by insufficient staffing and the resultant inadequate training.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to instruct the Department of Finance to accept the findings of the recent Joint Staffing Review (JSR II) and increase Social Security staffing levels accordingly.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kurnell Peninsula
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that your honourable house direct that the existing 4 (C4) zoning on the Kurnell Peninsula, in New South Wales, be removed and that this be replaced by a zoning more appropriate to the unique ecology of the area and to the historical significance of the Kurnell Peninsula, being the birthplace of the nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian Republic
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of these Electors showeth that as:

In Australia, tobacco kills about four times as many people as the total killed by drink, drugs, murder, suicide, road accidents, rail accidents, air accidents, poisoning, drowning, fires, snakes, lightning and every other known cause of accidental death all put together.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will prove your worth with effectual action against the promotion of tobacco.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

We consider that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combatting the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.
We therefore ask the House to take action to prevent the implementation of this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and END the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That whereas the Federal Government has determined to proceed with the introduction of a national identification system to be known as the Australia Card, the following citizens of Australia express their concerns at the potential violation of civil rights and democratic freedom posed by such a national identification system and urge that the Government not proceed with its planned introduction of the Australia Card.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Two Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That, as a consequence of the Hawke Government's decision to introduce a two dollar coin in 1988.

Whereas the introduction of a one dollar coin was only a twofold increase in the maximum value of coinage, the elimination of the two dollar note represents a fivefold increase before a note can be used.

It will have taken eighteen years from decimalisation to go from the fifty cent piece as the highest value coin to a one dollar coin, but only a further four years to replace the two dollar note with a coin.
The lowest value paper note will be five dollars, forcing a dramatic increase in the weight of coinage carried and dislocation of the retail industry.
Many people, particularly the elderly, will mistake the value of the coin for that of another lower value coin just as many now confuse the one dollar coin with the ten cent piece.

That the addition of two new coins in four years creates the biggest number of coins in circulation at any time in Australia's history and will lead to the removal of the one cent and two cent coins; this will accelerate the cost of living, particularly the cost of food where numerous items are involved and future price rises would need to be five cent increases on every item on every occasion.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the proposed two dollar coin not be proceeded with by the Hawke Government, and no future Government proceed with this proposal for several years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity. In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner.
The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.

PETITION.TITLE: Mail Delivery Service, Dowerin, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strenuously object to the proposal that the mail delivery service in the town of Dowerin in Western Australia is to cease.

The mail delivery service provides a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel to a Post Office to collect mail. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the cessation of the mail delivery service in Dowerin.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Industrial Relations Bill will increase industrial disputation, bankrupt companies, and give the union movement total and absolute power over the Australian community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's Industrial Relations Bill to save Australia from the actions of militant unions and give our economy a chance of recovering.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Murray electorate respectfully showeth that:
The August 1st changes to Medicare Benefit rebates are unfair to patients, such as those with chronic disabilities requiring consultant physician or after hours consultations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Amend the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to restore the original rebates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
1. the effect of present Government policy in not returning a fairer share of road taxes and fuel excise to the community for road construction and maintenance is totally iniquitous; and
2. unless immediate action is taken to redress this funding situation, our road network will disintegrate beyond reasonable repair.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain concerned electors from the Geelong district, Victoria, Australia.

We would like to commend the Government for its involvement in the formulation of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty (Rarotonga Treaty) but would urge that further action should be taken to ensure a Truly Nuclear Free Zone in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Parliament support the following measures.
In the nuclear free zone there should be:
(1) No nuclear weapon transit nor temporary presence at ports and airfields of nuclear armed ships or aeroplanes.
(2) No support facilities and programmes for nuclear weapons systems.
(3) No nuclear waste reprocessing, transport, storage or disposal on land or sea.
(4) No mining, export and/or processing of uranium.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need to lift the restrictions and burdens on Australia's mineral and energy exports.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the election, which is really not that long ago, on 11 July and, indeed, right through since March 1983 the Hawke Government has been responsible for trying to perpetrate a number of myths on the Australian electorate. One of those myths is that our traditional exports, particularly those in the minerals and energy area and in agriculture, do not matter. The second myth-we heard a little more of that from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) who is at the table during Question Time today-is that where there are difficulties facing exports that those are all beyond the power of this Federal Government. We on this side of the House regard the important role of energy, the way by which minerals contribute towards the economic and social development of large tracts of Australia and the way by which those traditional exports can continue to play an important part in the provision of export earnings for Australia as matters which cannot be ignored. That in no way lessens the importance that has to be given to the changing dimension of Australia's industry, nor does it, in any way, deny that we would want to expand opportunities in high technology, manufacturing and tourism and indeed in every possible way to overcome what has become a chronic adverse balance of payments problem.

SPEECH.PARA: In this place since the presentation of the Budget the two predominant areas of concern to the Australian community which have emerged are, firstly, the extent to which our overseas debt is continuing to balloon out and, secondly, our current account is in a very serious and continuing adverse position.
