The reason that this matter of public importance was brought up by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and me yesterday was that it seems to us that the Government has not only been deluding itself but it has also been attempting to delude the Australian electorate as to the role and importance of three particular areas of minerals. Of course it is true that there has been some general improvement in gold prices. The general interest in gold has meant that there has been an impression that all is well in the mining industry. While that has been true it is also true that in other sectors of the mining industry there are and have been very significant problems. Base metal prices have not been good; there have been problems in copper prices; and there has certainly been a very real difficulty with oil. We know that some of the problems that are now occurring in the Middle East result from the impact of the decline in oil prices on the economies of countries there.

Australia is one of the world's biggest mineral and energy producers and exporters. We had mineral exports worth $13,000m last year. We are expected to increase this by 12 per cent this year to $14.5 billion. It makes an enormous contribution to our economy as I have said not only in the direct contribution from exports but indirectly it also employs over 78,000 people directly, many in remote and isolated areas. In the National Party we have two members whose electorates have absolutely and fundamentally depended upon the growth of those industries; that is the electorates of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). The industry employs over 78,000 people directly, but it contributed about $3,500m to the State and Commonwealth revenues in 1985-86. It is that point that I would suggest the Minister failed to recognise when talking about the coal industry a little while ago and suggesting that there was not anything that the Commonwealth could do to try to help the coal producers in their present plight. Investment in the industry is about $20 billion. The direct impact is only part of the story. Mineral-related activities comprise about one-third of the value added by manufacturing in Australia. The mining and oil industries employ about 200,000 people and then there is all the flow-on and the infrastructure, all of which is critically important. There is no doubt that if honourable members have a look at its contribution to regional development they will see that from 1967 to 1985 there were 24 new towns with a total population of over 40,000 people, 12 new ports and more than 20 airfields and almost 12,000 kilometres of heavy railway line.

Mr Deputy Speaker, need I say it: 90 per cent of that development began and was completed during the days of coalition governments and most of it-forward planning though it might have been-was certainly initiated during our day and much of it has fallen off since this Government has assumed the realms of responsibility. Over the last few years there have been a series of major turmoils such as falling world oil prices. This has flowed on now to coal and we are all aware of the difficulties facing the industry there. There is a decline in world demand-I will talk about that in a moment-and domestically, we have had significant industrial trouble. We have got problems with work practices, costs, charges, wages, taxes and transport and energy charges and there is a very real and fundamental problem in trying to stimulate the whole of the energy and mineral industry at a time when the Government is long on rhetoric and very short on action.

The rate of growth in sales is low. Net profits are down again and, alarmingly, exploration spending has declined for the fourth successive year. Unfortunately, Labor's response has been too little too late. In some cases-in the oil tax regime, for example-it is positively damaging. The Government does not seem to understand that as far as the future deficit position is concerned it might be all very well to hope that the North West Shelf will bring in some great bonanza, but the reality is that unless there is significant and continued exploration this country will become so critically oil-deficient that we will have to depend on increasing imports and that is going to turn around totally the whole of the economic position of this country. I am afraid the Government's response flows from a fundamental misunderstanding of the importance of the industry and of the whole nature of our exports.

Honourable members will remember that under Messrs Whitlam and Connor, Labor's approach was based on massive intervention and regulation. We had the whole discredited theory of resources diplomacy. But under this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and successive Ministers the approach has been to hope the industry will go away. The Government takes the maximum slice of tax while it happens and then it is going to act only in extreme circumstances as, indeed, we found with the Prime Minister's intervention in the coal industry this year. In fact, his intervention did absolutely nothing either to encourage confidence for those who were employed in the area or to expand our prospects for the continued survival of the industry. In search of a manufacturing-led recovery in the current account deficit, the Government has let the mining industry swing in the wind. Everyone agrees that we need to lift manufactured exports. Depending on them alone is wishful thinking.

The Government's export effort virtually ignores the rural and mining sectors. Yet it is in those sectors with the right cost and wage environment which can do most to reduce our disastrous current deficit and ease the burden of overseas debt. The Australian Financial Review said in its editorial on 3 September:

Given that we can do very little to influence world prices and volumes demanded, we have no choice but to lower production costs and remove some of the regulatory and taxation burdens imposed by Governments.
Indeed, the same editorial made this important point:

It has to be driven home to all Australians that unnecessarily high taxes and charges on our export industries may provide them with subsidised social facilities and restrain rises in charges in Government-provided services but these subsidies are harming our long-run competitiveness.

Yesterday, at a function which the Minister and a number of others and I attended, a publication was released by Dr Andy Stoeckel, the former head of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and Sandy Cuthbertson, a former First Assistant Commissioner of the Industries Assistance Commission. I commend to everybody an analysis that was presented and displayed fairly effectively in graphic form on page 2 of that publication. It sets down the policy to improve trade. It sets down in balance the fact that if 60 per cent of effort is put into overcoming the domestic troubles of industry-it is specifically referring to agricultural industry-most of our problems will be behind us.

If the Minister analyses those areas he will find, first of all, 25 per cent with respect to industry policy. I suggest that exactly the same statistics apply to minerals and energy as they do to agriculture where there are problems about research allocations and assistance to particular industries and disadvantages that other sectors suffer. There is a 10 per cent tax. The Minister ignores the role that taxes have on providing a disincentive to our mining companies. Companies such as Mount Isa Mines complained last year that its fringe benefits burden alone was in excess of $3 1/2 billion. Then there is 15 per cent of the macroeconomic problem where we need a tighter fiscal stance, less reliance on monetary policy and genuine competitive interest rates. A total of 50 per cent is in labour and productivity. In the mining and minerals industry work practices have been appalling and there is the necessity to return to productivity. Where the second tier wage increase has failed abysmally there is a need to look at management and work practices. The unions have to accept that they must be prepared to change their work practices or there will be a continuation of what is occurring in the coal industry at the moment. The other day we all saw the stand taken by the Amalgamated Metal Foundry and Shipwrights Union with respect to Peko-Wallsend Ltd. The extent to which it persists in refusing the changes in work practices is to ensure that those who currently work in the industry are unlikely to be able to preserve their jobs. We must have reduced unit labour costs, there must be greater capital utilisation and lower unit capital costs and there must be an opportunity for private sector investment. A great deal can and should be done in that area by the Government.

I wish to speak briefly in this matter of public importance debate today on two other industries which concern me greatly. Of course, the crisis in the coal industry follows the Government's refusal to face the facts until it was too late. It seems to me that the Government is even worse when it comes to looking at the situation in the uranium industry. Whilst I am delighted that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is at the table, has made a few comments which suggest that at long last he realises that there have to be changes in the uranium industry, the reality is that the Government's political attitudes and prejudices to a few people down south have resulted in this absolutely idiotic three mine uranium export policy.

We all know that there are tremendous uranium resources in Australia. We know that a policy that says that there is good uranium in one place and bad uranium in another place-good uranium in Roxby Downs and bad uranium in Nabarlek-is absolute rubbish. The Minister-and we are prepared to back him in his determination-must make sure that his colleagues in Labor Caucus and his other colleagues within the Labor Party, particularly at their next annual conference, recognise that their policy on uranium is bad for Australia, bad for employment and bad for Australia's balance of payments prospects. We must recognise the role that uranium can play in the lesser developed areas of Australia. There is no doubt that a great deal can be done if the factional leaders in the Labor Party are prepared to accept some of the rhetoric that the Minister has been advancing.

Despite the economic imperative to redress the flagging balance of payments, Australia is losing over half a billion dollars a year simply because of Labor's prejudicial policy against uranium exports. There is no doubt that, if we can only have a rational position on yellowcake exports and overcome the political intransigence and disproportionate political influence of the pro-Aboriginal, anti-nuclear conservation lobbies within the Labor Party, Australia's export potential will be significantly enhanced. We have set down adequate safeguards for uranium. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), as Minister for Foreign Affairs, was largely responsible for introducing those safeguards internationally. We set down safeguards that ensure that Australia's uranium is not exported willy-nilly; it is exported subject to very tight constraints.

The Minister at the table and everybody else in Labor Caucus do not realise that the sooner they get away from their present absolutely abysmal prejudicial attitude towards uranium exports the better. Indeed, I am delighted to see that even the new Labor member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) apparently disagrees with Caucus about the prospects of uranium exports from the Alligator Rivers area. I cannot say that there is too much else that I would agree with him on, but I am delighted to know that at least in that area there is some move. It is absolutely essential that we do something to improve the export potential for Australia's uranium resources, and to do it in a way that maintains the safeguards laid down by coalition governments.

The other commodity I wish to refer to is oil. Oil is vital to Australia. Domestic production is dropping as the Bass Strait fields age and replacements are not being found. By the early 1990s domestic oil production will have fallen by about 50 per cent and our annual oil import bill will have risen to about $3,000m. The only reaction of the Government to this serious situation is to argue that production from the North West Shelf gas field should by then be offsetting the oil import bill. There is no recognition of the truth; the Government's oil tax policies are fundamentally flawed and motivated not by logic but by ideology and greed. The Government has a role to play in the coal, uranium and oil industries. It should assist by ensuring that exports are freely allowed subject to the sorts of safeguards I spoke of before. Secondly, it must help to lift the burden of our labour policy which imposes an unnecessary discipline on private sector investment. Thirdly, it must reduce the present unduly harsh tax burden which serves as a real disincentive. It gives no incentive to an industry which could contribute so much at a time when Australia is in such an economic crisis in the international scene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, yesterday when the Opposition proposed this discussion of a matter of public importance I thought it was rather incredible. I think it is astounding that it has proposed it again today. What we have heard from the tired old war horse, the right honourable member for New England, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), would not have passed for a schoolboy essay. There was total confusion as to whether he was prepared to look at the reality of commodity markets, whether he wanted to get into socialist planning, or whether he just wanted to have a bit of a dig at a few areas where there may be inconsistencies in the way governments over the years have addressed some of these very complex questions. I am absolutely amazed by some of the statements he has made. When he was last in government, Australia's coal exports as a share of total world markets were 14.4 per cent; today they are 27.4 per cent. Yet, he wants to focus on coal.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also truly staggered by his remarks on uranium. Olympic Dam has not even started producing uranium yet. The Ranger mine will be able effectively to double its capacity by 1993-95. I must tell him that people are not actually falling over themselves trying to buy our uranium. There is a world glut of uranium. The world markets will not recover until at least the mid-1990s. Oil exploration is now on the way up. I would have thought that all those market-driven people on the Opposition benches would have conceded that oil exploration has some correlation to the price of oil. Over recent years many Australian-based oil explorers have been getting into consortiums, involving themselves off-shore in countries adjacent to Australia and effectively adopting a very sensible strategy for Australia's long term interests. This Government is not interfering in many of the vital commercial decisions that these companies should make. That is, by and large, the direction we are taking.

The right honourable member for New England was totally confused. He simply did not know where he was. He seems to have just remembered that he is the Opposition spokesman for resources and trade. Unfortunately for him, he had not researched the subject very well, otherwise he would have found that this Government's record in minerals and energy trade is one that we are very happy to debate and that the Opposition's record when it was in government, administered by the right honourable member's predecessor as the Leader of the National Party, was not one that bears close examination-Doug of export controls. Our exercise of the export control power, which is one of the main instruments for controlling trade, has been based on the premise that where export control is plainly in the national interest we will exercise it. Where no national interest benefit can be demonstrated we have had no hesitation in removing and reducing export controls. We do not regard these debates about privatisation, public ownership and regulation or deregulation from an ideological perspective: we look at the realities of the situations and the commodities and we get on with the business of trying to create the best environment possible for those industries.

Before I refer to some of the specifics of our policies I will first make a few comparisons which demonstrate how the minerals and energy industries have fared under our reasonable approach compared with the restrictive and burdensome regime of the Fraser-Anthony years. Since 1982-83, the real value of resource exports has increased by 53 per cent. Despite the terms of trade fall in 1985-86 and 1986-87, the value of output of the mining industry has increased by more than 40 per cent in real terms. The value of alumina exports has increased by 43 per cent; zinc, by 57 per cent; copper, by 43 per cent; iron ore, by 18 per cent; and gold, by about six-fold. Yet the honourable member still comes in here and sets up the straw man of the myth that agriculture and minerals do not count. My portfolio now administers policies associated with 84 per cent of Australia's exports.

No one in the Government is saying that we should in any way relent in our efforts to promote agricultural and resource and energy trade. We are saying that when the world markets demonstrate to us so convincingly every day that world commodity markets can be corrupted so easily by the rich and powerful nations it is madness to put all our pennies in that basket. We have to try to diversify our economy, but for those agricultural, mineral and energy commodities we have to get into value adding. We have to enhance their capacity to contribute more to national income and we have to take off regulations. That is what we have been doing where it has been in the interests of the industry. Crude oil exports have increased from zero to $782m in 1986-87. Without the sorts of improvements I have just spoken about and without the Government's policies our balance of payments would be in a worse situation than it is in now. The Government is fully aware of that.

Let us turn to specific policies within this sector, in particular the crude oil market. The market was heavily regulated by the Fraser Government. Exports were restricted, prices were set, crude oil liftings were specified by the Government and a highly complex system of levies on the industry was developed. On 1 January 1988 the crude oil market will be deregulated and the Government no longer will be making the detailed decisions for this industry which the Opposition was quite prepared to make when it was in government. It made a virtue of it. Exports and imports will be allowed and producers and refiners will negotiate prices and sales which optimise their own operations. The consumer and the country will be the winners. We have also allowed free market sales of crude oil-something that was never allowed by the Fraser Government. Indeed, as I mentioned, crude oil exports accounted for $782m worth of exports in 1986-87, and producers now will be able to take advantage of the riches in the world market-to the benefit of Australia's trade position. The Fraser Administration, of which the right honourable member was a member, would not allow that.

We are also rationalising the crude oil excise system. The system of excise and royalty, or even royalty, or even royalty alone, together with export restrictions-a system put in place by the Opposition-would never have allowed new fields such as Jabiru and Challis to get off the ground. The resource rent tax has been welcomed by the more sensible parts of the oil industry as the most rational way for the Government to take some return for the community from the community's own resource. Under the resource rent tax a project is taxed only when super-profits exist. High cost marginal projects escape the tax altogether.

We have made similar rationalisations in the administration of this industry through the introduction of cash bidding for some exploration blocks. This greatly reduced the administrative involvement in awarding acreage. We have streamlined and eased the burden of the crude oil excise system. On-shore oil producers, for example, now pay no crude oil excise. That seems to be some encouragement. The downstream part of the oil industry is now almost too competitive, if we want to take it a bit further. The competition which exists between the petrol marketers, I guess to the great benefit of consumers, has resulted in a very lean and competitive refining-marketing sector with relatively low profitability.

In the minerals area, our approach will bear any examination the Opposition cares to attempt. The industry is not now administered according to the whims of powerful interest groups. The mechanisms of environmental impact statements, the Australian Heritage Commission and export controls have been administered so as to allow the benefit and costs of conflicting land use to be carefully weighed. We will be looking at this process in even more depth in the near future to ensure that it is working as efficiently as possible. It is a legitimate and necessary area of government involvement which the Opposition barely even acknowledged, let alone tackled.

Our policy on uranium has allowed that industry to make a significant contribution to the economic well-being of this country, while keeping well within the safeguard requirements necessary when dealing with radioactive material. The open slather policy advocated by the Opposition, if that is what it is advocating today, would not have increased that contribution by one dollar. As I have already said, the existing three mines have the capacity to double their output to take advantage of any improvement in the world market. The Government itself holds 2,268 tonnes which is quite prepared to sell, yet the Leader of the National Party said that we are holding this up because we are stopping the export of yellowcake. That is what we are actually exporting. I thought even he would have found that out.

It is interesting to point out some of the realities of the market-place. We have a three-mine policy-we have three mines-and we have a minimum price. Our prices are spot prices, and with those sorts of controls we cannot hold the world market; but the world market itself really does mean that investment at this time is rather a nonsense. We will not get a greater slice of the world market by taking an open slather approach to uranium mines. We now know that the various nuclear projects that the Opposition has been drawn to from time to time-such as the Jervis Bay nuclear power station and a uranium enrichment plant-would have, in terms of the economic costs and benefits, left us with many very expensive white elephants.

I have already referred to some of the points raised with respect to coal exports. Our policies on coal exports have allowed that industry's export tonnage almost to double since 1982-83 and the value of those exports to increase by 77 per cent. We have moved from being an also-ran in the world export stakes to being the world's leading coal exporter. That is not an indicator of restrictions and burdens. My predecessor-he was criticised for it by the coal unions-even removed additional controls such that we do not send coal exporters abroad with price guidelines but we exercise a monitoring role after contract negotiations have been started to see that Australian coal companies do not bid against each other and bid the price down. That policy is working very well. I have taken key crucial decisions in respect of both steaming coal and metallurgical coal exports since I have been Minister, and the way those controls have been exercised has been beneficial to the industry. So, really, we are implementing a policy of encouragement and minimum involvement in commercial negotiations, and that has been successful in allowing this industry to be a major positive contributor to our balance of payments.

To sum up, this matter of public importance is more an indicator of the Opposition spokesman's inexperience in this area of policy. His speech was so bad that I think he must have written it himself. He has really chosen an area in which the Government has a strong record of achievement, a record which I have no qualms in comparing with the Opposition's directions less ad hockery

I wish to pick up just a few more points. My colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), I guess, will address the coal industry a lot more; but one of the matters the Leader of the National Party picked up was work practices. If we look at the North West Shelf to see what happened in the iron ore province there and look at the enormous amount of concessions given by trade unions in very willing negotiations with the companies, we see that many work practice problems have been resolved very satisfactorily. If we look at what has been achieved at the enterprise level between management and labour in the coal mines in the western district of New South Wales, we find that concessions have been made by the trade union movement-$215 a week in one case, and a 50 per cent cut in bonuses in another case. Even then those mines are still at risk, partly because of high State charges but not because of anything to do with productivity. The reality for some of the very efficient mines in that area is that they would have to cut wages by another 60 per cent to get costs down by another $5 a tonne. The problem is the world market price as well as State charges. The problem does not lie in work practice negotiations at all. The Leader of the National Party talked about regulations. I have already addressed that pretty effectively. We are taking regulations off where they are acting as an impediment to any of these industries.

I guess it took the greatest gall, of course, for the Leader of the National Party to talk about taxes. If we look at oil and petrol excise, we see that the Fraser-Anthony years were the years of greatest tax on this industry. They got on it and they could not get off it; it was like a narcotic. Many other things need to be analysed if we are to look at this whole complex industry instead of bringing into this place fatuous matters of public importance. I thought the right honourable member might even have referred at one stage to the exchange rate. One of the realities is that the exchange rate is now affecting the profitability of the people in these industries which are so exposed on world markets. Part of the problem I have in explaining to some people the reasons these industries are in trouble is our enormous exposure on world markets because we have been very successful in getting a greater share of those markets.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition's matter of public importance today really should be treated with contempt. The Opposition ought to put a bit more homework into it, do a bit more research and try to see whether it can put up something that makes a bit of sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate on a matter of public importance--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr West) agreed to:
That the business of the day be called on.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF SURVEY MOTOR LAUNCHES FOR THE ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Construction of survey motor launches for the Royal Australian Navy.

This proposal is to acquire four survey motor launches to enhance the Royal Australian Navy's capabilities to conduct surveys of Australia's inshore waters. Australia's present survey force includes HMAS Cook, Flinders and Moresby which provide the major effort in offshore operations. The Navy uses the two heavy landing crafts, Brunei and Betano, for inshore surveys. However, these two craft are designed for amphibious work and landing supplies. They are not suited to survey work.

The acquisition of the survey motor launches has been deferred for some years due to financial constraints. However, their acquisition is now urgent to enable the surveying of coastal waters, particularly around northern Australia. The survey of northern coastal waters has important strategic and commercial implications. For instance, several commercial vessels have run aground in recent years. Better charts are urgently needed for the inshore waters to minimise the risks of commercial loss, environmental disasters and possible loss of life. Naval operations in these waters are also dependent on sufficient charting resources. There is also an international obligation to survey Australia's coastal waters.

Tenders for the construction of the launches closed in October 1986 and evaluation of the responses has now been completed. It is intended that a contract will be awarded next month with the first survey launch being completed in November 1988. The fourth and final launch is to be delivered in October 1989. The estimated total project cost is $28m at September 1986 prices.

As the construction of the launches is now urgent, it is not appropriate for the proposal to be referred to the Joint Committee on Public Works for consideration and report. It has not been possible to bring this proposal to the House at an earlier date due to the sensitive nature of the tenders and the requirements for a detailed evaluation process. Any deferral of the construction program which I have just detailed could result in additional costs to rectify degradation of essential equipment to be installed in the craft. Additional costs may be incurred if the contract is not awarded by October 1987. If the House agrees to support this motion, the contract can now be awarded and detailed planning and construction can commence. I commend to the House this motion that it is expedient to carry out this important work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, this is yet another example of this Government's gross administrative incompetence. We have heard many examples today of the Government's inability to administer its departments and properly to get on with the job of government. This is yet another example.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government requests that the purchase of these vessels not be considered by the Joint Committee on Public Works. That Committee normally has the job of reviewing government purchases. Its role as set out in 17 (3) (a) of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, is to have regard to:
the stated purpose of the work and its suitability for that purpose . . .

In other words, the Committee's role is to consider whether the Government's request for expenditure of money is appropriate. It must consider whether the work will achieve its goal or whether it will be a white elephant. The Government is saying to us, `We do not want the Public Works Committee to consider this proposal. We want the Parliament to accept that it is urgent.' The Public Works Committee Act allows works to be approved without being referred to the Public Works Committee, provided:
The House of Representatives has resolved that, by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that it be carried out without having been referred to the Committee . . .

Let us look at the explanation put up by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for the urgency. First, he said, `We have not gone ahead with this project to acquire survey motor launches for some years because of financial constraints.' The project has been around for a number of years, but the Government has not acted upon it because it says that it has not had the money. Suddenly, today, the Minister says to the House, `This acquisition is now most urgent to enable the surveying of coastal waters, particularly around northern Australia'. Why is the need suddenly most urgent? The project has been before the Government for years. The Government did not have the money before, but suddenly it has found the money, so it rushes into the House and says that the project is most urgent because `we have to survey the coastal waters, particularly around northern Australia'.

All this week and last we heard about the Amann Aviation fiasco. The Government clearly has not been able to get its act together to establish proper contracts for the air surveillance of northern Australia. So it is no wonder that the Government rushes in here today and says, `We need these boats now to survey the coastal waters, particularly around northern Australia'. Why has there been this sudden rush? Why, after a couple of years, is the Government rushing into the Parliament and saying that it is now urgent? Is the explanation in the Minister's speech? He said:
Tenders for the construction of the launches closed in October 1986 and evaluation of the responses has now been completed.

Why did the Minister not refer the work to the Public Works Committee when the Government started considering funding of the project and called for tenders last year? Why were the works not referred then? There is deathly silence from the Government. The Government has to come up with a better explanation than is in the three-page speech. The Government says that the project has been around for years but that it has not had the money. Then the Government decided that it would allocate the money, so a year ago it put the project out to tender. But the Government still did not bring the matter before the Public Works Committee. Now the Government suddenly says that the project is most urgent, giving no explanation. The Minister said in his statement:
It has not been possible to bring this proposal to the House at an earlier date due to the sensitive nature of the tenders and the requirements for a detailed evaluation process.

Is that not the case with most tenders that the Government lets or puts out? Are not all tenders sensitive? Certainly there are commercial sensitivities. Do not all tenders require a detailed evaluation? That is no excuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coastal surveillance contract did not get one. They did not get a detailed evaluation.
—My colleague is quite right. Suddenly the Government is concerned about detailed evaluations of tenders. The Minister then said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is intended that a contract will be awarded next month with the first survey launch being completed in November 1988.

So on the death knock the Government wants to award the tender next month and, on the death knock, it rushes into this Parliament and says, `Heavens above, we cannot refer it to the Public Works Committee because we want to award the contract next month'. No explanation is given as to why suddenly it is urgent for the Government to award this tender. I put it to the Minister, who is seated at the table, that the program has been around for a couple of years. The Government sought tenders last year and now it wants to award them next month. There is no excuse other than gross administrative incompetence for the Minister rushing into the House and saying that the matter is now urgent. It is no more urgent than it has been for the last three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is-much more.
—Why?
—You will know when the announcements are made. Stop knocking South Australia.
—This Parliament is supposed to debate that sort of thing.

—This is the point. There is something behind this motion. Again the Government is not telling the full story. The Minister is saying that there is some reason but he is not prepared to give us the reason. That is interesting because as I understand it the real reason to declare the acquisition as now being urgent is the Government's gross administrative incompetence. The tenders were called last October and they become void at the end of next month. So the Government is not telling the Parliament-but this is the case-that the Government has bungled again and it is asking us, `Please do not delay these contracts because they are urgent. If you ask us to explain we will have to say that we have bungled again'. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), has just said, `We cannot explain to you now the reason why we want to declare this urgent'. I know that he cannot. The Government has bungled again. How many bungles have we unearthed this week?
—You only have to read your speech on the front page of the Advertiser tomorrow.

—It would be a nice change to read some of my speeches on the front page of the Advertiser. The residents of South Australia would be better off if they read some of my speeches on the front page of the Advertiser. The Minister for Administrative Services says that there is another reason the Government is seeking to declare this project urgent. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any deferral of the construction program that I have just detailed could result in additional costs to rectify degradation of essential equipment to be installed in the craft.

I ask the Minister: what on earth does that mean? Does that mean that the Government has actually bought some of the equipment that will go on these survey vessels and if we do not immediately buy the vessels then the equipment in some way will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to degradation.
—The equipment will be subject to degradation. What does the Minister mean? Has the Government bought the gear and left it out in the open?
—Haven't you got a shed to put it in?
—Doesn't the Government have a shed to put it in? What on earth is going on? I want to know what the Minister means when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Any deferral of the construction program that I have just detailed could result in additional costs to rectify degradation of essential equipment to be installed in the craft.

What does the Minister mean? We tried to find out. We went and asked people in the Minister's office. They said, `We do not know. Go and see Beazley. He is the one responsible'. So we went and saw the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and he said, `Oh no, it is West's problem'. This is another classic example of the new administrative arrangements. No one is responsible in this Government. We know that it is a balls-up but Ministers are now trying to shift the responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Barker will withdraw that type of language.
—It is sometimes called a big, big mess-up.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw. Clearly, it is a very big mess-up. I just cannot believe that this Government can come into this House with this pathetic excuse for its gross administrative incompetence. It cannot effectively run its tendering processes; we have seen that quite clearly over the last two weeks. The Ministers do not know who on earth is in charge of these programs and now, on the death knock, because the tenders will be invalid at the end of next month, because the Government is running out of time, the Minister has rushed into this House to declare the project urgent without a scrap of support for the declaration of urgency. This Government has had this project lying around for two or three years. It opened the tenders a year ago and now, on the death knock, the Minister rushes into this House and says that the matter is urgent. Let me tell the Minister that this is a classic example of the bungling that is going on in the Government. There may well be some other reasons why the Government does not want the Public Works Committee to have a look at these projects because last week we discovered that an internal investigation is being undertaken in the Department of Defence into allegations of corruption and fraud in the tendering of contracts for defence equipment. The Canberra Times detailed the allegations in an article headed `Defence-deals fraud alleged'. What are the allegations? The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The allegations are believed to refer to relatively unknown companies with allegedly dubious backgrounds, said to account for about 20 per cent of direct purchases for supplies placed by the Department of Defence.

Another fraudulent procedure allegedly in use in the department is the amendment of provisional action priority review documents, so that deficiencies in stock and liabilities could be written off and new orders placed to overcome them.

Is that why the Government is trying to avoid any investigation of this project? Is this one of the projects that is under internal review because of allegations of fraud and corruption? What does the Government have to hide in relation to the awarding of tenders in this case? There is no substance to the reasons that the Minister has given for declaring this matter urgent. His excuse is paper thin. There is no substance to the argument for the declaration of urgency. We find that the project has been around for three years and that the Government is seeking a declaration of urgency for a defence contract at a time when there are serious allegations of fraud and corruption in the tendering process in the Department of Defence for defence equipment. I understand that this is a defence contract to be let by the Royal Australian Navy for survey motor launches. I believe that it is time for the Government to come clean on this issue. We have raised genuine concerns. Clearly, it is not a matter to be declared urgent and the Government ought to come clean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for McPherson.
—How long will you be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important matter because we are talking about $28m for this project.
—If you have a lot of business why did you bring on the stupid censure motion this morning?

—The Opposition has already outlined why we are not happy with this proposal. It is a proposal to bypass the parliamentary system. If the Government is short of time, as the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) has said, why did it move that stupid censure motion this morning, waste the Parliament's time, and-not that we minded-give us all of those free kicks? If it wants to move another one when Parliament resumes, that will be fine.
—Order! The honourable member might return to the matter that is before the House.

—I see that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) is present. No doubt the next thing he will say is that the Opposition is anti-Australian business because we are questioning a $28m contract which the Government is trying to slide through without any scrutiny.
—Where do the white-shoe brigade stand on the ID card in your electorate?

—Would not the Minister like to tip a bit of that on me. The fact is that this matter has been brought in as a matter of some urgency. There is no urgency about it. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition of the survey motor launches has been deferred for some years due to financial constraints.
All of a sudden it is urgent. He continued:
Tenders for the construction of the launches closed in October 1986. . .

That is a few days short of 12 months. All of a sudden, the Minister tries to convince us that it is urgent. Inquiries this morning to the Minister's office and to the office of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) were entirely unsatisfactory. One passed the buck to the other. After going to Minister Beazley's office, I was told, `Go and see Minister West, he is the bloke who is responsible for all this'. I went to Minister West's office and spoke to one of his staff, as he was not there. The staff member said, `No, it has nothing to do with us, the Minister is just moving. You should see the Minister for Defence'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's as bad as Biggles and Bungles.
—You should have been here during the Fraser Government. Boy, were they beauties.
—It is no wonder that the Government has problems with the identity card if this is the way in which it conducts its business.
—Order! There is far too much interjection and noise. We might deal with notice No. 9. We will not have any more interjections from either side.

—At last someone from one of the offices said, `The real reason that we want this put through is because we would have had it by now except that the election interfered with it'. Who called the election? Three months later the Government is blaming us and telling the House that this is a matter of urgency and must be put through. A suggestion has also been put to me that naval vessels should not be considered by the Public Works Committee (PWC). I do not know whether there is any validity in that suggestion.
—Yes.

—If there is, why does the Government not amend the legislation, if it is so convinced of it? The same thing happened when the submarine contract was being considered by the House. When the Minister for Defence read his speech regarding the submarine contract, he said, `It is too complicated, we don't want it to go to the PWC'. It was quite clear that he never had any intention of referring it to the Public Works Committee. It is also quite clear, from talking to members of his staff today, that there was no intention of referring this matter to the Public Works Committee, either. The Government will ram it through on the pretext that it is urgent. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not good enough. There should have been some Public Works Committee scrutiny of the submarine contract. The Minister for Defence has entered the chamber. He might be able to answer this point. It is an appropriate time for him to come in.
—No, it's West's problem, not his.

—Is it? I ask the Minister for Defence: whose problem is it? Is it his problem or is it the problem of the Minister for Administrative Services? Had the submarine contract been subjected to some proper scrutiny, we might have got the answers to some questions that are plaguing the submarine contract right now. The Minister said that all the submarines would be built in Australia. How much of the first submarine will now be built in Sweden? Perhaps he could answer that. He might also tell us which performance standards will be adhered to by the Government. Which performance standard is the Government insisting on from the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC), which will build the submarine? Are they the performance standards submitted by ASC or are they the performance standards which the Royal Australian Navy upgraded by taking the ASC standards and upgrading them? Perhaps he can answer that. Also, while the Minister is present, he might tell us who is responsible and who will pick up the tab for the final integration of the combat systems with the vessel? We would not be asking those questions if the PWC had had a chance to scrutinise the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that really annoys members on this side of the House is the arrogance of this Government. When one dares to go to Minister's offices and ask questions, they say, `What's this? Why are we being questioned about this? We want to put this through. It is none of your business'. If the Government had had any chance of it going through with some degree of co-operation, it blew it this morning when I visited the office of the Minister for Defence to ask some simple questions about what it was all about. It was like drawing blood out of a stone. Eventually someone rang up and very grudgingly gave a few details when we tried to establish why this was such an urgent matter. It was very unsatisfactory. The same thing happened in regard to the office of the Minister for Administrative Services.

No satisfactory explanation has been given as to why this matter has suddenly become urgent. The fact is that the Government and the Minister for Defence had no intention of ever referring this matter to the Public Works Committee. They are trying in an arrogant way to bypass the system and ram it through in the hope that we will agree to it. Mr Deputy Speaker, we certainly do not.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises the importance of the National Welcome Home Parade of Vietnam Veterans in Sydney on 3 October 1987;
(2) notes that the Australian Armed Forces served with great distinction in Vietnam between 1962 and 1972, earning great credit for themselves and for this nation;
(3) pays tribute to all Australian men and women who served in that theatre of war and honours the memory of those Australians who died in Vietnam in the service of their country; and

(4) expresses its appreciation and the appreciation of the Australian people for the individual and collective commitment, effort and sacrifice of its sailors, soldiers and airmen, men and women alike, who took part in the Vietnam conflict.

I think it is very important to have read the terms of the motion so that all of those persons who are listening to the broadcast of the debate today-especially Vietnam veterans-will understand what we are doing. It gives me very great pleasure, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, to speak to this motion. I am very pleased to be associated with the Vietnam veterans' national reunion to be held in Sydney from 2 October to 7 October, which is next week. I would like to thank the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) for bringing this matter to my attention. I am very pleased that the honourable member will second this motion. As most honourable members would know, the honourable member for Farrer is a Vietnam veteran. I think he suffered a shrapnel wound in Vietnam. I am also pleased to see that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who is also a Vietnam veteran, is present. There is a bipartisan approach to this motion. I am very pleased to say that the honourable member for Farrer was the instigator of the motion. I also thank the Leader of the House and Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) for allowing us time to debate this motion. I know he is also very concerned about, and pays great tribute to, the Vietnam veterans of this nation.

As I said, it is pleasing to see that the honourable member for McPherson is present. I had the honour, with the honourable member for McPherson, of being part of a parliamentary delegation to Vietnam. It was very interesting to speak to Vietnamese Government officials and also to hear both sides of the story. The visit brought back many memories to the honourable member for McPherson. It also showed members of the delegation, at first hand, the destruction, devastation and suffering of the Vietnamese people. They suffered as Australian service men and women did.

I take a special interest in Vietnam veterans because my nephew was a member of the United States forces in Vietnam. He was conscripted to serve as a member of the United States Army's medical corps in Vietnam. When I visited the United States as the Parliament's representative at the United Nations in 1985, I had an opportunity to go to Texas to speak to my nephew. I can assure honourable members that he had some very sad stories to tell. We have all seen movies where the medic is called in to help his colleagues and comrades wounded in combat. He had to do just that. He is not the same young man who had to go to Vietnam. Likewise, many young men and women in Australia suffer as my nephew does. Some honourable members may be wondering why my nephew served with the United States Army. My eldest sister was a war bride. She is now an American citizen and lives there. That is the connection. My sister married an American soldier just after the Second World War. That is why I pay tribute to not only Australian Vietnam veterans but also American Vietnam veterans.

I pay a special tribute to the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt. I can assure honourable members and the Parliament that he was instrumental in ensuring that Vietnam veterans were given a hearing in the Parliament, the Caucus and especially in Cabinet. He was instrumental in $15,000 of taxpayers' money being granted to ensure that the reunion is a success. I also pay tribute to the organisers of the march. A tremendous amount work has been done behind the scenes. I am sure that it will be a great period for all Australian men and women who are able to witness the proceedings of the week. I am sure that the event will bring back many memories.

I pay tribute to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for his support to the Vietnam veterans by supplying aircraft so that service men and women from Perth, Darwin and other far-away places can go to Sydney. For those who are disabled and are not able to make their own way, the Government, and especially the Minister for Defence, have made available not only aircraft but also Land-Rovers. Many other services will be provided by defence personnel and I am sure that many disabled veterans will be housed.

I thank the Secretary to my Department, Mr Noel Tanzer, and all the deputy commissioners around Australia who have assisted Vietnam veterans. I inform those veterans who may be listening to the broadcast today that the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service will be open in Sydney, the hospitals will be open for those who have problems, and other assistance will be provided. I think that 100 wheelchairs are being supplied by the Department in Sydney. I also thank the State governments, most of which have donated $10,000 towards the reunion. One can imagine there being thousands of Vietnam veterans in Sydney at that time, many of whom, with their families, will have to be billeted. I thank those involved in that area for providing assistance. I also thank those in private enterprise who have donated, together with the Returned Services League of Australia and other organisations. Their contributions have been very valuable in terms of organising this great reunion. It is important to inform honourable members that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has let my office know what arrangements will be made for those wanting to make donations so we can pass on the information to the Vietnam executive which is organising the march. Any donation which a person wants to make to Vietnam veterans will be tax deductible if it is made to a charitable organisation which is willing to accept donations.

I urge all Australians to support this celebration, this reunion, of the Vietnam veterans in Sydney. I hope that people will line the routes of the march. I am sure that it will be a very interesting time and will be very encouraging for those Australian men and women who served our country in the Vietnam encounter. A total of 49,211 Australian service men and women served in Vietnam; 19,450 were national servicemen and 44,295 were conscripted but never went to Vietnam. A total of 41,910 were members of the Army; 4,443, the Air Force; and 2,858, the Navy. I hope that the same number of persons involved will be there on the day. I conclude by reading to the Parliament and to all those listening the Prime Minister's message to the Vietnam veterans:

On the occasion of the Australian Vietnam Forces National Reunion and Welcome Home Parade, Sydney, October 1987, I should like to convey to Australia's Vietnam veterans my own and our nation's best wishes.
This special commemorative event enables all of us to reflect on the significance for Australia of our ten year involvement in the Vietnam War.
Although all Australian forces were withdrawn from Vietnam 14 years ago, Vietnam may never in a sense be withdrawn from the lives and minds of many of our veterans and their families.

There is, of course, no denying the fact that the Vietnam war was one of the most divisive and disturbing issues in Australia's history. But equally, whatever our individual views on the merits of Australian involvement, all of us acknowledge the courage, dedication and sacrifices of our forces in Vietnam. In that conflict, they demonstrated once again the traditional valour and professionalism of the Australian services.

To our Vietnam veterans, and to all who participate in the Commemorative Reunion in Sydney this October, I should like to say personally, and on behalf of all Australians, that we share a sense of pride, gratitude and respect for you and your fallen comrades. You have honoured us with your deeds and with your sacrifices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I support the motion before the House, which gives recognition to Australian Vietnam veterans, and indicate the Opposition's total support for the wording of the motion. This is one of those unique bipartisan occasions. I am pleased to report that, partly at my instigation, the Senate has passed a motion along similar lines today. No doubt the House will do so shortly. I am pleased that I will be joined in my support for the motion by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). We are the only two members of Parliament who are Vietnam veterans. Perhaps it is a reflection of the passage of time that, following the most recent election, there are now only five returned servicemen in the Federal Parliament. But that does not in any way take away from the sense of feeling associated with the motion before the Chair.

SPEECH.PARA: Vietnam veterans of Australia are finally to be welcomed home in a national welcome home parade to be held in Sydney on Saturday, 3 October. The weekend, quite properly, includes reunions, probably a very moving wreath-laying ceremony at 4.30 a.m. in Martin Place, and the parade itself. It has been organised by the Australian Vietnam Forces Reunion Committee under the chairmanship of the hardworking Mr Peter Poulton. It will allow Vietnam veterans to show that they are proud to have served their country. It is vital that the Australian people and the Australian Parliament do not pass up the opportunity to make this truly a welcoming home by the nation. For this reason the Opposition instigated in both Houses of Parliament the raising of a motion recognising the parade and the dedication of Australian Vietnam veterans. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has indicated, some 49,211 Australians served in Vietnam. Very sadly, only some 48,700 Australians returned from Vietnam. Some 500 Australians never returned from Vietnam. This tragic war, which resulted in turmoil in Vietnam for decades, also claimed the lives of over 2 million Vietnamese. Our Australian Vietnam veterans gave it their very best. They fought in very difficult circumstances and showed a great deal of determination and dedication, and all the while maintained the high standards set by Australian soldiers in other conflicts.

In many ways, the Vietnam conflict was unique. For example, there was the advent of the ultra-modern helicopter as a form of transport, the advent of instant television coverage of the war and a range of other factors. It was a war in which the commitment of the Western nations declined as the casualties mounted and as time marched on. It was a war which attracted world-wide controversy and, tragically, the troops serving there unfairly attracted some of the blame associated with that controversy. Yet, the sacrifice made by thousands of Australian sailors, soldiers, airmen, nursing staff and other personnel has never been fully recognised. On the positive side, some good things did eventuate because of Australia's involvement in the war. Medical advances in the treatment of injuries have significantly benefited, and this will help future generations. As well, Australia's military organisation was shown to be cohesive and strong. Its soldiers were well disciplined and professional and, above all, under extreme pressure they coped with the problems of being involved in a very controversial and difficult war.

Vietnam veterans can understandably be disappointed with their welcome home up until now. Controversy surrounding Australia's involvement in Vietnam and disappointment about the outcome of that conflict have left Australians unsure about how to express their appreciation for the individual commitment, effort and sacrifice shown by those Australians who went. However, we hope that on this long weekend in October that will all change. The weekend is the culmination of efforts made by the Australian Vietnam Forces Reunion Committee and its Chairman, Peter Poulton, and several hundred organising behind the scenes. This Committee has not only organised and publicised the event but arranged for over 500 financially disadvantaged and disabled veterans to be flown into Sydney for the march. I acknowledge the contribution made by the Government, by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the provision of Hercules and other forms of Royal Australian Air Force transport to assist with that movement. It is hoped that over 20,000 Vietnam veterans from across the nation will attend, and, significantly, the parade will also include contingents from Korea, the Philippines, Thailand and New Zealand, and a large group from the United States, as well as a South Vietnamese contingent comprised of veterans living in Australia. This march and weekend follows the successful welcoming home of United States Vietnam veterans, which was held in Chicago from 12 to 15 June 1986. I have in my hand a copy of the welcome home parade booklet and poster associated with that very successful parade. In Chicago, a huge tickertape parade was organised, and it included an Australian contingent. It was truly a recognition that the veterans of Vietnam had served their country and deserved the respect and appreciation of its people.

However, even though the Government has announced its support for the parade, and that support is shared across Australia, up till now there has not been a statement from the Parliament of its appreciation of the sacrifices made by Australians in Vietnam. This motion rectifies that, both in the lower House and, as I said earlier, in the Senate earlier this afternoon. Now, the nation and the Parliament have the ideal opportunity to remedy the defect of never having said, in a formal sense `Thank you' to the people who risked their lives in the Australian national interest. Not to be actively involved in this welcome home parade now, either directly or indirectly, would be to pass up the best opportunity we are likely ever to have to extend a welcome home, even if it is some 10 years to late.

The Australian Vietnam forces welcome home parade should be supported by our whole nation, either directly or indirectly. I commend both the motion and the national welcome home parade for our Vietnam veterans to the nation as a whole. I would only add that Australian troops in Vietnam were not into drugs, even if they were into alcohol on occasions-I suppose that that is part of our fighting tradition. They were not into civilian massacres and mayhem. They were into giving disciplined and dedicated service, giving forth their best in extremely difficult circumstances. By this bipartisan motion, we thank them and welcome them home at last, and we wish them well. The House might allow me to say: `We went, we served and we are glad that we are going to be welcomed home at last'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to express my support for the motion and to be associated with it as a Vietnam veteran and also as the shadow Minister for Defence. I pay tribute on behalf of all Australians to all those who served in Vietnam. All wars are savage and difficult, and all people who served in particular theatres believe that that was probably the most savage and difficult of the lot. Who is to judge? Certainly, Vietnam was no different in that regard. It took its toll of life and limb and of the mental health of many people, some of whom are still suffering. In some ways, it was more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) paid tribute to the national servicemen who served in Vietnam. In some ways it was more difficult for them because they were hauled off the streets, so to speak, trained and often were in Australia one day and within 24 hours, without any adjustment period, were in the middle of a theatre of war. I pay tribute to them. I was a company commander at the time and half the soldiers that I had were national servicemen. Within a matter of weeks of those people joining the company one would not have known who was a national serviceman and who was a regular. What is more, one would not have cared. All that mattered was who did the job properly.

Unfairly, servicemen have been blamed for that war. People say, `You were in Vietnam, therefore, you must be one of the guilty parties'. In this House, at one stage a couple of years ago, I was accused of being a hired killer because I had been in Vietnam. I hope that that sort of sentiment has died down, because it should be clearly recognised that people who went to Vietnam went because the Government sent them there and not for any other reason. Over the years since their return, they have had little recognition and I hope that this march in a week's time will go a long way to redressing the imbalance and the lack of recognition that people who served in Vietnam have been accorded compared to the returned service men and women of other wars.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
