TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following proposed standing order be adopted as a sessional order:
General purpose standing committees
28B. (a) General purpose standing committees shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament as follows:
(i) Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs;
(ii) Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts;
(iii) Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training;
(iv) Standing Committee on Community Affairs;
(v) Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs;
(vi) Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology;
(vii) Standing Committee on Infrastructure, and
(viii) Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

(b) A standing committee appointed pursuant to paragraph (a) shall be empowered to inquire into and report on any matters referred to it by either the House or a Minister including any pre-legislation proposal, Bill, motion, petition, vote or expenditure, other financial matter, report or paper.

(c) Each committee appointed under subparagraphs (a) (i) to (iv) and (vi) to (viii), inclusive, shall consist of 12 members and the committee appointed under subparagraph (a) (v) shall consist of 10 members, with membership of each committee reflecting the proportion of Government to Opposition Members in the House, namely, 6 Government and 4 Opposition for a committee of 10 members and 7 Government and 5 Opposition for a committee of 12 members. Each committee may be supplemented with up to 3 members for a particular inquiry. Government members are to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and Opposition members are to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips.
(d) Every nomination of a member to a committee shall be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker.
(e) Each committee shall elect a Government member as its chairman.

(f) Each committee shall elect a deputy chairman who shall act as a chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.

(g) For a standing committee of 12 to 15 members, 6 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee including 4 Government members, and for a committee of 10 or 11 members, 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee including 3 Government members.
(h) Each committee shall have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(i) Each committee shall appoint the chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(j) The quorum of a sub-committee shall be a majority of the members of that sub-committee.

(k) Members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the public proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(l) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(m) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to move from place to place.
(n) Any sub-committee shall have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any sittings or adjournment of the House.
(o) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(p) Each committee shall have leave to report from time to time.
(q) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the relevant standing committees appointed during previous Parliaments.
(r) Each committee shall have power to confer with a similar committee of the Senate.

Parliament has a history of attempting to form committees after each election to deal with matters that may be raised between elections by notice of standing committees or select committees, joint committees between the two Houses, et cetera. In some ways it has been effective and in others it has left a great deal of criticism that perhaps the House of Representatives did not cover as broadly as should be the case, matters raised within this Parliament. This has a long history in that for a long time the Parliament had a very narrow view of the world. If we go back 30 or 40 years we find that the Parliament did not debate the wide range of matters that now come before it. It is true to say that there is hardly one issue affecting the lives of the Australian people that is not, at some stage, debated through legislation, general debate, interest or questions by members of the national Parliament.

It is with this in mind that the Government has resolved that we should move to establish general purpose committees. I do not wish to go through them all. They are listed on the Notice Paper. Honourable members will see from them that with the addition of the joint committees which are being established, there is hardly an issue that cannot be covered. The references can come from the Minister or the House. The numbers of people to serve on the committees are listed. I have not been following the matter that closely but I understand from the Press that the Government has already elected the chairmen of the various committees. I understand that the Opposition will be doing likewise. It is hoped that we will be able to establish the committees as quickly as possible to have the sort of experience of them that we should have prior to our moving to the new Parliament. It may well be that people will have criticisms over the next 12 months of the committees which would require the Parliament-I do not say the Government-looking at some amendment to their operations. Nevertheless, this is an enormously important step that the Government takes in offering to the Parliament-particularly the Opposition-far greater latitude in the operation of the committee system than was ever given previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than you want to give.

—It is not more than I wanted to give. But let me say that it is more than the Liberal and National parties were ever prepared to give during their reign of government. As a member of the Opposition from 1975 to 1983 I know that we continually pressed the Fraser Government to look at expanding the committee system in the House of Representatives but we were denied on every possible occasion. This Government has taken the opportunity--
—Five years to do it.

—Well, we have just been elected for another three years. The truth is that the blokes opposite would not win an election with a shot of elephant juice. This is a very important step in the third term--
—It is an afterthought.

—I say to the honourable member for Gippsland that this is quite a simple proposition. If he does not like it, he should tell us not to have it. As Leader of the House and as a member of the Cabinet, if the honourable member from the Opposition tells us that he does not want this system I will carry the message back to Cabinet.
—It has taken too long to put this before us.

—The honourable member has been busy filling in his colouring books and everything else while he has been sitting opposite for the last four years. He has another three years to go so he should just enjoy himself. Let us see which committee he could serve on. It could be the infrastructure committee, I think. Since the McGaurans own most of the things in Gippsland the honourable member should be pretty good on that committee. Those interjections were uncalled for and unseemly. Let me say that this Government has given the Opposition far greater flexibility in its dealing with these issues through the general purpose committees than has ever been the case previously. It is our sincere hope that the committees work successfully. If they need some minor tinkering when we move to the new Parliament, because of the operations or perhaps because of some criticism that members serving on the committees may have, the Government certainly will be only too willing to look at this.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been the experience of all members of parliament that the committees are capable of doing an enormous amount of constructive work within the parliamentary system. When we are away from the microphones and the media and we have to sit around the table sorting out the various specific problems referred to committees, we find that the committees of this Parliament do enormously constructive and positive work. It is to be hoped that the general purpose committees which we now move to establish can live in the same way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the Government's move to expand the trend that was commenced by the Fraser Government when it established the Standing Committee on Expenditure. We echo the sentiments expressed by the Governor-General on 21 August 1983:

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal would give members of parliament a more effective role and participation in the great affairs of this nation.

Like the Government, the Opposition will watch very carefully the operations of the committees and we will not be hesitant to suggest alterations that might be made. Whilst we support the thrust of what the Government has in mind there are two matters that concern us. I would like to bring them to the attention of the House.

The first is the indication from the Government that staffing and funding of the committee structure will not be increased. Whilst the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has gone to pains to point out that the number of committees will be increased, as I understand it, the Government has not proposed in this financial year to provide any additional staffing or funding. Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask the Leader of the House to go back to the Government to have this matter reviewed. If there is to be no increase in staffing and funding, it follows of course that the existing committees will not be serviced as well as they have been in the past-and those existing committees are vital and very important. I will mention one of them. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts is a very effective watch-dog on public expenditure. I would not want to see that Committee's activities stifled because of lack of proper staffing and facilities.

In a spirit of co-operation, through you Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask the Leader of the House to give us an indication as to the degree of support that will be available in the current financial year and also an undertaking that he will request the Government to review the funding and staffing arrangements. The other matter that is of concern is in relation to the establishment of the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The current proposal before the House is for there to be three senators on the Committee, one from the Government and two from the Opposition, and four members of the House of Representatives, three Australian Labor Party members and one member from the Opposition.

The Opposition is a coalition of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. We would very much like to see the representation from this chamber increased so as to accommodate two Opposition representatives. We would of course agree to an increase in the number of Government representatives. Our proposal is that the 3 : 1 arrangement in the House of Representatives be increased to 4 : 2. I am mindful that that proposal would require an amendment to the legislation. I give an undertaking, on behalf of the Opposition, that if the Government agrees with our proposal we will facilitate such an amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the Government on its courage and commitment to strengthening the effectiveness of parliament in introducing the comprehensive committee system. Parliamentarians and commentators have been seeking this reform for two or three decades. So far no government has been willing to undertake it. So this reform is very important. It will increase the opportunities for backbenchers to be involved in thorough, comprehensive and careful study of particularly important questions. It will also give Ministers an additional forum in which they can present material or to which they can refer issues they regard as requiring further study and it will also give the public the opportunity to put before parliament ideas and information about subjects under discussion. It is a very important reform in strengthening the effectiveness of Parliament. It is a reform that a number of other Westminster-style parliaments have introduced. We are not leading the way in this, but we can draw on their experience in ensuring that this new committee system is effective. I think it will add in important ways to the effectiveness of all backbenchers and, I hope, to the effectiveness of the Government itself. I congratulate the Government on introducing this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the motion establishing the general purpose standing committee, I also wish to canvass the role of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts in part. Let me first refer to the proposed Standing Orders for the committees. Under proposed Standing Order 28b (a), a number of committees are to be established. Paragraph (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A standing committee appointed pursuant to paragraph (a) shall be empowered to inquire into and report on any matters referred to it by either the House or a Minister-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some 10 efficiency audits from a larger number which have been divided between the old Standing Committee on Expenditure and the Public Accounts Committee for consideration. In addition, there was expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance in relation to a number of Appropriation Acts and three years of reports from the Auditor-General whose consideration had yet to be completed. The Public Accounts Committee has before it a very considerable work load, one which is very demanding but which is required of it by statute and by the Government. If honourable members refer to the report of the Public Accounts Committee they will find that a number of matters were raised by the Government which it wanted the Public Accounts Committee to look at. They included the approval of annual report guidelines and the approval of appointments of private auditors to statutory marketing bodies. As well, the Committee had the responsibility of undertaking an examination of all the acquisitions of computers by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do I mention all these matters in this way? It is because we are seeing this very welcome advance with the establishment of a new committee system and with a number of new committees-eight precisely-that will have to be staffed, yet we have before us a proposal containing no additional resources for the Parliament to be able to undertake those works unless the activities of the other committees of the Parliament are curtailed and the staffing shared with the new committees to be established. In relation to the Public Accounts Committee and the work load that it has before it, the changes which I understand are foreshadowed will have a very significant impact. They will probably take more than half of the Committee's staff away and its effectiveness to be able to carry out its statutory responsibilities will be severely curtailed.

I have an interest to declare: I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee in the last Parliament and I will probably seek to be a member of that Committee again because of the nature of the work that it undertakes. I have served on many committees of the Parliament-the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception, the Joint Select Committee on Family Law, the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and the Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights. I know something of the operation of parliamentary committees. The Public Accounts Committee is a unique creature of this Parliament which has served as an example to parliaments around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to Queensland.

—The Minister makes the point that I was coming to, and I thank him for that. It is one which we hope will be an example to Queensland. We can jointly encourage it by enhancing the reputation of the Public Accounts Committee and maintaining the reputation of the Public Accounts Committee to ensure that Queensland will recognise the folly of its ways. If the proposals that we have before us go on and the effectiveness of the Public Accounts Committee is curtailed and its reputation irreparably damaged, we will be doing this Parliament a great disservice and the desire of people to see accountability to the Parliament for expenditure of public moneys will be sabotaged. That is the fact of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the plea most strongly to the Clerks of the Parliament, to Madam Speaker and to the Government to ensure that the resources necessary for this Committee to carry out its functions properly-they may have to be curtailed somewhat; I recognise that-be available to it to ensure that its statutory duties are properly fulfilled. I would regard it as a very poor day if, in establishing this new committee system, we saw the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament effectively ruined. If I believe that its reputation is likely to be damaged I will report to the Parliament and I will certainly discontinue any involvement on my own part with it if it is not going to be able to carry out its functions properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) that this particular moment in Australian parliamentary history is indeed a first because it is truly the first time since Federation that there has ever been established a comprehensive system of standing committees in the House of Representatives. Regrettably, that probably is not going to receive the publicity that it truly deserves to receive because of the importance of the moment and the potential that this change has to improve the quality of Australian democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say in a very bipartisan way-certainly with no reflection on the existing Government, of which I am a staunch and loyal member-that it is true that over the last 20 years, if not more, back bench members on both sides of the House have often felt that there are occasions when they may be tending to become the voting fodder of the Executive government. I truly believe that there is a vast repository of talent and goodwill on both sides of the House that ought to be channelled into constructive energy within the Parliament. I agree with one comment of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), if I understood him correctly, that back bench members do have an important role to play. Certainly my own experience on the Public Accounts Committee bears out just how important parliamentary committees can be.

I address myself briefly to the comments of the honourable member for Dundas. I do not think there would be anyone on this side of the House who would in any way countenance any change in the operation of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts that would lead to some diminution in the effectiveness of that Committee. If there is one thing that we all have in common on this side of the House-I am confident it is shared certainly in the Liberal Party of Australia and hopefully even in the National Party of Australia-it is the belief that the Public Accounts Committee operating effectively is an essential part of the parliamentary process, in the Federal arena and in the States. For that reason we have all sought to bring pressure to bear on the Queensland Government to establish a public accounts committee that will operate effectively.

My response to the honourable member for Dundas is that I am confident that the Government will not allow anything to happen that would diminish the effectiveness of that great Committee. Of course, I too have to declare an interest as having received the support of my colleagues for election to chair that important Committee. It would be remiss of me if I did not give special credit to the honourable member for Fraser who, as honourable members on this side of the House know, was the person who within the Government led the charge for the establishment of this new, comprehensive committee system. Many of us have been strongly supporting the establishment of those committees, as has the Department of the House of Representatives, over a period of, I believe, some 18 years, but it is to the credit of the honourable member for Fraser that he was able to marshal the support to bring about this important change. This House owes him and the government of the day, which has had the courage to implement this reform, a great debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add one or two quick comments in the light of the reference that has been made to my home State of Queensland and the desirability of having a public accounts committee in that State. The Liberal Party in Queensland stood up in the 1983 State election campaign with one of its main platforms the introduction of a public accounts committee. The history of that State election is well known: the Liberal Party having been annihilated for its foresight. Since that time, we have seen a number of senior people in top Government positions in Queensland actually go to prison for the misappropriation of funds, of the people's money, government money. At this moment we are spectators of the saga of corruption in the Queensland Police Force.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to use this forum again, as a Liberal, to direct a plea to the Premier of Queensland and indeed to the State Cabinet to recognise that corruption will thrive when people believe they will get away with it. All Federal government departments are aware of the fact that sooner or later they will be called to account in Parliament for their expenditure. In Queensland it is a never-never business: nobody will ever be touched. I believe that many of the problems in that State are due directly-perhaps indirectly-to the fact that nobody thinks he will ever be found out.

I use this opportunity to commend previous governments in this place for allowing themselves to be subjected to scrutiny. At times it can be an embarrassment to the government of the day when things are uncovered as a result of the scrutiny in the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. I believe that in a democratic system it is essential that everybody subscribe to the theory that if people are left alone and feel they are out of the public eye human nature is such that they will go astray. I commend the Federal Government for allowing the continuation of this Committee and being prepared to subject itself to scrutiny. I conclude by repeating to the Government of my State that it should wake up to itself because a lot of the troubles are of its own making.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say only a few words in support of the proposed committee restructuring. In doing so, I also congratulate the Chairman of the committee which considered the matter, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), for the tremendous work which he put into this proposal and the way he conducted meetings. I am very pleased to see that these changes have been made and we have the opportunity to oversee the work of the Government. I have just one reservation and that is that the committees will rely on the Government, the Minister and the Parliament for their references. I hope that the Government will be helpful in these matters. Sometimes committees have been able to take up items themselves and that has been very helpful as it has enabled us to uncover a lot of problems. I think it has been helpful to the Government also. I hope that although we have lost the opportunity to determine our own references Ministers and the Government will enable the committees to take up some matters which committee members are concerned about and which may reveal things which could be of help to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join colleagues on both sides of the House in commenting briefly on the Government's proposals to establish a range of committees. I should point out, however, that this has been Australian Labor Party policy since 1982. It has taken some three parliaments before the Government has got its act together to the extent that it has been able to do anything about it. I am concerned that the Government proposes to establish, according to my simple mathematics, no less than 22 committees all up. I think that is going to bring enormous strain on the Parliament on both sides and especially on the Opposition, which for obvious reasons, does not have the same number of people potentially available for committee work as the Government has.

SPEECH.PARA: I join my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in making some specific comments in relation to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts (PAC). As the previous Chairman of that Committee, from 1975 to 1982, I totally agree with him that there is a very real risk; despite the comments made by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), who suggested, if I may quote him, that `members will not stand idly by and watch the diminution in the effectiveness of the Public Accounts Committee'. The simple fact of the matter is that an enormous cut back in the staff available to that Committee is proposed. It is well over 50 per cent as I recall. To suggest, therefore, that the Committee is going to be able to maintain the same level of productivity with half or less than half of its resources, is simply nonsense.

A table of reports is included in the Public Accounts Committee's activities report for January 1985 to June 1986, report No. 255. It notes, for example, that in the financial year 1985-86 there were 19 reports; in 1983-84 there were 20, and so it goes. The figures speak for themselves. It is an extremely productive Committee irrespective of which party is in power. Lest there be any doubt about the long term value and prestige of that Committee, it is not gilding the lily of history to say that during my period as Chairman we established the Federal-State public accounts committees conferences. This PAC led the way in revitalising the capacity of the State parliaments to use their public accounts committees far more effectively than those in any other country in the Western world. I refer specifically to New South Wales.

I recall that we had our first conference there deliberately to show the then State Labor Government what could be achieved. I remember that the Treasurer, Mr Renshaw, whom we invited to give the opening address, made the somewhat nonsensical remark on that occasion that he was surrounded by the best Treasury officials that money could buy: he did not need parliamentarians to tell him how to do his job. Within 12 months there were two inquiries, in both the upper House and the lower House, in the New South Wales Parliament. Two years later there were new terms of references for their Public Accounts Committee.

I think it is fair to say that the State level the Public Accounts Committee in New South Wales would be by far the most effective instrument of public accountability in the several State Parliaments and ensures the capacity of Parliament to represent truly the interests of the people in the management of Federal and State financial affairs. Therefore, as an ex-Chairman of the Committee, I take a very dim view of any suggestion that this Parliament now go down the road of suggesting that we can gild the lily of accepting impression rather than substance and at the end of the day seriously expect the Australian people to thank the Government because it has been so abstemious in its expenditure on the Parliament. The Government can of course say, `Yes, we have increased the number of committees, although we have cut their resources to such an extent that none of them can do its job well; but don't worry, ladies and gentlemen, we have maintained our policy'. I say seriously to the Minister at the table, the Leader of the House (Mr Young), that we, as an opposition, support his intention to increase the capacity of members of parliament to make a worthwhile contribution, but let that contribution not be frustrated by honourable members' inability at the end of the day to say that the work of those committees was worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the questions of staff and/or references, which are directly related, there will be some upwards reclassification of staff in terms of their positions, but we will face a problem as we are not in a position to provide unlimited staff. TALK.START.PARA: —It is a statutory committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, the following proposed standing order be adopted as a sessional order:
Standing Committee on Procedure

28C. (a) A Standing Committee on Procedure shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament to inquire into and report on the practices and procedures of the House generally with a view to making recommendations for their improvement or change and for the development of new procedures.
(b) The committee shall consist of 8 members, 5 members to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and 3 members to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips.
(c) The committee shall elect a Government member as its chairman.

(d) The committee shall elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(e) The committee shall have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(f) The committee shall appoint the chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(g) The quorum of a sub-committee shall be a majority of the members of that sub-committee.

(h) Members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the public proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(i) The committee or any sub-committee shall have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(j) The committee or any sub-committee shall have power to move from place to place.
(k) A sub-committee shall have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any sittings or adjournment of the House.
(l) A sub-committee shall have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(m) The committee shall have leave to report from time to time.
(n) The committee or any sub-committee shall have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Standing Committee on Procedure appointed during previous Parliaments.

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following amendments to the standing orders be adopted for the remainder of this session:
Days and hours of meeting
Standing order 40 be amended to read-
40. Unless otherwise ordered, the House shall meet for the despatch of business-
(a) in the first sitting week, on-
Tuesday, at 2 p.m.
Wednesday, at 10 a.m.
Thursday, at 10 a.m., and
(b) in the second sitting week, on-
Monday, at 2 p.m.
Tuesday, at 2 p.m.
Wednesday, at 10 a.m.
Thursday, at 10 a.m.

The 4-weekly cycle will then be repeated.
Adjournment and next meeting
Standing order 48a be amended to read-

48a. At 7.15 p.m. on a Wednesday in a week in which the House is scheduled under the standing orders to meet on the Monday and at 10.15 p.m. on each other sitting day, the Speaker shall propose the question-That the House do now adjourn-which question shall be open to debate; if the House is in committee at the time stated, the Chairman shall report progress and upon such report being made, the Speaker shall forthwith propose the question-That the House do now adjourn-which question shall be open to debate. No amendment may be moved to this question:
Provided that-
(a) if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced;
(b) if, on the question-That the House do now adjourn-being proposed, a Minister requires the question to be put forthwith without debate, the Speaker shall forthwith put the question;
(c) a motion for the adjournment of the House may be moved by a Minister at an earlier hour;

(e) if the question-That the House do now adjourn-is negatived, the House or committee shall resume the proceedings at the point at which they had been interrupted:

Provided further that, if at 8 p.m. on a Wednesday in a week in which the House is scheduled under the standing orders to meet on the Monday, or at 11 p.m. on each other sitting day, the question before the House is-That the House do now adjourn-the Speaker shall interrupt the debate, at which time-

(f) a Minister may require that the debate be extended until 8.10 p.m. or 11.10 p.m., as appropriate, to enable Ministers to speak in reply to matters raised in the preceding adjournment debate; at 8.10 p.m. or 11.10 p.m., as appropriate, or upon the earlier cessation of the debate, the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting, or
(g) if no action is taken by a Minister under paragraph (f), the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting.

When I gave notice to the Parliament of the Government's intention to consider those sections of the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Procedure which the Government had resolved should be determined in fact by the Parliament, a number of honourable members raised with me the question of whether the Parliament itself-and this was raised in evidence given to the Procedure Committee at the time-would meet for its two-week sittings from Monday to Thursday in both weeks. The Government does not find this proposition attractive because of the necessity for Cabinet to meet on the Monday prior to the sitting of those two weeks, or perhaps three weeks, of sittings of the Parliament. I think anyone who has served in the Ministry or the Cabinet would understand the necessity for that.

Nevertheless, having looked at the program there is no doubt that a lot of members, particularly those who have to travel a long way, would be greatly benefited by perhaps sitting more time during the sitting days rather than the extra days themselves. For this purpose I seek the co-operation of the Parliament, and have moved that in the first week of a two-week sitting program we sit the normal hours on the Tuesday, starting at 2 p.m.; on the Wednesday at 10 a.m.; and on the Thursday at 10 a.m. Instead of finishing at 8 o'clock on the Wednesday night, we will sit right through, adjourning at 11 p.m. However, in the first week we would sit only on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday so honourable members can return to their electorates on the Friday, and in the second week of sitting we would have the normal pattern we have now of the Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. This means we will have half an hour less for parliamentary business than we have under the present system, but all honourable members will be back in their electorates attending to their constituents on the Friday rather than on the Friday night or the Saturday morning as is now the case, particularly for people who come from Cairns, Darwin, Perth and some of those places and who cannot get to those places on Friday night.

Again this is something we put forward as an experiment in dealing with procedures. We hope it will be successful. Nevertheless, we will keep our eye on it. If it is not successful, we will be ready to move back to the existing procedures. I think all honourable members who have spoken to me will welcome the fact that we will be able to cram into the three days of the first sitting week almost the same amount of government business as we do now in four days. That will give them the additional day back in their constituencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this motion. The proposal that the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has put before the House effectively reduces the amount of time available to the Opposition to raise matters of public importance and to ask questions of Ministers. As a matter of fact, it really contradicts the resolutions we have just agreed to to establish committees, which, as I pointed out and the Leader of the House pointed out, give honourable members more opportunity to participate in the affairs of the nation through this Parliament. I know the Minister has made it clear that this is for a trial period, but we do not even support it for a trial period. If the Minister and the Government have additional business to deal with on a Wednesday night, we will gladly co-operate and we will be prepared to sit on Wednesday evenings, but we are not prepared to agree to give up Question Time or the opportunity to raise a matter of public importance on a Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was careful to say a few moments ago that, under the proposed arrangements, the House would be able to deal with the same amount of Government Business between Tuesday and Thursday as is currently dealt with between Tuesday and Friday, but the operative words were `Government Business'. As I understand it, the Government gets about 2 1/2 hours of business time on Fridays and, by sitting on Wednesday evenings, it will still get the additional 2 1/2 hours. The Opposition misses out on Question Time. Increasingly, Parliament has been missing out on questions ever since this Government took office.

It is important for the House to know the average number of questions without notice asked on each sitting day over the past few years: in 1980, under the Fraser Government, 15.2; in 1981, 16.2; in 1982, 15.4; in 1983-the first year of the Hawke Government it dropped to 12.7; in 1984, 12.1; in 1985, 12; and in 1986, 11.8. Until 4 June this year, the average has been 10.7. The average number of questions without notice being asked on each sitting day has progressively dropped, yet in 1984 the size of the House of Representatives and the Senate was increased. There are more honourable members but fewer opportunities to ask questions. We oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I do not argue with the Question Time figures given by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife)--
—Not even the logic.

—Not even the logic. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure made a recommendation about the number of questions. When dealing before the election with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), we suggested that the Government intended that there be no fewer than seven questions from the Opposition each Question Time. We are trying to rectify the problem in Question Time, in terms of the number and length of questions and the length of answers, by ensuring that at least a minimum of seven questions comes from the Opposition.
—Will you increase the length of Question Time?
—I doubt it. I shall ring up Nareen and ask Malcolm what he would have done.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Ms Crawford:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it Please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Bowman, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I wish at the outset of my first speech to this Parliament sincerely to thank the electors of Bowman for the trust and confidence which they have placed in me. I am proud to represent them in this House. I am equally proud to be here as one of the five new Labor members from Queensland and to have the opportunity of contributing to this historic third Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am, as many honourable members know, a naturalised Australian, having arrived in this country at the age of four with my parents and younger brother in 1951. I am Italian by birth and I stand here today as only the second ever Italian-born member of this Parliament and as the very first Sicilian-born. As a new Australian, immigration and ethnic affairs are a part of my heritage and, therefore, a matter in which I shall be very interested.

Australia has come a long way from the days of its white Australia policy. This policy was effectively traded in for a multicultural Australia for unashamedly practical reasons after the Second World War. Only the most narrow-minded person would now deny the success of multiculturalism and the contribution made to Australia, both economically and culturally, by migrants of all nationalities.

At the opening of Parliament last week, the Governor-General indicated in his Speech that the Government had commissioned a review of Australia's immigration policies. I welcome this review as I believe it will produce an immigration policy which will carry us into the next century. This initiative, first promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the recent federal election, shows this Labor Government's concern and commitment to a multicultural Australia. With approximately 1.2 million people applying to migrate to Australia each year, this updating of our immigration policy will ensure the current economic and social needs of our country are served and at the same time will preserve Australia's excellent record throughout the world as a humanitarian nation.

The nature of this review will provide an opportunity for community and ethnic groups to communicate with one another and come to a better understanding of Australia's capacity for migrant intake. This review process is an initiative which I applaud and which has my fullest support.

By virtue of my birthplace, I am here today representing not only my electorate of Bowman but also the large national Italian community. The Italo-Australian community represents the largest group of non-British immigrants in this country. On latest calculations, there are some 800,000 of us. This figure includes those of us who, like me, were born in Italy and those who have one or more parents born in Italy. So significant is the magnitude of the Italo-Australian community that it is serviced by two excellent Italian language newspapers, namely Il Globo and La Fiamma, which between them have a circulation of almost 100,000.

I wish to record at this stage my sincere thanks to and appreciation of the Italian Ambassador to Australia, Mr Eric Da Rin, and his assistant, Mr Faustino Troni, both of whom have graciously extended their congratulations and good wishes to me on the occasion of my election to this House. In addition, I was extremely pleased to have received a congratulatory letter from the Italian Foreign Minister, the Hon. Gulio Andreotti. I can assure them that their support and encouragement has been greatly appreciated and I am proud to have been thought worthy of their congratulations.

Italians have contributed to every aspect of the Australian community, including business, church life and sport. By their hard work and industry since the turn of the century they have built up the north Queensland sugar industry into the most efficient in the world. Their contribution to the overall economy of this country cannot be underestimated. Whilst I could find no accurate statistics to highlight my claim, I doubt whether each member of this House does not know of at least one Italo-Australian who owns a successful small business, a concrete or marble firm, a construction company, a farm, or simply a good Italian restaurant.

The Italian company Electric Power Transmission, otherwise known as EPT, has been constructing power lines across the length and breadth of this nation for many years now, using the highest technology and engineering skills, and at present is electrifying much of the rail network in my home State of Queensland. Another Italo-Australian company, Transfield, has just completed the construction of the Gateway Bridge which links, across the Brisbane River, my electorate and that of Lilley. These are only two examples of the enterprise and contribution of the Italian community in Australia. There are obviously countless others.

Italians are no longer referred to as new Australians. Having helped to lay the foundations to build Australia, they are now an inspiration to all new arrivals to our country and contribute to the evidence that Australia is still the land of golden opportunity.

On my way to Canberra this week it was quite correctly suggested to me by my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) that I have a duty to the village of Piedimonte Etneo where I was born, to my grandparents, now both deceased, to my father and mother-who, I am sure, are both listening to this speech at home-and to all Sicilian-Australians to tell their story to this House. I am pleased to take up this suggestion, as Sicilians in this country generally have been much maligned because of the unsavoury activities of the very few. The reality is that the Sicilian community represents the largest single group within the national Italian community and numbers some 250,000. Many of them are descended, like me, from poor farming families. Their families, like mine, came to Australia with no knowledge of our language and, in fact, often unable to read or write even their own language. Their only material possessions were the clothes on their backs, but they brought with them the most valuable asset of all-a vision and a dream that through hard work, determination and tenacity they would succeed. Included in this dream was their firm belief that they could achieve for their children and for their grandchildren that which was not available to them in their own country, namely, equal opportunity-the same equal opportunity that Australians often take for granted.

In addition to that vision they also brought with them what regretfully is becoming less and less important in our modern Australian society-that is, the preservation of the family unit and, moreover, a deep and profound respect for their elders. It is with pride that I can say that Italians generally, and Sicilians in particular, treat their parents and grandparents with a love and respect that borders on reverence. My own grandmother, who passed away only a few years ago, epitomised the very reason why the elderly command such emotions. She was a kind-hearted and warm Sicilian woman who was completely illiterate but, through hard work, along with my grandfather, raised her family in Sicily during wartime under very difficult circumstances. She imigrated to Australia when she was in her mid-60s, together with my grandfather, and died in the family home in Australia at the age of 86. Until the last weeks of her life she was not satisfied unless she was working and doing something constructive. Is it little wonder that it is highly unusual for the elderly in Italian families to be found in retirement homes? They generally end their lives in their children's home and this creates the cycle of respect that is carried down from generation to generation and which I naturally hope my children will continue when I grow old.

The legacy that the original Sicilian immigrants have left and will leave is the knowledge that their children and grandchildren have in the main become successful, entered the professions and achieved distinction in many areas of Australian society. It is with pride and humility that I count myself amongst their numbers.

I have mentioned previously in my speech that the concept of equal opportunity was the main reason why there has been such an influx of immigrants into this country since Federation. It is because of my sincere belief in the concept of equal opportunity for all, irrespective of their race, colour, or creed, that I am a member of the Australian Labor Party. In realising the vision and dreams of my family I have not forgotten the roots from which I came. I have sought throughout my whole adult life, through my legal practice and my connections with the trade union movement, and now as a Federal Labor member of parliament, to dedicate myself to the principle of creating a society of equal opportunity for all Australians. I have been a member of my Party for 23 years, having first jointed the youth wing of the Queensland Branch at age 17 and at 21 achieving the position of State President of Young Labor, Queensland branch.

During the maiden speech of my colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) reference was made to the long and hard road which some honourable members have endured to obtain a seat in this House. Perhaps it can be said that he was unwittingly referring to me. I first sought to represent my Party in the State Parliament in Queensland in 1969 and had the rather unique distinction of casting my first ever vote in my own favour. I owe much to the great Australian Labor Party. Obviously, if it were not for my association with Labor I would surely not be standing here today. The people of Bowman elected me for a variety of reasons, but I am certain that the overwhelming majority elected me because I was part of a team-a team called the Australian Labor Party. I can find no better way to succinctly describe the approach of this Government than to use the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on delivering the Budget last week when he said that Labor was `governing with compassion and authority, good sense and confidence'. This is the Labor way.

I now wish to make some mention of the at times comical and at other times sinister antics of the National Party State Government in my home State of Queensland. If I do not I will be shot. I had intended to make more detailed reference to these matters in my maiden speech to this House. However, because of advice that I have received from a member of this House, whose advice I respect, I will not be unduly provocative and will address my remarks in a much milder way. I come from a State where the Government is more concerned with prosecuting comedians than restoring the economy which it has allowed to run down over many years; where the Government is more interested in commissioning commando-style raids on university campuses in the early hours of the morning to remove condom vending machines, which, believe it or not, are illegal in that State; and where it is more concerned with disregarding public opinion on important issues than abolishing the worst gerrymandered electoral boundaries in the country.

One of the major areas where the Queensland National Party State Government stands condemned is its unreasonable and confrontationist attitude toward the union movement. Although often denigrated by our conservative opponents here and in Queensland, I have found the trade union movement in Queensland to be a responsible body which at all times works in the interests of its membership. Queensland unions and unionists work in the very difficult atmosphere of animosity from an extremist State government and survive despite constant threats to their right to organise and even their fundamental right to exist.

Democracy has long been sick in the State of Queensland but the final blow will be struck if the National Party Government further extends its already draconian industrial legislation and introduces work contracts. The proposed legislation provides only the bare minimum of guaranteed working conditions allowing the rest to be negotiated, supposedly voluntarily, between employers and employees. Job security in any workplace will become a thing of the past because the Government will specify that contracts must cover a period of less than three years. Awards will no longer apply and disputes will be settled between individuals in the civil courts rather than by the tried and true method of conciliation and arbitration before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

The Hawke Labor Government has shown what co-operation and rational discussion with the union movement can achieve. I do not want to take anything away from my colleague the Treasurer; in fact I am sure that he would agree with me that much of the credit for the continuing economic recovery of this country must be attributed to the union movement. The restraint and maturity which it has shown in these troubled times makes it a pleasure for me to say in this place that I am a proud unionist and, in fact, I am, and have been for some time, a financial member of two major Australian industrial unions.

I am a lawyer by profession and, as such, I have a great respect for the law and the institution of the law. My legal practice in Brisbane is renowned for the industrial work which it performs and while, because of my parliamentary and electoral responsibilities, I can no longer play a part in the practice of law I will be taking a keen interest in all legal matters that come before this House. My previous work in the field of industrial law and general common law damages claims brought me into direct contact with the trade union movement and its members. My work in the specific area of master and servant common law claims and workers compensation claims has given me an appreciation of the day to day problems which Australian workers face in their workplaces. I firmly believe that the Government's initiatives in the area of occupational health and safety will go a long way to minimise the many hundreds of millions of dollars that it costs the community yearly as a result of industrial accidents.

It is surely appropriate that I devote a portion of the time available to me today to describe the area and the people which I represent in this place. The Federal electorate of Bowman is both complex and diverse. It is, in many respects, a microcosm of Australian society with much of the social and economic spectrum contained within its borders. The electorate is an area in which conservation and industry both play an important part. Moreton Island is among the bay islands which I have the honour to represent. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) would know that. I have a keen interest in ensuring the preservation of Moreton Island in its natural state for future generations of Australians to enjoy. It is one of the largest sand masses in the world and, during the Federal election campaign, I had the privilege of escorting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to this beautiful part of my electorate where he once again demonstrated this Government's commitment to the environment. As a financial member of the Moreton Island Protection Society, an active organisation dedicated to keeping the natural beauty of the island intact, I will continue to assist in the fight to ensure that the Queensland State Government is not able to destroy yet another part of Queensland's natural heritage.

I am also proud to have situated in my electorate the Island known as North Stradbroke Island. North Stradbroke is one of the most historic and picturesque sections of the Moreton Bay area and boasts one of the oldest and culturally rich Aboriginal communities. North Stradbroke is a stark example of the environment and industry existing together harmoniously. It is famous for its rich mineral sands and, although sand mining has been in existence for decades, rehabilitation programs employed by the sand mining company are first class. Other well known islands in my electorate situated in Moreton Bay are Russell, Macleay, Karragarra, Lamb, Peel and Coochie Mudlo. Almost all of these islands are inhabited by permanent populations and form an integral part of the natural attraction of the Moreton Bay region. All honourable members will be welcome if they want to come for a holiday.

In stark contrast to the islands is the northernmost end of my electorate, where much of the heavy industry is located. The community there is well established with the majority of residents on fixed incomes. It is a suburb of working class people; people who have worked hard all their lives; people who are entitled to expect a decent and safe standard of living for themselves and their children. Honourable members will recall, as a result of a question asked by me in this House last Tuesday week, the recent saga of the proposed construction of a caustic chlorine plant in the residential bayside suburb of Lytton. During the Federal election, when the National Party of Australia mistakenly thought it could win the seat of Bowman, the Queensland State Government announced that the plant would no longer be built in that area. Although much relieved and no doubt very grateful, the residents of the area recorded their usual strong support for the Australian Labor Party on election day. I take this opportunity of thanking them for not allowing themselves to be blackmailed or bribed by the Premier's ploy to try to buy their votes. In what can only be described as a shameful decision, the Premier reneged on his election commitment and announced that the plant would go ahead despite the obvious safety risks involved. Massive public outcry ensued, and even when faced with a revolt in his own Party the Premier stubbornly decided to use the issue to reassert his dominance, which was, I remind honourable members, already very badly tarnished after his failed Canberra push. In the end the chemical company itself did the honourable thing and yielded to massive public pressure. This is typical of the disregard which the Queensland Government has for the ordinary working men and women in Queensland. I state quite categorically that the people of Bowman are entitled to the same quality of life as the people of Kingaroy.

Further south my electorate encompasses the famous Redlands district, formerly a farming area noted for its volcanic red soil. It was in this area that I grew up and my father operated a small market garden. Much of this areas has now become a medium density residential area, and in fact continues to grow at one of the fastest rates in Australia. This area is a typical mortgage belt area, with its young families and first home owners. It is these families in suburbs such as Alexandra Hills and Capalaba who have benefited from the first home owners scheme introduced by the Hawke Government, and will further benefit from the further declines expected in home loan interest rates. At the southernmost end of my electorate are the still rural areas of Thornlands and Redland Bay. These areas supply much of the market garden needs of south east Queensland, including the famous Redlands strawberries, of which the residents of the Redlands Shire are justifiably proud.

It would not have been possible for me to take my seat in this place if it were not for the tremendous support and encouragement that I have received from a wide variety of relatives, friends and Labor Party supporters. I wish to place on record my sincere gratitude to and appreciation of my father and mother, who came to this country with the specific dream of giving my younger brother and me an education and the opportunity to succeed. My brother and I, for our part, have realised their hope and ambition by both entering the profession of law and now by my election to this House. I make specific mention of my brothers Joe and Phillip and my sister Sarina, who have been tremendous to me over many years in helping me to achieve my goals. My special thanks go to my branch members in Bowman, many of whom have shown me great loyalty and friendship over a long period. I assure them that their efforts will not be forgotten. I wish also to take this opportunity to place on record my sincere appreciation of the friendship, help and support that I have received from Mr Errol Hodder, Secretary of the Queensland branch of the Australian Workers Union, Mr Bob Briskey, recently retired State Secretary of the Amalgamated Postal and Telecommunications Union, and its current Federal President, Mr John Hogg, the Queensland State Secretary of the Shop Assistants Union, and my many other friends in the union movement.

Last, but certainly not least, I want to make particular mention in this, my first speech to this House, of the love, affection and tremendous support that I have received from my wife, Tina. Her loyalty and support during the 17 years that she has been with me and during which time I have had my fair share of political ups and downs-mainly downs-has never faltered. I love her and my family very much. I am pleased and most grateful that she is here today with my two children, Zina and Sam, to hear me deliver this speech. It is certainly a moment for which the four of us have waited for so long.

In conclusion, Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure that those honourable members present from both sides of the House who know me personally would acknowledge that despite the hard road behind me I have never lost that tenacity and determination characteristic of the Sicilian race. Those who do not know me quite as well will, I assure you, Madam Deputy Speaker, be very quick to learn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member on his speech, but I encourage him to look up to see who is in the chair in future. Before I call the honourable member for Chisholm, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great privilege and honour to stand in this House as the representative of the people of Chisholm, an electorate in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. I thank the people of Chisholm for the opportunity to serve them, a task to which I look forward with great enthusiasm. Chisholm was created in 1948 and was served from 1949 to 1970 by Sir Wilfrid Kent Hughes, a man who is still fondly remembered in the electorate today. From 1970 to 1980 it was represented by Tony Staley, a man whose advice I sought some years ago when I considered standing for Chisholm, and whose enthusiasm and encouragement is, in part, responsible for my coming to this House. More recently, Chisholm was ably served by Graham Harris of the Liberal Party of Australia and Helen Mayer of the Australian Labor Party. Following those people, I am cognisant of the hard work and excellent representation to which the people of Chisholm are accustomed.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not come to this place without a great deal of support from a large number of people, I wish to place on record my gratitude to the many people, both inside and outside the Liberal Party in Chisholm, whose tireless teamwork has enabled me to stand here today. These people have an unswerving belief in the role of the individual in society, in the ability of people to order their own lives and to make choices for themselves, and who have the desire to achieve justice by maximising the freedom and opportunity of the individual, rather than placing the duty of justice on authorities with the power to command people what to do. I also wish to acknowledge the role of my parents, family and close friends, in particular, Shelly Colman and Rob Collins, whose confidence and support gave me the courage to pursue my convictions rather than opt for a more secure existence, and whose hard work over a long period was an invaluable help.

One comes to this place with a certain amount of baggage which colours one's outlook and perspective on life. I grew up in a very close family, one that encouraged personal responsibility, that valued competition in encouraging the individual to achieve his full potential, and that placed greater value on satisfaction with personal effort in any endeavour, rather than the ultimate success or failure of that endeavour. It is with this background that I come here with a vision for the type of society in which I wish to live. Much is said about Sweden as a model for society, for co-operation and consensus. Yet this is the type of society that has an inherently weak government, where it is very difficult for government to make a policy decision without the acquiescence of interest groups, and where the `power of the pull', the ability to get one's own way, leads to a high welfare state where all groups must be accommodated, but where the individual outside those groups is powerless and forgotten. Such a society suffers the tyranny of the majority. This is not a free society. In a free society, in the words of Walter Lippmann, `the state does not administer the affairs of men, it administers justice among men who conduct their own affairs'. This `power of the pull' is leading us to a society where powerful interest groups promote entrenched privilege, where anachronistic practices by labour and management continue unchanged, where rigid work rules, a legacy of an era of standardised mass production, remain protected, and where mature industries have more political sway than emerging ones.

All this leads us along a road where social and economic fatigue erode our productive capacity. This is the Argentinean road. If we are to avoid the Argentinean road, it will be through the productive effort of ordinary Australians, who are often powerless and forgotten. It is these forgotten people-people in business, in professions and on the land-without strong business groups or strong trade union groups to speak for them, people who are working for their own security and happiness and that of their families, who are much of the dynamic, innovative and productive element of society.

It was out of a sense of balance that Sir Robert Menzies directed much of his energy towards these forgotten people. Today, these people are again being squeezed. Once again, out of a sense of balance, I believe that the energies of government should be directed towards providing an environment to give these people the incentive and motivation to pursue their goals, free of the hand of government, inasmuch as their actions do not adversely diminish the freedom of others. Of course, in a society not all will cope. I see no contradiction between a society that promotes competition and rigorously defends the role of the individual, and yet has compassion for and an understanding of those who will not cope or cannot compete. It was Menzies' view that `industrial progress is not to be based on the poverty or despair of those who cannot cope'. That is a view which I hold.

I turn to two areas of concern. The first relates to our aging population. Currently 10 per cent of our population is over 65 years of age. By the time I reach retiring age that number will have increased by 56 per cent. Whilst services for the aged are improving, one area stands out as being of particular concern-that is, services to those who are physically fit but failing mentally. With age-related dementia appearing as an increasing problem, services to this group are of great concern. Domiciliary services to these people, while improving, have a marked lack of nurses and other health personnel with psychiatric skills, skills which are necessary to properly advise and counsel a family on the difficulties and stresses associated with having an aged, demented person in the home. For the more seriously demented person-and that is 4 to 5 per cent of the population over 65 years-specialised hostels for difficult patients, particularly those who wander, are in short supply. Currently, many of these people are in psychiatric hospitals or nursing homes at about double the cost to the community. Such hostels do not require trained nursing staff but can be managed adequately by competent people with a minimum of in-service training.

Finally, there is a great need for specialised nursing homes for seriously demented people who are physically well. Currently, such people are inappropriately placed in nursing homes, where they must be physically and chemically restrained, or in long term wards and psychiatric hospitals. In some cases, because of lack of knowledge or facilities, such people are treated in a manner the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals would not tolerate for animals. From the onset to death from Alzheimer's disease, the average lifespan is nine to 10 years and many people would spend half that time in institutional care. In raising this issue, I do not see the solution as a greater call on government funds but rather as a change in attitude at a State and Federal level, a more appropriate direction of government funding and a willingness to battle entrenched positions. In this way government could contribute to a more humane and compassionate treatment of those in our society with no voice at all.

Secondly, I wish to speak about the identity card. A great deal has been said in this chamber about the taxation and social security aspects of this card. These are two of the three main areas in which it would impinge on people's lives. However, it is the third area of use, in relation to medical services, which has received no debate, which is of particular concern to me-this area being, in the words of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), `the only relatively regular use that will be made of the card by most Australians'. Clause 53 of the Australia Card Bill requires that a recognised hospital notify the Health Insurance Commission of the identity card number of any person entering that hospital. Quite simply, this means that any person entering a specialised private hospital for treatment of alcoholism, for treatment of psychiatric or stress-related disorder or to undergo plastic surgery, for example, will have the name of the hospital and the hospital stay recorded on a central computer. That will be recorded even if the hospital and medical bills are paid for totally by the patient.

As a doctor I have indeed felt privileged-not in the sense in which that word is most commonly used by the detractors of the profession, but in the sense that one sees people when they are at their most vulnerable and one has the confidence and trust of people at such a time. There are few times in medical practice when one sees someone more vulnerable as an individual, or a family in more distress, than when a person needs treatment for alcoholism or a psychiatric disorder. Commonly, people move interstate because of the stigma involved. That will occur no more. Wherever a person goes, the government will know.

We will have the intrusion of government into the most personal, private and intimate aspects of someone's life. Quite frankly, it is none of government's business and it is very small consolation to suggest that there will be adequate privacy provisions. In recent years we have seen the privacy of the Health Insurance Commission computer. The most recent example of which honourable members will be aware saw young women being interviewed at home and at work and their personal lives being brought before the courts merely because they had been referred to a doctor who was under investigation by the police. This aspect of the legislation is a major intrusion into a very intimate and personal aspect of someone's life. It really is the final insult that this piece of legislation places individuals as mere cogs in the corporate wheel of government. It will receive the contempt it deserves.

Finally, one comes to this House not just as a representative of an electorate but also as a representative of a party. While I have been a member of the Liberal Party for only a relatively short time, I have never seriously doubted the philosophy of the Party. For the reasons I have already mentioned, I am proud to be a member of the Liberal Party in this House. It is a party that offers Australians the opportunity to maximise their own productive effort and reward and to give a voice to the forgotten people while at the same time showing compassion for those who genuinely need the help of government. I look forward to my time in this House and I thank honourable members for the courtesy they have extended to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Hinkler I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to congratulate Madam Speaker on her re-election to such an important position in this House, and also Mr Deputy Speaker on his re-election. I also extend my gratitude to a woman in another house, my wife, Marcia, who along with my family has supported me so loyally in my efforts to be elected to Parliament. I am beginning to understand the significant sacrifices which wives and husbands make in the service of our great nation. In this respect, I wish to acknowledge the efforts and energy of my predecessor in the Hinkler division, Mr Bryan Conquest. My family has had a close relationship with representation in the Hinkler electorate. My father served on a local authority within the division. My great-uncle Ben served the State of Queensland as a senator for some 25 years. I am honoured to follow the lead they have given me. Their interests, like mine, were those of my local area. In my electorate, the industry, management and employees are responding positively to the changed circumstances our nation is facing.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer honourable members to the Queensland sugar industry as proof of our ability to respond. Bundaberg is the centre for the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd. The company, led as it then was by Mr Roy Diecke and his executive, foresaw major difficulties looming in the industry. With the co-operation of unions, cane growers and management, a revitalisation process was formulated. This process occurred long before the cry was taken up by the Queensland Government. The process of co-operation and consultation has ensured that today the Bundaberg Sugar Co. is in a sound position to face up to a changed world situation. This has been completed with a minimum number of industrial disputes. Honourable members might well contrast this approach with the destructive confrontationist alternatives.

Bundaberg offers sugar producers and Australia a fully integrated package. It has excellent soil, a well-established port, a rum distillery, a sugar refinery and three mills-Bingera, Fairymead and Millaquin. Australia, through a provincial city like Bundaberg, has optimised its export income through this approach. Nearby, in Childers, the Isis sugar mill plays an important part in the region's prosperity.

The challenge for all our primary producers is to examine ways in which they can achieve this integrated approach. I am convinced that employment can be created, and export income generated, if all primary producers examine the maximum income to be made from their product. The wool industry is one such industry. I am certain, too, that the cattle industry can be fully utilised. I assure all honourable members that Bundaberg has plenty of facilities ready to accommodate any ideas business people may have.

The sugar industry welcomes the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to finance research into the industry. All our primary products will penetrate world markets, provided they are equipped with the latest research capability. I welcome, too, the assurance from the Prime Minister that rum maturation will no longer be an issue with the Government. As some honourable members would be aware, Canberra has the perfect climate for one of Bundaberg's finest products, Bundaberg rum. Members and their constituents who may have indulged in this beverage can be assured that their headaches have maintained employment in my electorate.

As a member whose family owns a cane farm, I confess to a vested interest in my concern for the sugar industry. I might also say that all cane farms are experiencing the changes which are now being witnessed in our district. Our farm has now been partially leased for the growing of tomatoes. This diversification is occurring on farms throughout our region. As well as sugar, Childers now has large avocado farms. Brian Weiss first interested farmers in the district in the advantages of avocados. The Bundaberg region has surpassed Bowen as a major tomato growing centre. People like John Pressler, Ron Simpson, John Neighbour and Ray and Rosemary Anderson were the pavers in creating this industry in our local region. The Bundagerg office of the Commonwealth Employment Service has just notified that over 1,000 job vacancies exist for pickers in this industry over the next few months. This is significant cash infusion into our local economy. The success of this operation may be reflected in a glut in some markets. However, diversification has meant survival for primary producers in my electorate.

In the Port Curtis region, diversification has seen the emergence of one of the largest paw-paw operations in Queensland. Roy and Thelma Wilson have contributed significantly to this industry in the region. The processing of these primary products can be undertaken in our region. These fruits and vegetables could easily be processed in our area. I call on our businessmen wishing to export these products to contact the Bundaberg Development Board. It, together with officers of Austrade, will be willing to ensure that the potential can be explored.

To the west of the provincial cities are the citrus growing areas of Gayndah and Mundubbera. The fruit grown in this region is the finest citrus in the world. Hinkler produces some of Australia's finest primary products. These many and varied industries are the life blood of the numerous towns of the region. Cracow is producing gold once more. The devaluation of the dollar, imputation of company dividends, the prices and incomes accord and the incentives for research and development are incentive enough for business people to explore the opportunities.
