The major difficulty is the Queensland Government. Queensland has no major blueprint for manufacturing industry. Queensland manufacturing has lost jobs every year since 1982. The Australian Bureau of Statistics confirms a continuing decline in manufacturing in every month of 1987, over the same months of the previous year. The last time manufacturing was wasted so severely was in the early 1980s. The previous Federal Government followed the Gregory thesis. This theory meant that manufacturing was stripped, whilst Australia embarked upon a drive to export minerals. Regrettably, Queensland is still adhering solely to this thesis. A more diverse economy would have cushioned Queenslanders against a downturn in world commodity prices. Yet, a broad based economy is still achievable. It would be marvellous if the Queensland Government took up the challenge and made the Hinkler electorate the model for the transition from primary production to an integrated secondary industry.

Factories within the Hinkler electorate have already taken up the new dynamics in the Australian economy. One important company is Austoft in Bundaberg. I invite all honourable members to come to Bundaberg and meet with the management of this progressive company. Its birth is noted inconspicuously in the book Australian Events and Places. In a chapter entitled `Bundaberg', the company is mentioned merely as a local engineering works, which was taken over in 1966 to manufacture whole stalk cane harvesters. The chapter merely noted that this was the only such plant in the world making this product in the 1970s. In 1971, the ownership passed to foreign interests and has been foreign owned since that time. In that sense, the company followed a distinctly Australian tradition.

Throughout the 1970s and early 1980s, with sugar prices buoyant, there was simply no need to change a successful formula. The company was strong enough, even to withstand the overvalued dollar. By 1986, the sands of time had shifted against the sugar industry, but had shifted in favour of Australian manufacturing. By 1986, the management was successful in achieving a management buy out, and the company is now back in Australian hands. The company, now trading as Austoft, exports sugar cane harvesters to more than 40 countries, and now has 95 per cent of world export markets, as well as 100 per cent of the Australian market. In recent times, Austoft has diversified into other hydraulically operated construction equipment, through the development of trenchers and loaders. Last year, Austoft achieved 37 per cent of the Australian trencher market, after only one year in the business. Previously, most trenchers were imported from the United States of America and therefore Austoft is not only a significant exporter but is also replacing many imports.

This company has taken up the challenge, and has now taken the bold step of acquiring an American company, which is the second largest in its field in North America. As a result, Austoft not only acquired the Mustang product range, but also a strong distribution channel into northern America and Europe, for its construction equipment. Austoft builds quality Australian products. It is Australian managed, and controlled. It is out there, on world markets, earning export income for Australia. There are some who would have us believe that such success could be achieved only by squashing the employees and allowing management to run riot. The fact is that Austoft is a highly people-oriented company. The management and work force consult about difficulties and directions the company is taking. Men like Leo Mulkearns, the general manager, and assistants like Geoff Campbell, Phil Ainsworth and John McGrath, are local Bundaberg people, showing the rest of the world. How ironic that their management techniques have to be shown to the rest of Australia. Honourable members opposite, who wanted to scrap the export management development grants, should go to Austoft. The company has received about $600,000 since the Hawke Government was elected in grants from the scheme. Come to Bundaberg, and see an Australian company becoming a world leader with the help of these grants.

The Hinkler electorate is blessed with an industrial power house in Queensland in the city of Gladstone. Blessed with a natural harbour, Gladstone is the site for some of the largest industrial companies in Queensland: the Boyne Island aluminium smelter, Queensland Alumina, the Queensland Cement and Lime Co., a grain handling facility, a huge power station, and a coal loading facility at Clinton Wharf. With such assets, Gladstone's potential is unlimited. I am keen to see Gladstone become the industrial giant of central Queensland. It has overcome the image difficulties it had many years ago. Gladstone is now a wonderful city ready to move along the path to continuing economic recovery for Australia.

I promised during the election campaign that I would try to establish a task force in Gladstone. I am delighted to inform the House that the inaugural meeting of the task force has been held. For the first time, we have seen in Gladstone, unions, local government, small business and management join together to promote and develop the region's resources. I would like to express my appreciation to the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and members of the Port Kembla Task Force, for giving their valuable time to meet with the Gladstone group, to ensure that it got off on the correct footing. On the Gladstone group's behalf, I would also like to thank the Prime Minister for his interest in the project. The Prime Minister, during his recent visit announced an allocation of $25,000, to enable the Gladstone task force to set up a research capability. Although a fledging group, the Gladstone task force is meeting in a spirit of co-operation to place the future of Gladstone high on its agenda. Mr Deputy Speaker, if I may place this small commercial: If there are business people listening, and looking for a place to invest, I would say to them, `Get on a plane and head for Gladstone and Bundaberg'.

The Hinkler division includes the tourist resorts of Heron Island and Lady Elliott Island, and coastal areas including Woodgate, Elliott Heads, Innes Park, Bargara, Moore Park and Agnes Waters. These areas are perfectly placed to take up the tourism explosion Australia is enjoying. The work being done by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), the Australian Tourist Commission, and entertainers like Paul Hogan, are giving Australia every opportunity to capitalise on our tourist potential. The devaluation of the dollar and the political instability in some of the world destinations have strengthened Australia's case for tourism. I am keen to see investment along the coastline of Hinkler to accommodate tourists. The climate in the region is one of the most equable in the world. It has much to offer tourists. I encourage all honourable members to consider these resorts when escaping the chills of Canberra.

My speech would be incomplete without discussion about the wealth creating coal industries in Moura. Honourable members might well pause to consider the difficulties in the industry. I have representations before me from the Moura Widows Association. Honourable members may well recall the tragedy of the Moura mine disaster. Nearby is the Kianga mine, which was the source of tragedy some years ago. In these times, it is often forgotten that the men who win mineral wealth for Australia sometimes are required to pay the highest personal sacrifice. I pay tribute to these men and their families.

As we are all aware, the world is not prepared to pay Australia what it once did for our coal. In Queensland, the coal industry employs 10,000 people directly and another 32,000 indirectly. Twenty-four cents of every dollar of the Queensland Government's revenue comes from rail freight charges. I call on the Queensland Government to cut rail freight charges by $80m. This would mean a cut of 20 per cent, but only in the profit margin of the State Government rail freight charges. It would reduce rail freight charges by $1.50 per tonne. The coal industry pays the Queensland Government $778m annually in royalties, payroll tax, rail freights and port charges. The Queensland Government's high taxing policy on coal is putting jobs at risk in the coal industry. A reduction in freights would give the industry a more competitive edge in world contracts. This would safeguard the jobs of miners who share real concerns about their future.

I wish to remind the House that Australia would be in a more perilous condition if it were not for the enormous contribution being made by employees, management and farmers within my electorate. I am concerned to see Queensland reach its optimum economic potential. To do this, all sectors within my electorate will need to continue to work together. Australia cannot afford a return to the past-an era of divisiveness and confrontation. We cannot afford to allow our affairs to be entrusted to people who would rely on Australia's luck to see us through. We must be genuinely creative. The challenge we face as a nation can and will be overcome. We need only to embrace the Australian spirit in unity and with a sense of purpose to ensure that each and every Australian will control his own destiny, and retain his own dignity. Let us all, in our 200th year, look to a new horizon and ask how we can all best serve our nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Presentation of Address-in-Reply

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! His Excellency the Governor-General is absent overseas. Madam Speaker will ascertain on His Excellency's return when it would meet his convenience to receive the Address-in-Reply and will notify honourable members accordingly.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill concurrently with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill which establishes an Insurance and Superannuation Commission and introduces into legislation provisions for occupational superannuation standards. This legislation is of profound importance for the future development of superannuation in this country. Because of the significance of this legislation, the Opposition will not oppose its passage through the House. However, in saying so, I wish there to be no doubt in the eyes of the Government that we believe that this legislation essentially is an ad hoc exercise that shows little evidence of the Bills being related to the major problems facing long term retirement policy in Australia. For the benefit of honourable members it should be noted that Australia is experiencing rapid population aging. The numbers of persons aged 60 and over are expected to increase from two million in 1981 to three million in the year 2001 and five million by 2021. I cite those figures from the National Population Council report 1986. The report went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The pace of population ageing will accelerate in the next century as the baby boom generation reaches old age. The proportion of the population aged 60 years and over is expected to increase from 14 to 22 per cent between 1981 and 2021.

By 2020 men can expect to live another nineteen more years after they reach age 60 compared to another seventeen years in 1981. Women can expect to live another twenty-seven years after age 60 in 2020 compared to another twenty-two years in 1981.
The dependency burden, namely, the numbers of aged relative to the working age population, increases steadily until 2001 and rapidly from 2011 to 2021.

These statistics, while they are expectations of demographic trends, make it perfectly clear that the government and this Parliament ignore at our peril the long term aging of the Australian population. While efforts can be made through migration and so forth, the record of Western Europe and North America, which show similar trends to those of Australia, would suggest that both pre- and post-natal policies have been less than effective in making long term changes in the age structure of the population as a whole.

Because of all these factors the simple reality is that relatively fewer Australians will be expected to maintain a high level of productivity and be prepared to devote more of their taxes to social security, if it is intended that the retired people of this generation will be able to live under reasonable circumstances. About 80 per cent of older Australians receive some pension payment. By the year 2001 the rate may increase with the growth in numbers of old people; that is, people aged 75 and over. Increasing rates are not expected to create any financial crisis but income support policy for the years 2011 to 2021 may require more radical policy responses, such as raising pension ages. Private superannuation is primarily paid out in small lump sums and seldom provides long term retirement income, leaving retirees with minimum incomes insufficient for financial independence.

Coverage through industry superannuation is liable to increase the numbers in the work force who are covered by such plans. But the important thing is that despite the introduction of the 3 per cent productivity arrangement entered into by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions in 1985 the facts are that payments of pensions or lump sums at that level will achieve very little in encouraging the work force as a whole covered by those plans to have the capacity for long term protection or to give them the ability to have financial independence from the demands they may have to make on the public sector.

I am also surprised that in this legislation no attempt was made to define what superannuation is, although there was a reference to superannuation plans. For the purpose of what I have to say I would like to put on record that the Opposition defines superannuation as: a system of deferred income for genuine retirement purposes. It is designed to enable people to maintain an adequate standard of living after retirement. It should also result in decreased dependence on the social security system. We believe that ideally every income earner should have access to a superannuation scheme with appropriate tax incentives which are both effective and affordable. These are questions which will be under considerable scrutiny in the coming months.

Superannuation remains for most people an important source of domestic savings. It is estimated that approximately $100 billion is invested both in Australia and overseas. This is currently managed by superannuation funds which generate annual earnings of approximately $7.5 billion. These earnings are the basis of the independence and financial security of Australians who are planning for the future. There are approximately two million people in funded superannuation schemes. About 46 per cent of the work force are covered to some extent, of which the public sector constitutes the largest element. In fact, only about 27 per cent of non-public servants are currently covered by superannuation. In 1985-86 total contributions to superannuation funds were $9.25 billion while the total wages and salaries bill over the same period in Australia was $120 billion.

Widespread implementation of the Government's 3 per cent productivity superannuation scheme could result in an extra $3.5 billion in superannuation contributions. But it is not expected that we will see widespread implementation in the short term, nor that the total contributions-all from employers, regrettably-will have a major impact, as I said earlier, on the capacity of the beneficiaries to truly have independence at a financial level. The potential growth, however, makes it even more essential that employer-financed benefits must be able to justify their tax concessions while, at the same time, we should be making every effort possible to encourage employees to also make a direct contribution towards their superannuation.

It is a matter of great regret to the Opposition that this Labor Government, quite early in the piece, in its first year in office when it reviewed the superannuation benefits, determined to withdraw the $1,200 deduction which was currently in place at that time to encourage individuals to enter into joint schemes with employers and have access to tax deductibility as a result. The stupidity of the present system is that the individual in a joint scheme-if I may use that term-gets no tax deductions whatsoever although the employer gets 100 per cent tax deduction up to seven times final salary. On the other hand, small business people and the self-employed also are limited to deductions of only $1,500. I think it is perfectly obvious that this whole question of deductibilities in relation to superannuation is a matter which needs to be reviewed and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has already advised the House in the Budget session that that is his intention so to do.

The legislation, therefore, which we are debating tonight, contains a number of very significant elements. Firstly, for example, in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill we are told that it is the purpose of this legislation to put on record the Government's intentions in relation to superannuation standards. Unfortunately an examination of the legislation makes it more than evident that this is really not what it is all about. For example, the operating standards which are in part II of the Bill in fact contain little more than a set of statements of subject headings or intent. There is no serious attempt being made to offer to the Parliament and to the Australian people, to the insurance and superannuation industries and, above all, to the contributors of superannuation any sense of direction or philosophy which should underline what the Government really is directing its efforts at in this most crucial area of public finance.

The Bill contains only the headings under which regulations may be promulgated. Since this matter has been in gestation since 1983, and the subject of a detailed statement by the Treasurer on 11 June 1986, some 15 months ago, the Opposition is not satisfied that the Government has taken sufficient account of the need to present to the Parliament, the superannuation industry and the millions of contributors and potential contributors, an adequate statement of its philosophy or the principles which should underpin any further regulatory action. For example, part II of the Bill says in relation to vesting that the regulations may prescribe standards applicable to the vesting in members of superannuation funds of benefits arising directly or indirectly from amounts contributed to superannuation funds. This limited statement is extraordinary when compared with the Treasurer's statement of 11 June where, in attachment 1, he referred to vesting standards and the benefits which should arise from employee contributions. The most important point he made was this:
Employee contributions will vest in full in the employee from 1 July 1986.

One of the amendments we will be moving in the process of this debate is to change the dates. The dates are wrong because we are debating legislation which, in fact, was initially debated in this House prior to the last election. It could not proceed to the Senate because of the double dissolution but, clearly, the dates need to be changed. We are surprised that there does not appear to have been an effort by the Government to date to offer amendments so to do in this debate.

While the Government has chosen full rather than partial vesting as the basis of its policy, even though many employers and sections of the superannuation industry such as the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd have questioned this, surely full vesting in the employee is a principle which ought to have been expressed in the Bill. Yet there is no information whatsoever of detail in this relationship except to say that we are to look to a statement made by the Treasurer on 11 June last year. Similarly, in regard to the costs of funds management, the principle that `the level of management fees will be a matter for negotiation between trustees and fund managers'-also a statement made by the Treasurer at that time-should have been included in the Bill.

Other important principles, such as the payment of benefits on retirement at age 55 or later, while certainly not an objective supported by the Opposition, nevertheless is a principle which should be expressed in the legislation. Other standards enunciated by the Treasurer in his statement of 11 June covering issues such as preservation and portability are also of fundamental importance and should also have been identified in the Bill. For example, the composition of trustee boards is a subject of great significance to both management and contributors whose interests must be paramount.

The operating standards referred to in the Bill do not mention the Government's intention to require equal numbers of persons to be nominated by the unions and employers, nor does it stipulate that an independent trustee may be appointed. Why has this matter been ignored? I do not know. I hope the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, can tell us, but certainly no effort has been made to do so in this legislation.

The exercise of effective control over the investment policies of superannuation funds goes to the very heart of a successful national superannuation policy. Whatever formula is adopted, the objective of trustee boards and fund directors must be to ensure that the investments of superannuation funds are directed towards achieving maximum returns to members consistent with the sound management of fund assets. The need to include principles in the Bill which adequately cover investment standards should be obvious to the Government, yet it has failed so to do.

The Government's determination not to set down principles but rather to keep the industry in a state of uncertainty, especially in areas such as investment and taxation, is, in my opinion, diametrically opposed to the need to pass legislation which creates a sound basis in law upon which the industry, contributors and fund managers can make long term plans directed at ensuring that people in retirement will have a degree of financial independence and make fewer demands on social welfare. As a result of the recent Budget, the industry is now on notice that the Government is considering seriously the imposition of a differential tax on superannuation income which will distinguish income generated from investments overseas from that in Australia. Such interference in the market-place surely contravenes paragraph 17 of the Treasurer's statement of 11 June in which he said:
Investments of superannuation funds are to be directed towards achieving maximum returns to members consistent with the sound management of fund assets.

While trustees and managers are expected to keep investments at arm's length we see here the ultimate example of double standards in a government setting regulations, whether under the tax Act or under occupational superannuation standards legislation, which will effectively remove from management the right to determine where it can achieve the maximum return on the investment of contributors' funds. We all know that Australia especially now needs massive investments in our industries, much of which comes from the insurance and superannuation industries. Apart from banks they represent the largest source of capital investment in this country. One has to ask the question, therefore: Is it worth while taking the risks which the Government is doing at this stage in not being prepared to establish what I would call a level playing field which encourages managers of investment funds to be able to make what they regard as the right decisions, whether they be domestic or foreign? Is it any wonder that industry is concerned that this Government's acceptance of the 3 per cent productivity claim of the Australian Council of Trade Unions would lead to a situation where pressure would be applied on fund managers to invest only in politically acceptable industries or countries. Regrettably, this is no idle threat. Last year the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association seriously considered interfering in the investment decisions of the Commonwealth's own Superannuation Fund Investment Trust for ideological reasons. The performance of trade union funds such as the building unions superannuation scheme, better known by the acronym `BUSS', will of course be judged over time but any discussion one has with either builders or labourers leaves one firmly of the view that the manner in which this scheme was established does not give confidence about the ultimate outcome.

Funds dominated by some trade unions are seen more as an easy means for the unions to gain revenue through agency arrangements rather than as a bona fide means for providing employees with the best return on their investment. It is precisely for that reason that the Opposition parties have been concerned right from the beginning with how best we can establish a mechanism by which as many people as possible-hopefully one day all the working force-will be able to join superannuation funds. But surely the principle must be that they should be funds which people have entered voluntarily, of their free choice. Despite what the Treasurer said in his statement, workers in areas such as transportation, communications and building have no choice as to where their superannuation contributions will be placed.

One of the other issues of great concern to us in this legislation is retrospectivity. This issue was raised by none other than the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its report No. 9 of 27 May 1987. It made some observations which I would like to report. It said:

. . . clause 4 would apply the Bill, in effect, from 1 July 1986 so that superannuation funds and approved deposit funds would be required to comply with the conditions established by the Bill from that date in order to gain concessional taxation treatment.
The report then went on to say:

It appears that the basis of this retrospectivity is to be found in press releases which the Treasurer made on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986. Once again the Committee has occasion to draw to the attention of Senators the practice of the Treasurer of treating his press releases as de facto changes to the law by introducing legislation backdated to the day on which he first announced the proposal to change the law.
This is not the first time that this Senate Committee has complained about the way in which the Treasurer has responded to this Parliament. The Committee went on to say:

. . . it appears that the Treasurer found it necessary in this case to modify or add to the terms of his initial announcement so that the de facto legislation may be said to have been amended before it was introduced into the Parliament.

The Committee went on to make another statement which I would like to quote. This is of great importance not just in relation to this Bill but in relation to the growing tendency we have seen even in the context of the Australia Card, which has now died a quick death, for this Government to use regulations rather than legislation as the basis of its methodology of government-and worse than that, to prefer to use Press releases. The report stated:

The practice of `legislation by press release' carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament.
The Senate has effectively spoken on this matter. It went on to say:
. . . Ministerial press releases and when the Minister concerned issues further press releases modifying or adding to the terms of the original press release.
This should not be condoned as an alternative to logical and well thought out legislation. The report stated:

The Committee condemns in the strongest terms the practice of `legislation by press release'. When, in November 1985, the Committee requested the Treasurer's comments on the fact that, in almost four years of existence, it had never received a response to a comment made by it on a Bill for which the Treasurer had been responsible, the Treasurer responded that, due to the considerable time pressures continuously experienced by his staff and the limited number of officials engaged in the legislation area, a practice of not responding had been adopted.

What more do we need? We have the arrogance of a Treasurer who says to the Senate Committee which has the power of this Parliament to review regulations that he is not interested in the views of the Parliament; furthermore he has no intention of responding to the Committee. If that is the way we are going to proceed then clearly establishing more committees in the Parliament, or even being here, is a waste of time. If this man should have the luck one day to become Prime Minister-I am sure the Australian people will think otherwise-democracy in this nation will be reaching its nadir.

Another important amendment we will propose-I will refer to this in due course-concerns the impact of this Bill in relation to timing. The 60-day appeal procedure which is the basis of appeals under the taxation Act should be the basis of appeals under this legislation. Unfortunately, that is not the situation. This Bill proposes that the 60-day appeal period be reduced to 21 days. One of the difficulties the Government will face in the implementation of this legislation is that there are between 200,000 and 300,000 superannuation funds operating in Australia today. This Bill sets down in its so-called operating standards, the details of which we will one day know of in regulation-as I said earlier, they are not contained in the Bill-the mechanism by which this new authority will have the duty to review all of those 300,000 schemes.

Clearly, no authority can handle such a vast body of work. There are two possible alternatives. One is to allow the industry a degree of self-regulation, which is the situation that has applied in the past, and in time to review funds. That at least is a logical way of doing it. However, if the 60-day review procedure is to be cut down to 21 the problem is that if a scheme which has been in operation for three, four or five years prior to being reviewed by the agency is then found to have some element in it contrary to the operating standards the details of which we know so little about, there will be a catastrophic situation. Funds have been invested and many hundreds or thousands of people may be members of that scheme and it is just not a practical proposition so far down the road.

The way in which we believe it should be done is simply to limit the timing arrangement and to allow the authority the capacity to work more closely with funds by issuing pro forma applications. Most schemes are similar. While schemes produced by the Australian Mutual Provident Society, for example, are designed to fit in with the requirements of a specific company or industry, nevertheless there is a certain similarity about the schemes. If the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner issues to fund managers a standard form, probably two-thirds or more of existing superannuation schemes would fit within that context and therefore the administrative costs, the time delays and the risks to the investment and the fund managers would be substantially less.

I hope the Government will consider very seriously some of the proposals we are putting forward. As I said, this is extremely important legislation. It should set in place the principles of private sector as well as public sector superannuation for many years to come. One of the matters of great concern to us is simply this: whereas in the United States of America people are currently planning 50 years ahead and looking into the twenty-first century, they are not seeing a retirement age of 55 as the lotus eaters of Australia are; they are talking about a retirement age of 72. The point I made earlier is absolutely valid. Right across the Western world in the countries with the highest standards of living we are facing the fact of lower birth rates and longer life expectancy and therefore more people going into retirement.

Whilst it is easy to overplay the financial costs involved in meeting the obvious social welfare requirements, at the same time any government worth its salt has a fundamental responsibility to this and future generations of Australians to make sure that we are planning far enough ahead. That is why the Opposition simply cannot accept the basis of the 3 per cent productivity proposals which were accepted by this Government last year and put forward by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It was clearly a disguised form of wage increase, but if one sees it as the Government claims it was, as the basis for a universal system of superannuation, I regret to say that it is a failure. It is a failure for a number of reasons, principally because 3 per cent will bring one virtually nothing and certainly not enough money to make it worth while. A viable scheme requires a contribution by employer and/or employee of about 9 per cent for a worker on average weekly earnings (AWE), $438 a week, entering the scheme at age 25, to generate an indexed pension of 55 per cent of AWE by the age of 65, and 10 years certain after that, with an assumed real rate of interest of 3 per cent compound per annum. An assumed real interest rate of 2 per cent would require a contribution of about 13 per cent of total salary. This illustrates the fact that the 3 per cent productivity decision is the absolute minimum, and if a fund achieves real earnings of, say, 2 per cent per annum it would take an AWE employee 30 years to achieve a payment of $20,000 at age 60. That would buy an indexed annuity of about $18 to $19 a week. Clearly this is well below the $50 a week income currently allowed before the pension is reduced.

While it is clear that the Government entered into these very important superannuation policy initiatives, forced to the barricades to a large degree by pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, it is a matter of great regret that we now have in place a situation where many thousands of Australians are being encouraged to go into schemes which are worth only 3 per cent of their total salary, funded entirely by employers. While these schemes claim that employees are also encouraged to make a contribution, the regrettable fact is that there is a growing tendency in this country to imagine that costs of that nature have to be borne by the Government, by the employer or by somebody else, but not the employee. Having said that, I note that there is also a growing tendency in the upper end of the wage market for terms and conditions of employment packages to include schemes based absolutely on employer contributions. We believe it is desirable to have a system into which employers and employees contribute to these schemes. That is the best way of ensuring that a sufficient fund will be built up to enable employees to see their later independence as a reality-something which will never be achieved on the basis of a 3 per cent contribution. As a result of these problems, the Opposition therefore moves:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for the operating standards to be incorporated in the Bill or in a separate Act so as to protect the rights of employees to determine whether they should join union superannuation funds or other funds of their choice'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, the amendment is seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be a wonderful experience to go from government to opposition because it seems now that, along with a lot of other matters, the Opposition has finally discovered superannuation. Members of the Opposition are experts when they are over there on the Opposition benches, but when they are on the Government side they do absolutely nothing. When we look at superannuation in Australia and follow the history and evolution of the system we have now, we should note that for the majority of the time the Liberal Party has been in power, and it has done absolutely nothing. The evolution of our present retirement scheme began in 1951 when we had the National Welfare Fund. That was the embryo, at least, of a national superannuation scheme. I go back to 1983 and remind the House of the superannuation and retirement scheme that we inherited from the present Opposition, which has finally discovered superannuation. Not only has it discovered it; it could also give us a definition of it.
—It is a pity you could not give us one.

—It was a very good definition, too. When we came into power in 1983, a number of schemes were in operation. Later I will go through the statistics of how the schemes broke down, and I will accept many of the statistics used by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). Certainly the majority of people in Australia did not do anything about providing for their own retirement. Even though previous Liberal governments had talked about the freedom of choice of Australians to do so, the fact is that hardly anyone did anything. Only about 40 per cent of the Australian population had access to superannuation schemes and, of the other 60 per cent who were supposed to provide for their own retirement, about 95 per cent of that group did absolutely nothing and now draw the old age pension. This was the situation when those people who actually went into a superannuation scheme finally retired.

SPEECH.PARA: A superannuation scheme, as the honourable member for Bradfield pointed out, should involve income that is deferred so that a person can take it when he retires, on a regular basis. But what was happening was that people were taking their superannuation in a lump sum. Having received taxation advantages for those contributions during their working life, they then took their superannuation in a lump sum and paid virtually no tax on it. They would spend that sum sometimes on holidays, sometimes on holiday houses or sometimes on second cars-which by themselves are worthy things, and I do not doubt that the people earned such rewards, but that was not what superannuation schemes were all about. Superannuation schemes were designed to allow people to take their deferred income on a regular basis. People were taking their lump sum but were paying virtually no tax on it and were then going on to the old age pension. They were double dipping. As we call it. So they received a taxation concession through their working lives for investing in superannuation schemes, took the money as a lump sum, receiving another taxation concession, and then went on to the old age pension.

As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, when we became the Government we ended that by putting a tax on lump sums and so gave people the incentive to roll those funds over and take their income on a regular basis over time. To shore up the system somewhat more, we brought in an assets test. Both of those measures were opposed by those opposite; in fact, they campaigned very heavily against us, with some effect, during the 1984 election campaign. However, they were necessary measures. They were hard things to do but we had to do them to shore up the superannuation scheme. The ludicrous situation was that once somebody had taken his lump sum and either spent it or, if he went the other road, invested it in a non-interest bearing scheme, he could still draw the old age pension. In fact, many of the pensioner newspapers ran full page advertisements inviting pensioners to do just that. This Government ended that, just about from day one.

A most distressing part of the scheme operating under the previous Government was that it was used for tax avoidance. I refer to what are now called cherry picker schemes, where employers actually used superannuation schemes to avoid paying tax. Not only that but, at the same time, they used these schemes to cheat their employees out of entitlements. I acknowledge that the honourable member for Bradfield agrees with me. That was a distressing part of the superannuation scheme that we inherited. It does not happen nowadays, due to the measures of this Government.

I move on now to some projections. Certainly the honourable member for Bradfield talked about projections. I would like to illustrate to the House some of the pitfalls in making projections about where we should be in the future. I agree with his assertion that we need to make those predictions. I looked at a speech made by a Treasurer Casey back in 1938. He made some projections and, with hindsight, we can look at how accurate they were. Back in 1938, Treasurer Casey projected 40 years ahead. He said there would be 1.28 million pensioners, and, in actual fact, in 1978 there were 1.38 million pensioners. So he was pretty close; it was an error of only 2 per cent. At the time he also predicted that actual cost of those pensioners to Budget revenue. In 1978 dollars, his 1938 prediction was that they would cost the Commonwealth $478m. In actual fact, they cost $3,229m-an error of 680 per cent. That just shows, if this is any example to go by, that making accurate projections is very hard indeed.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about the predictions by Treasurer Casey in 1938 and drawing the attention of the House to the inaccuracy of those predictions, certainly in terms of the projections on the outlays of funding the pension system. As I said, in 1938 Treasurer Casey predicted a cost in 1978 of $478m. In actual fact it was $3,229m, an error of 680 per cent. I think also an Australian study of 583 private businesses and their superannuation funds causes some concern when we look at the participation rate. We see that 56 per cent of men and only 22 per cent of women represent the distribution of people who actually took part in superannuation schemes. Ninety-one per cent of executives participated in a superannuation scheme and 72 per cent of salaried people within those firms participated in superannuation schemes. But then there is a dramatic drop in that workers in schemes accounted for only 32 per cent of the distribution. Certainly, in Australia as a whole only 40 per cent of Australians had access to schemes and, of the 60 per cent who did not have access, about 95 per cent are now on the old age pension. The honourable member for Bradfield also talked about the predictions of the aging of the Australian population. I agree with him; it is a problem which really needs addressing. Even though he made the point that 3 per cent was not a lot, at least it is a start.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before us today deal with the standards to be included in the regulations under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. Let me just refer briefly to a few of them. Certainly one of the great benefits of this Bill will be the portability of superannuation benefits. The standards announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) provide for benefits to be transferred from a superannuation fund that a member is leaving to one that he or she is joining. I know that that has been one of the obstacles to the present scheme: if one leaves a job and one enters an industry superannuation scheme one tends to lose the benefits and it is not an ongoing scheme. The portability of benefits under the superannuation scheme will be of great benefit.

In addition, the membership of the trustee boards will make great advances as a result of this Bill. All superannuation funds established after 16 December 1985 are required to have equal participation of representatives of employers and employees on their trustee boards to encourage increased member participation in the management of superannuation funds. I refer to the infamous cherrypicker schemes whereby superannuation concessions were used to further tax avoidance schemes. That could not have happened had we had the participation of employees on those boards.

There are other benefits in the Bill: minimum vesting standards, minimum preservation standards, the security of benefits standards. I have already mentioned the membership of the trustee boards. I turn to the reporting requirements. The Government will require superannuation funds to provide to members information on matters affecting their entitlements, including details of benefits for new members and the effects of any change to trust deeds on members' entitlements and the net earnings of the funds on the members' and the employers' contributions.

I turn now to basic superannuation fund conditions. The superannuation funds will have to continue to satisfy a number of conditions to qualify for tax concessions. These conditions include: the fund has been established for the sole purpose of providing superannuation benefits to members on retirement or to dependants of members. I take the point made by the honourable member for Bradfield in his contribution tonight, and I certainly agree with the way in which he expressed his belief in superannuation. It certainly fits in with that.

The level of benefits provided by a superannuation fund must be reasonable; that is, the level of benefits must not exceed the maximum levels in relation to final average salary currently set by the Commissioner of Taxation. We are saying there that they must be realistic; we do not want these superannuation funds being turned into vehicles for deferred pay to be taken later on. The other provision is that under the basic superannuation fund conditions the fund must be indefinitely continuing.

I will not take any more time of the House. I know that we have a long way to go in the superannuation Bills which are before the House tonight, but every step we take along that track can only lead to Australia having a better retirement system than the one we currently have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Superannuation, the subject of this legislation, is an issue that is of very great importance to the people of Australia. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) had a good deal to say about the inaccuracies of long term projections. Certainly, more in the way of planning and long term thought is needed in this matter than is evidenced in this makeshift legislation. Whatever estimates we come up with, the indications from demographic studies are very clear: as we move into the first decades of the twenty-first century we will have a very large retirement population. Detailed projections were set out by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly).

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of providing retirement income is not one which can or should be met from public funds-that is, taxation. Since there is a very long planning, implementation and build-up period involved, in the order of 30 years, the issue of an adequate superannuation policy is a quite central issue of policy. Yet the Government has not addressed it. It certainly does not do so in this makeshift legislation, specifically the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. The Government is here reacting and moving to catch up with events. It is not initiating; it is not putting down some well thought out, long range policy and action. The legislation provides that the really critical matters-the actual standards for the superannuation funds-be laid down by regulation.

Clearly, the Government does not know where it is going. Over the last 18 months we have had policy by Press release, something we have become accustomed to from this Government, with the Government driven to action by the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the rulings of a compliant Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Indeed, the history of this matter stems from Australian Labor Party Government-ACTU action-all along we have had an Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions government-dating back to September 1985.

This was recounted by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) back in June and I will summarise his account. On 4 September 1985 the Government came to an agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the context of the Accord Mark 2. Under this agreement the unions were to obtain for their members, through the conciliation and arbitration system, in effect a 3 per cent disguised wage increase, called a productivity increase, in the form of superannuation contributions by employers on behalf of employees. That deal was arrived at between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the ACTU to disguise a wage increase which was over and above what was economically justified. It was very necessary for the Treasurer to present a facade to the Australian business and financial community to try to suggest that the wage increase that was being granted, which was clearly in advance of what ought to be granted, somehow was not a wage increase at all. It was called a productivity increase, and it was to be paid in the form of superannuation. It was `superannuation based on productivity'. Could one get a more sensible or benign idea? Expressed in that sort of motherhood term, everyone would agree with it.

On 16 December that year, before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had made any decision, the Government published some guidelines and draft operating standards for occupational superannuation funds. Then on 11 June 1986 the Government published more comprehensive standards for these funds-again, by way of Press release. This was done as a matter of urgency to meet the requirements of the Australian Taxation Office so that the funds would enjoy the tax concessions that were available to superannuation funds. Towards the end of June, after the standards had been issued, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission brought down its rather ambiguous decision on the 3 per cent claim. It was not prepared to agree that everybody should get it, but it would confirm consent agreements between employers and unions. That, of course, meant a field day for the more powerful unions, which went about the business of forcing employers to put money into union-controlled superannuation funds. On 30 June 1986--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you name one employer that was coerced or forced?
—We will come to that.
—The BUS scheme.
—Which employer?

—Large building industry employers generally, which brought in the BUS scheme-the building unions superannuation scheme-to which my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield, by way of interjection to the Minister, has referred.
—You don't know what the BUS scheme is. You are relying on him.

—No, there is no problem about that. On 30 June 1986 the Government, which was clearly concerned by the Commission's absolute refusal to toe that line, issued a further statement promising consultation with the industry. On 10 March 1987 the Arbitration Commission, in the context of the unions pressing these claims, modified its decision and said that, rather than relying on consent arrangements, it would arbitrate in particular disputes. Therefore, it put itself in the position to impose this so-called productivity increase on the whole work force. That is the history of the matter. It started with a fraudulent deal between the Treasurer and the ACTU in order to disguise a wage increase. It has led to the Government trying hard to catch up, all along the line, with what the Arbitration Commission was deciding and what the unions were pushing for in the field.

SPEECH.PARA: The standards set out in that Press release have been operative since 1 July 1986. We now have some legislation, but we still do not have the definitive standards. This legislation makes provision for regulations specifying the real operating standards to be made. This Bill sets up a framework for regulations. One would think that the Government might have been warned by the recent ID card experience! The Bill sets up this framework for the subsequent provision of actual regulations. There is still no thoughtout, long term policy. The Government, in its defence, talks about flexibility, keeping it all flexible. In place of that, one can read that it will proceed cautiously by regulation from time to time, lest it tread on the toes of some of its union mates! That is what it amounts to.

The Opposition has expressed reservations about aspects of these standards. Those reservations have been set out by the honourable member for Bradfield. One point in particular is the preservation of benefits only to age 55, not to, say, age 65. In the United States at the moment there is talk of the age of 72. We are not opposing such aspects of the Bill. But the honourable member for Bradfield has moved, by way of an amendment to the motion for the second reading, that the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted so as to incorporate the actual operating standards which are required. I believe that that is the only proper course. However, failing that, we will move some 13 amendments. The first is to clause 3. At the end of the definition of `superannuation fund', we want to add the following words:
``, but does not include:
(c) a fund established as a result of an employer or employers being threatened, intimidated or coerced by a trade union or trade unions.''.

In effect, this amendment states that if the superannuation funds are to enjoy the taxation concessions that are available, we would want to be certain that the funds are not set up as a result of coercion. Everybody knows-whatever the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding) says-that there has been coercion, that people in the building industry, to which I have referred, have been bludgeoned, on building sites and elsewhere, into becoming members of these funds. Sub-contractors have been forced into these funds with employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Small business suffers.
—We've had that experience in Wakefield.
—Yes. Many have had experience of that, as my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield says. Membership of the superannuation fund, along with the union card, becomes a ticket for the job.
—What's worse, you can't get the job without it.
—That is exactly what I mean: one cannot get the job without it, as my colleague says.
—No freedom to work.

—Order! If the honourable member for Higgins would go to his correct seat, he might interject from there, even though that would also be out of order. He has managed to do that on a number of occasions today.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate my colleagues' support.
—You may appreciate it, but the Chair does not.

—We will see how we go. The regulations that are built into the provision that the Opposition is trying to insert amount to an elementary matter of civil liberties and rights. Indeed, it is linked to our approach to industrial relations, and, as my colleague the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has said, to non-compulsory unionism.
—Freedom of the individual.
—Yes, the freedom of the individual.
—If the honourable member for Higgins interjects again, I will deal with him.

—Funds such as the building unions superannuation scheme, the BUS scheme, to which my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield referred a moment ago, which have been set up-despite what the Minister says-as a result of coercion of employers by unions, would have to be examined very closely and would be excluded from the taxation concessions if it were found that they were set up as a result of coercion.

SPEECH.PARA: Another key amendment, to be moved by the honourable member for Bradfield, is amendment No. 9 to clause 7 (2), on page 6 of the Bill. After paragraph (j) we propose that the following paragraph be inserted:
``(ja) the levels of administrative fees, commissions or other deductions which may be payable from amounts contributed to superannuation funds;''.

That is the matter that we propose should be added to the list of matters about which a regulation prescribing actual standards should be introduced. The purpose of regulations made under that proposed sub-clause would be to control the `creaming off' of money paid into funds by unions and used for their own purposes, instead of being used to meet genuine costs of administering fund managers. It is common knowledge that the ACTU was privy to an understanding that anything from 30c to $1 a week from the proposed employer contribution should be received by the union. The official leaflet of the Allied Unions Superannuation Trust states that $1 is to be put aside each week for administration. I suggest that the House should think of what that would involve. It is anticipated that at least three million Australian employees become members, coerced or otherwise, of superannuation funds. At $1 a week, $50 a year, for three million employees that is about $150m per annum. At all events, the excess, above a reasonable administrative cost, may be $100m. That is a very large sum to be creamed off in this way. If employers are obliged to provide this money for retirement benefits for employees, the employees should be getting the money in the form of benefits. Of course, over time, nobody anticipates that the superannuation contribution will stay at 3 per cent. There is no way that a contribution of 3 per cent, even over 30 years or more, will provide a reasonable superannuation retirement income.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should go up.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Sturt says, it should go up. In 1973, when the Public Service scheme was before the Parliament, I discussed in this House what its true cost was and what its impact would be on the private sector. I suggested that to fund an adequate indexed retirement income would cost of the order of 15 or 20 per cent and upwards of income. That is what will be pressed for under these arrangements. The contribution may be 3 per cent now but increasingly larger amounts will be sought. If the charge about which we spoke a moment ago were to go up in proportion to the quantum of money to be administered, invested and so on, we would be looking at a siphoning off of the order of $750m.
—They would all have beach houses.

—I am not as worried about that as I am about the fact that the ACTU-Australian Labor Party political machine would probably be the best funded political machine anywhere in the world. That is what concerns me much more. Australians generally need to be wide awake to this and to just who may be able, and how, to control their lives. Let us have no argument as to the importance of introducing this amendment that there be regulations as to adequate standards of control in this area of administrative fees. What I have just said is quite apart from the loss of end benefit to members, who are supposed to be the beneficiaries of the schemes. This `bleeding off' has the effect of reducing the end benefit to members.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I suggest that what needs to be reflected upon is the vast magnitude of the funds that will accrue to unions via such unions controlled investment funds. Even at 3 per cent-that is just the start; I have referred to 15 per cent or more-with the aggregate of wages in this country of about $130 billion, there could be $2 billion to $3 billion a year available for investment. As the percentage rises higher than that, the sums would be huge. It is not a case of union bashing to express disquiet at this. Union controlled superannuation funds could accumulate enough funds to buy control of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd every year. So there is a potential, if the funds are not properly set up and properly controlled, for an exercise of enormous leverage. That is why the issue of these standards is such an important one. That is why this makeshift legislation, which still does not spell them out definitively, is also inadequate. I commend and support the second reading amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. In doing so, I note that these are identical Bills to those which were debated in this place in June-only two or three months ago-prior to the dissolution of the Parliament for the election on 11 July. So we have already had considerable debate on these Bills. They have already been passed by this House. Following their passage tonight they will go to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills give effect to various standards for the superannuation industry and they are basically the standards which have been outlined previously by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Press releases during 1986-on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December. The Bills follow extensive consultation with and advice from groups which include the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia. The Government also took into account the views expressed in the final report of the task force on occupational superannuation which was tabled in this House in early 1983. Consultation is an important aspect of the process which this Government has undertaken in many of its major economic reforms and consultation will continue, of course, with key groups during the process of the drafting of the detailed regulations which will give effect to the legislation.

These are important Bills because they deal with superannuation. I cannot think of a more important subject which this House could be discussing in the context of economic and social policy than superannuation. The decision which was taken by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to ensure that all Australian workers had the opportunity to be part of a superannuation scheme, I think, was an imaginative and historic decision, because there is an enormous need to improve and expand the scope of superannuation coverage in Australia. There are many good reasons for that. If one looks at the extent to which Commonwealth taxpayers fund age pensions in Australia at the moment, one sees that it is undoubtedly a growth area of government outlays. In 1981-82 the taxpayer, through the Federal Budget, paid out some $4 1/2 billion in age pensions. By last year the figures had increased to $6.2 billion. In the 1987-88 Budget almost $7 billion will be spent providing age pensions to retired Australians. In that context, 30 per cent of the Government's total social security outlays, which now total more than $20 billion, are paid in the form of age pensions.

There is a second and important reason why superannuation coverage is essential to the social and economic advancement of this country. Currently we have around two million elderly and retired Australians. It is estimated that by 2001 the number of elderly and retired Australians will have increased to 2.6 million. An analysis of the work force shows that, by 2001, for each retired person there will be three or four people in the work force. Some population projections suggest that by midway through the twenty-first century the ratio of dependent elderly to those in the work force might be closer to 2:1. So clearly there is a need to provide encouragement and support for occupational superannuation. The Gruen report-the report of the Panel of Review of Proposed Income and Assets Test which was commissioned by this Government to look at the assets test primarily-also indicated that, on its calculations, over the next few decades the growth rate of elderly people in our population would be at 1.8 per cent per annum compared with a growth rate of a population in general of 1.1 per cent per annum. An overall retirement income policy is essential. Clearly, occupational superannuation is a very important part of an overall retirement income policy.

There are many benefits of superannuation to individuals and to the nation. One of the major benefits is that superannuation provides a private provision of retirement income. Another benefit of superannuation is that it will, over time, reduce a retiree's dependence on transfer payments from social security and, therefore, reduce the overall level of public expenditure. There is a third argument, a very good economic argument, that increased superannuation will lead to an increased flow of savings and hence investment in the economy. In a nation like ours, which traditionally has had high levels of consumption expenditure and a level of savings and investment which are too low to maintain our competitiveness as a nation, any measure which attracts savings and therefore investment will enhance our capacity to improve the competitiveness of our nation and our economy, and that is a good thing. There is a final reason why superannuation is important, and that is that it brings a planned approach to the crucial matter of social policy. In this context of occupational superannuation, it is worth noting that, at the moment, almost half the work force has no form of superannuation cover, so any scheme which can broaden the coverage of superannuation is something which is of benefit to people in the work force.

There are three Bills before the House, but the most important puts effect to standards which will be included in regulations governing occupational superannuation schemes. Most of those standards are already being applied in accordance with the Treasurer's statements released during 1986, and they provide for a wide range of standards covering the operational aspects of schemes. They include, for instance, things like minimum vesting standards, and these standards require employers to distribute benefits more evenly among employees, allowing employees who resign before retirement age to receive a larger share of benefit than they have previously. There are standards relating to preservation. These standards are designed to improve the level of benefits available to members of superannuation schemes at retirement, by requiring benefit to be retained in a superannuation fund or an approved deposit fund until the member retires.

The standards also relate to a third important matter, and that is the portability of benefits. These standards provide for benefits to be transferred from a superannuation fund that a member is leaving to one that he or she is joining or to an approved deposit fund or deferred annuity fund. The fourth standard relates to the security of benefit. In this respect, the Government has announced several measures which will improve the security of members' benefits. New superannuation funds established after 16 December 1985 are not allowed to provide loans to members, as the provision of loans to members would be inconsistent with the preservation of benefits to retirement. The fifth standard relates to the membership of trustee boards. All superannuation funds established after 16 December 1985 are required to have equal participation of representatives of employers and employees on their trustee boards to encourage increased participation in the management of superannuation funds.

There are two further standards which are incorporated in this legislation. They relate to reporting requirements and to basic superannuation fund conditions. In respect of that final matter, the funds will obviously have to satisfy a number of conditions to qualify for tax concessions. Those conditions include that the fund is being established for the sole purpose of providing superannuation benefits to members on retirement or to dependants of members, that the level of benefits provided by the superannuation fund must be reasonable, and that the fund must be indefinitely continuing. They are very important standards, in which, in consultation with the industry, the Government is putting into detailed regulations, and they will govern the operation of occupational superannuation funds in the future. I welcome those standards, which make an important contribution to the quality of superannuation which is available in Australia.

Some of those issues-vesting, preservation and portability-will become increasingly important to all Australians as the quality and type of our working life changes considerably in the future. It could be said that, a century ago, even decades ago, the traditional work pattern of a typical Australian was such that one could expect to be employed in a job of one type for most of one's working life of 30 or 40 years. Technological change was much slower and the opportunities and necessity for people to change from one job to another were far fewer. There is no doubt now that with the trends emerging in Australian society, and which are clearly evident overseas in some of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, of rapidly changing technology and changing social and economic patterns, the old fashioned view that one could start a job early in life at 18 or 20 and keep that job through one's working life until retirement age at 60 or 65 is no longer relevant. Indeed, the changing educational, technological and training patterns in the future will mean that everyone in the work force will need to be much more flexible in his working arrangement. He will need to prepare for regular retraining during his working life and will need to be aware that it will be virtually impossible to maintain and keep the same job from youth to retirement.

All of that is very relevant to superannuation, because if we want Australians to contribute more to their retirement income, then it is essential, if people are going to change jobs and move in and out of training and retraining programs more frequently and with more flexibility, to recognise that issues like vesting, portability and preservation are crucial to the flexibility and efficiency of an economy, particularly one that is becoming increasingly deregulated. If we want to pay attention to issues like international competitiveness, a highly educated and mobile work force and improvements in productivity, it will be necessary to have training and retaining programs with flexibility in working patterns and therefore to have increasing flexibility in the standards that apply to occupational superannuation funds. Basically, that is what these standards put effect to.

The Opposition has preshadowed a number of amendments in this debate. The previous speaker in this debate, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), paid particular attention to two of those amendments. One was the proposed Opposition amendment to clause 3 which was to amend or alter the definition of a superannuation fund. I know that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) will make some comment about this later, but there is a real problem with that amendment because it simply will not be possible for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner objectively to determine that a fund has been established as a result of threats or coercion from trade unions, as the Opposition is suggesting.

It is relevant to say in that respect that, in its decision in June 1986, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission agreed to ratify agreements for new or improved superannuation benefits provided that the consent of employees was genuine. Subsequently, the Commission indicated, in its decision of 10 March 1987, that this approach had led to an unacceptable level of industrial disputation in respect of superannuation. Therefore, in its more recent decision of 10 March 1987, the Commission agreed to arbitrate on superannuation claims in instances where negotiation and conciliation had failed to produce agreement between employers and employees.

We can say that, as a result of that decision, the level of industrial disputations relating to superannuation should be substantially reduced and that, if new or improved superannuation benefits result from an award made by the Commission, the question of a superannuation fund paying the benefits being established as a result of threats or coercion from the unions should not arise. I think that that is a fairly sound response to the Opposition's amendment, which is based on its usual paranoia about the union movement. If there were any contracts which were made between a union and an employer in which duress had been involved, which is the imputation of the amendment, then that would be void under law, so there is another argument saying that that amendment is redundant.

The other amendment on which the honourable member for Berowra commented is that to clause 7 of the Bill to provide for the prescription of fees, commissions, et cetera which would be payable by funds. My response to that is that the Government's announced operating standards already contain a number of provisions which will make superannuation fund trustees more accountable to members. These provisions include a requirement that large superannuation funds established after 16 December 1985 and with more than 200 members must have equal representation of employers and employees on their trustee boards. I could respond in greater detail to that, but the fact that both employers and employees are reflected equally in the composition of the board is surely a sound response to the proposal which was put in that amendment.

The Treasurer in the previous Liberal-National Government, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), looked at the concept of a national superannuation scheme and decided not to introduce one. In his Press release in July 1979, saying why the then Liberal-National Government would not expand national superannuation, the then Treasurer made two points:

First, the Government is concerned at recent attempts by trade unions to obtain employer contributions to superannuation schemes as a means of circumventing wage indexation guidelines. These claims, if successful, would add significantly to labour costs and would thus have implications for unemployment and inflation . . .

Second, the Government is concerned to ensure that union activities in the superannuation area are directed towards meeting the genuine retirement needs of members and are subject to the same rules and standards as those expected of others involved in the area. In this respect the Government makes no distinction between those parties or organisations currently involved, or who would seek to become involved, in superannuation activities.

Both of the concerns expressed by the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, in 1979, are more than met and more than adequately responded to by the existing program which is in place for the expansion of occupational superannuation. When the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission agreed in the wage case that a 3 per cent wage equivalent could be paid in superannuation-as it was then-it was doing so in an environment in which real labour unit costs had declined significantly under the policies of this Government. When we came to office, real labour unit costs on an indexed basis in late 1982 stood at 108. By 1985, the index of real labour unit costs had moved down to 97.5. So the professed concern that the Liberal and National parties had then and still have about superannuation adding to costs and reducing national economic productivity and competitiveness is simply not substantiated if we look at what has happened to real labour unit costs under this Government.

This Government has been genuinely successful in ensuring a macroeconomic environment, including wages policy, which has ensured a downward trend in real labour unit costs. It has ensured that as a nation we are now more competitive than at any time in the last 20 years. When we look at last week's Federal Budget, which provides for a Budget deficit of only $27m, it is clear that the continuing trend towards improved international competitiveness and productivity growth will continue.

I conclude by saying that the growth of superannuation is essential for proper social and economic development. At the moment, too few Australians have the opportunity of participating in superannuation schemes. Steps taken by this Government will ensure that many more men and women, particularly low income earners, will have the opportunity of participating in superannuation. It will ensure that the nation's stock of savings increases, that more fund is available for investment in productive enterprises in Australia and that along the road in 20, 30 or 40 years the drain on the public purse for age pensions in the year 2010 or 2040 will be reduced significantly. I stongly support these Bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill before the House tonight have been here before-some three months ago. It is a mark of the Government's incompetence that they are here in the same form that they were here last time, because they were inadequate then and they are inadequate now.
—They are worse now.

—They are worse now because the Government has had another three months to do something and has done nothing. The Bills are a mark of the Government's incompetence and an indictment of its failure to care about the retirement of Australians. What we are really talking about is a very important concept to all Australians; that is, their retirement income and security and how they plan for that retirement during their working lives. It takes probably 30 to 35 years to plan adequately to provide for a standard of living during retirement. The big problem that we on this side of the House have with this legislation-and we have many problems with it-is that it indicates that the Government has no retirement income policy. The whole structure of superannuation in Australia since June 1986 has been based on a Press release referred to by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) as a statement--
—Three Press releases.
—He says, `Three Press releases'-hallelujah!
—Government by three Press releases.

—It is government by three Press releases. I am prepared to give credit to three Press releases; three Press releases are better than one, I guess, but not necessarily any better, because it certainly does not provide any surety for people planning their retirement that anything that they believe will operate at the present time will hold into the future.
