Of course, that is really what we are talking about tonight-whether people should be prepared to go ahead and plan for retirement over a long term with the possibility that they can have the rug pulled from underneath them by changes to regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major problems with this legislation is that the operating standards for superannuation funds and approved deposit funds are not specified in the legislation. Nor are they specified in the Press release. The excuse given by the former Minister responsible in this area was that a committee was still working on it. That was three months ago and I presume that the committee is still working. The committee has been working since June 1986 and I am told that in that time 300,000 superannuation plans have been established. That involves at least 300,000 Australians. I notice that the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, raises his eyebrows. There are probably in the order of one million or two million Australians involved because many of those funds would have more than one member. In the words of the honourable member for Bendigo, a couple of million Australians are planning for their retirement and putting in substantial amounts of money weekly or fortnightly on the basis of three Press releases.

The Government introduces the legislation in this place and says, `Let us pass it and send it up to the Senate and at some time in the future we will bring in some regulations and tell people what the operating standards for superannuation funds and approved deposit funds will be'. In the meantime, a couple of million Australians are putting all this money aside on the basis that it will be available to them in 30 years time to provide some sort of security for their retirement. It is not good enough.

Regulations are quite topical at the present time. I do not need to remind the House about the problems that can arise if people rely on regulations. We have seen today with the Australia Card Bill that the Government was not really aware of what could happen to regulations in the Senate. I am not suggesting that anyone on our side of the Parliament is opposed to superannuation, but if those opposite cannot plan to implement their identity card legislation because they cannot guarantee that the regulations will go through the Senate how dare they ask a couple of million Australians to put money away on a weekly basis on the strength of regulations that no one has yet seen going through the Senate or this House?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is government by Press release.

—Yes, and it is government by fiat and government by whim. People are planning over 30 years for their retirement and it takes a month to change regulations in this place. That is not the way to run a retirement income policy. What it really comes down to--
—You are a hypocrite.

—I would have a different attitude if the honourable member could provide us with some indication of what the regulations would look like. If those opposite could do that they could put them into the legislation. But if they are going to ask people to assign a trustee, to make contributions and to commit themselves to a superannuation fund, the very least they can do is put those operating standards into the legislation.
—Why didn't you do it?

—Because those opposite have the numbers. They are the ones who have been running around with Simon Crean and the Australian Council of Trade Unions stitching up a deal for 3 per cent on productivity or whatever because the Government is over a political barrel and Simon Crean and Bill Kelty said, `Do this deal or you have a problem; this is the pay off'. The reality is that those opposite did the political deal before they knew how they would run these funds-300,000 funds and millions and millions of dollars. How much money is in approved deposit funds at the present time? Yet we do not know what the operating standards are. They are very important for those Australians who are putting aside $10, $20 or $30 on a daily basis for their superannuation. The Government determines who will be running those superannuation funds, what those funds can invest in, what information people are going to get about their investments and what is going to happen with their money.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has not told them. It brought this Bill into the House for the second time. The first time was three months ago. It comes back three months later and it is still no different. The Government has still done no work. It has been sitting on its hands not only for the past three months, but since June 1986. It is about time that everyone out there in a recently established superannuation fund knew exactly of the incompetence and inactivity of this Government. It has not got a feather to fly with. It does not care about superannuation for Australian workers; all it cares about is the superannuation deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to keep Simon Crean and Bill Kelty happy and to provide ongoing administration charges so that the ACTU can finance its activities notwithstanding its ever declining membership base. Because it is not getting enough money out of its membership subscriptions it needs to look at additional sources of income. The additional sources of income have got to be the ultimate cash flow; that is, an administration charge straight off the top of the average worker's contribution to his retirement income. That is what this Government has done. Not only has the Government done that, but it has also not told the average Australian worker.

I wonder whether the honourable member for Bendigo is prepared to go out on to the shop floor of his electorate and tell some of this voters, his constituents, that he is supporting a Bill on the basis that they are investing for their future and there is no specificity on how that fund will, in fact, operate. I wonder whether the honourable member is prepared to do that. Is he prepared to go home, walk on to the average shop floor and talk about the lack of operating standards for superannuation funds? Would he invest his money in any sort of proposition where he did not know how it was going to be run? I would not and I do not think it is reasonable to ask the average Australian worker to do that. But that is what this Government is prepared to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Superannuation is all right for you but not the average worker!

—Here is the man who is talking about the average worker. If he had any commitment to the average worker he would not be supporting this Bill. He would abstain if he was not prepared to show some principle and vote with us. All we are saying is, `Don't do anything until you have laid down in black and white how these superannuation funds are going to work'. There is absolutely no guarantee that at some time in the future the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not have a rush of blood to the head or maybe a bit of coercion from one of his mates in the trade union movement. If the honourable member does not think the ACTU has influence, just remember what happened to the National Taxation Summit. While the Treasurer was wandering around this place trying to get option C up, I think the ACTU and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a few other factional leaders were off in a smoke filled motel room on the other side of town stitching together what the ALP's tax policy was. When are we going to see the same sort of collusion between the Australian Labor Party and some faction and the ACTU on superannuation funds? That is exactly what this Bill leaves the average Australian worker open to-some sort of back room deal on how superannuation in Australia will be run. It is just not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: America plans retirement income 50 years in advance. In Australia at present we are planning retirement income 18 months and more in arrears. People have been putting their money aside for their retirement for 18 months on the basis of the Treasurer's three Press releases-government by Press release-and this Government still does not know how it is going to run it. I have never come across a government with a hide like that. The honourable member for Bendigo talks about no action. Let me tell him that no action is not as bad as action that does not indicate to people where they are going. In Paul Keating's Australia it is hard to earn a dollar. Those people who are putting money into superannuation are putting it in after they have worked long and hard. They would be probably be thankful if they could have it in their pocket on a weekly basis after paying the Treasurer's taxes, after the Treasurer has increased government revenue over 75 per cent in five years and they are making their fortnightly contribution to superannuation. But they do not know how their funds are going to be operated.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't think they should have a right to say how it is administered.
—The Minister is interjecting that I do not think they should have a right to say how it is administered.
—But do you think they should?

—I am quite happy for the trustees of a superannuation fund to represent the people who are making the contributions. I have no argument with that at all provided those trustees know exactly what their obligations are. The Minister perhaps should give some thought-I presume he knows something about the law-to the obligations of trustees. They are to maximise the benefits flowing to the people on behalf of whom they operate.
—Some of your mates in Executor Trustee and Agency.

—That is right; we all know about that. Let us talk about another very celebrated case in Victoria involving superannuation and trustees. I think one Mr Landeryou went to an auction to buy a beach house for his wife and paid for it with a cheque on a trade union superannuation fund. Was he exercising his responsibilities as a trustee? Was he maximising the returns to the contributors to those funds?
—Order! I ask the honourable member who has the call to direct his remarks through the Chair, and I ask both him and the Minister to stop swapping comments across the House.
—With respect, Madam Deputy Speaker, I suggest that you should have suggested to the Minister that he cease interjecting.
—Order! The honourable member for Richmond has the call for debating and not for making suggestions as to how the Chair should operate.

—I am sorry, Madam Deputy Speaker. There are Standing Orders, of which I am sure you are very familiar. You are aware, as you have just said to me, that being the member with the call I have a right to speak without interruption. Now your responsibility in the chair is to enforce those Standing Orders.
—I call on the honourable member for Richmond to continue with the debate, and I assume that he is not reflecting on the Chair.

—No, I am not reflecting on the Chair. I am simply making reference to the Standing Orders and to the obligation of the person presently in the chair. The Minister may sit at the table and grin, but he knows that the point I make is very true. I have just referred to Mr Landeryou purchasing a house with a certain cheque. People are not protected against that sort of thing by this Bill, because it does not specify the operating standards for a superannuation fund. That is the very least safeguard that a person, who is making a contribution, could ask the Government to provide, particularly as the statement made by the Treasurer has been around for some 18 months, particularly since this Bill was introduced in the dying days of the last Parliament-and the Opposition parties at that time made exactly the same point-and particularly since this Bill, which passed through the House, was not accepted at that time by the Senate. The Government and the committee working on the Bill, with the industry, have had a further three months to work out those operating standards. I must ask why we have not seen them. There can be one of two answers. First, the Government has done nothing, it has just sat on its hands; or, secondly, it deliberately does not want to specify those operating standards. The Government's objective in having those standards may be that it does not want this Bill to be the subject of a full debate in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I for one think that retirement income policy in this country should be addressed, and addressed publicly, because it is one of the most critical issues that this country is facing. We have only to have some basic knowledge of the demographic structure of our population to realise that unless we take some fundamental decisions now and start planning to finance retirement in this country by about the year 2010 we will have a major problem. Despite this Government's claims of having an understanding of welfare issues, it has done precious little towards introducing an effective welfare system or to address the problem of retirement income.

As I mentioned before, the honourable member for Bendigo proudly proclaims that this whole thing is based on a Press release and the assets test. That is this Government's retirement income policy, and it is just not good enough. It will not take us out to the year 2010, and the Government will have to address these problems at some stage. If it really knew what it was doing it would be bringing the details into this House and it would have not only a parliamentary debate but also a public debate on the whole issue. Perhaps there are some sensitivities about the operating standards and about who will have what authority on superannuation funds and perhaps about how those funds will be required to invest their income. We saw in the ACTU document titled Australia Reconstructed proposals for 20 per cent of a superannuation funds income to be invested in specified areas.

The Minister was making a reference some time ago to the rights of trustees. Trustees have an obligation to maximise the benefits for the people they are acting for, and not to stick money into something that Simon Crean, Bill Kelty or someone else thinks is a good idea to bolster the position of the trade union movement at a particular time. That is what we are talking about now. I and the Opposition think that the workers of Australia have a right to know what this Government's retirement income policy is, and we do not know. They expose themselves to the risk of the Government, on a whim or as a result of pressure from the ACTU, making fundamental changes to the operating standards of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds which will significantly affect the standard of living that they can afford in their retirement.

As I pointed out, the real issue here is that it is very easy to change regulations but it takes 30 years to plan for one's retirement. I do not think this legislation is a very good deal for the average Australian worker. For that reason I support the amendments that will be moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate because I too support the amendments to be moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), but I also state that the Opposition will allow the passage of this legislation because, like me, other members on this side of the House acknowledge the fact that this legislation is a step in the right direction. As my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who has just resumed his seat, has indicated, it does not go far enough but it does set up an important framework which I believe should have been established many years ago. In that regard I am critical of all previous governments-Liberal governments and Labor governments. This framework under which superannuation funds can be given operating standards has been a long felt need. But that is not the end in itself: the end for which we should be aiming is the creation of an environment in which all Australian citizens can, through their own efforts, provide for themselves independence and self-reliance in their retirement at a standard of living which is acceptable to them and the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government came to office it missed a golden opportunity because 85 per cent of the age retirees of the country were in receipt of social security pensions, either full or part. Instead of going in the direction of penalising thrift, discouraging private provision by the imposition of the assets test, I believe it would have been cheaper for the nation if the pension had been made universally available; that there would be no income test and asset test and on the attainment of 65 years every Australian qualified by residence should have been entitled through an age pension to a basic minimum standard of living. A great majority of Australians who have been taxpayers in fact have been contributing to their own retirement.

Our tax system these days does not include within it a contribution for retirement income; it did some 30 or 40 years ago. A little less than 10c in every tax dollar goes on funding the current age pension scheme. An extra contribution of 10c in every dollar of taxable income above the tax threshold would provide to every Australian aged 65 and over the full age pension. That would then enable Australians to plan for their retirement, to make their investment, savings and expenditure decisions in a normal commercial way without being influenced by the destructive structure of the tax and social security system with its high effective tax rates being the combination of taxation imposed on top of the income test and the implication of the assets test. What do we find? Many Australians in the 10 years before their retirment are wriggling and adjusting their expenditure and savings patterns so that when they reach retirement they will receive what they, in my view, are properly entitled to-the return on the taxes they have paid in anticipation that the Government will provide them with a secure basic minimum standard of living. As a consequence of the distortions in people's savings, investment and expenditure patterns, it is costing, in tax and in overseas indebtedness, far more than the direct cost of providing those people a guaranteed pension upon their retirement.

Circumstances have changed since the Australian Labor Party came to office. There has been this move in respect of the 3 per cent superannuation pay increase. I think it is a great pity in terms of public policy that the debate about the 3 per cent superannuation payment has had two threads running through it which have become tangled in a most unfortunate way. One thread is the question of whether we as a nation can afford a pay increase. I want to put that debate to one side. I want to assume that it could be afforded, although I do not believe that to be the case. If one makes that assumption, and 3 per cent is put aside for every Australian, under the present tax regime we have no guarantee that the taxpayers at large-the public sector, to use the jargon-will be relieved of any future expenditure.

The Labor Party Government has failed in this regard in its indications of the standards that are to be set under this legislation. It has failed, firstly, because it says people will be able to take out their superannuation benefits at 55. If they do not they have 10 years in which they can blow it and come back on to the public sector-double dipping. Secondly, there is no requirement to guarantee a stream of income from the time of retirement, or the assets to support a stream of income. I think those standards should be set. It is my view that we as a nation should aim to ensure that all Australians contribute for retirement, either to the superannuation funds or to some private provision-I will come to that in a moment-at least 10 per cent of their earnings. Three per cent is a long way from that.

I turn to the public sector superannuation provision. I am aware, as many other members would be aware, that the government instrumentalities that join the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund have to pay 21 per cent of their payroll to have their employees members of it, and actuaries question whether that is enough. On information that I have, and having read the literature and talked with actuaries, I understand that 3 per cent of wages paid to the Government from the first dollar to 130 per cent of averaged weekly earnings for the whole employed work force would have provided a universal pension to every Australian of 10 per cent of average weekly earnings. Six per cent would have provided a pension of 20 per cent of average weekly earnings. Recognising that that would include some high income earners supporting low income earners, it may well be that 10 per cent is the more likely figure if adequate provision is to be made by individuals contributing in effect for their own retirement.

That raises then a further question as to whether we look at a flat rate minimum standard for everyone guaranteed by the Government and by the framework of the tax and social security systems, or whether we allow the tax and social security systems to give huge benefits to high income earners so that they can have earnings related retirement benefits. One approach would have been, as I mentioned a few minutes ago, to have had a universal pension for all, to have withdrawn all the tax concessions in respect of private provision and to have left everyone to play on a level playing field-to make the savings they chose to make, to make the investments they wanted and to make the current expenditure outlays that they selected, knowing that everyone would be guaranteed a pension of 20 to 23 per cent of average weekly earnings through the flat rate provision. But now we do not have that situation because the Australian Labor Party missed that opportunity.

What we have to ask ourselves when we are trying to cut expenditure and to help the average Australian on average weekly earnings and below is how we can possibly afford to have a tax forgone at the rate of $3 billion a year on the tax concessions available through superannuation fund schemes without any guarantee that there will be $3 billion a year relief on the demands on the social security system, either currently or in the future. So it is my view that all should be entitled to an age pension as of right on the attainment of retiring age or alternatively there should be a nexus between the tax concessions available directly or indirectly to employees and others providing for their retirement, or a maximum age pension to which they become entitled on retirement. Furthermore, those who benefit from the current superannuation fringe benefit tax relief should be required to provide security to the taxpayer that their superannuation savings will be available to provide them with retirement incomes.

I said earlier that I wanted to touch upon private provision. It is my view that individuals have a deep desire to be self-reliant, to provide for themselves. If people are prepared to make their own provision for retirement, they should be able to operate out of the tax liability that they would otherwise be subjected to if they had failed to make that provision. I do not think that they should be required by governments or anyone else to put their savings into nominated superannuation funds. I think they should have freedom of choice. A factory worker should be able to make his or her private provision or go into the factory's superannuation scheme, the industry scheme or the one run by the union, but it should be a matter of genuine individual choice, with no pressure and everyone entitled to make the savings that he or she chooses. If people can make the savings that will provide them with the resources to give them a stream of income equivalent to the age pension on retirement, they should be exempted from the tax that they would otherwise be liable to pay.

Most people, of course, want to go into superannuation funds but from time to time, for example, young families may want to purchase a house. I personally have no objection to saying to a young couple, `We can accelerate for you the rate at which you can pay for your house if, in making the savings and getting the tax relief to the extent of the amount of taxpayer cost for your age pension in that particular year, you will give security, by way of a mortgage or encumbrance or some such deed over the house, for that proportion of pension that that capital sum representing the relief of taxation would provide'. That mortgage could be moved from one house to another as mobile people changed their locations. In that way people would be able to fend for themselves. The money would not have to come into governments and be recycled through government departments and treasuries and creamed off in the expenses of government.

People could be given the option of saying, `Yes, I, throughout my life, want to provide for my retirement'. Many would love to do that now, but they cannot because the tax system is totally insensitive to people's desire to achieve that goal. Also, our tax and social security system at present is giving great tax relief, without our really understanding its purpose, in respect of contributions to superannuation funds, the income of superannuation funds and the payments that are made to people on retirement. We could well ask what the objectives are. One is that people will have incomes in retirement. But that is not working. What level of income do we want to give tax relief for? Do we give it for a flat rate pension, or an earnings related pension? Is it to be a device that enables people in the upper income brackets to divert huge amounts of their income through superannuation funds to provide themselves ultimately with lump sums that add to their accumulated wealth without necessarily doing anything to relieve the public sector of the cost of a social security pension? If it does that, it will be terribly expensive.

There may be a secondary reason for giving that tax relief: that we want people to save so that we can build up this country. If that is the objective, tax relief should be more directly targeted than is the device which is now available to a few people who can organise their affairs accordingly. We need a neutral tax system, whereby people are enabled to provide for themselves. If they provide for themselves they should be exempted from paying the taxes that they would otherwise have to pay to ensure that they have the social security pension when they need it.

The principal matter of concern that I have in relation to this legislation is that it does not fix a proper retirement age. People should not be able to take out their retirement provision, I believe, until they are 65, except in the case of invalidity. It does not, to add a small further point, deal adequately with vesting. I do not think tax relief should be available unless the funds are vested to the benefit of the members of the funds. We want to ensure that the maximum provision is available to the maximum number of people so that ultimately there is private provision for retirement incomes by most Australians.

We need to remember that the framework we are now establishing should be good enough to cope with a level of income payment to superannuation that will provide adequate retirement incomes. As I have indicated, that would mean a trebling or quadrupling of the current 3 per cent objective that is now being looked at. Whilst I welcome the legislation in the sense that it creates a framework, I am concerned that it has not addressed these fundamental issues.

All too often we talk about the crisis we are facing because the population is aging. In fact, the population is aging because we do not give birth to enough children-that is the reason. Nevertheless, the population is aging.

When we talk about a crisis and say that governments will not be able to afford it, what do we mean by that? Are we to abandon the old people and say, `You did not make provision for yourselves.'? It is a problem that provides a challenge for us all. What we need to do is to develop systems under which as a nation we are able to spread our income over our working lives and our retirement years. That is not possible under the present tax system. This Government has failed to do anything effective about that. However, I hope that the small tentative step that the Government has taken will open up new horizons so that we reach a situation where retirement incomes are provided by individual Australians at a level that involves a guaranteed minimum, and that they are enabled to do so by generous and extensive tax relief being granted to them if they provide a guarantee that they will not fall back on to the government system and become dependent on a social security pension. So, there is that opportunity to move from the universalist approach of the social security pension--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply to comments made in the second reading debate by thanking all honourable members for their contribution and expressing some regret that the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) particularly allowed their attitude towards the trade union movement to colour completely any kind of balanced approach to what this legislation purports to do. This legislation was not brought before this Parliament as being a comprehensive, all-embracing package to deal with superannuation. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) was right when he described it basically as a first step and the honourable member for Richmond was right when he said that this legislation had already been through the House on one other occasion and it was only the time limitation which prevented it going through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the proposition which seems to be central to the position which has transfixed the Opposition, and that is that we should not be proceeding by way of regulation in respect of aspects of this legislation. The suggestion that was made by the honourable member for Richmond and, I think, the honourable member for Berowra--

TALK.START.PARA: —Regulations on the principles. The principles are not in the Bill.

—Yes, that is right. I will deal with that. The position taken by the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Berowra that somehow or other what the Government was doing was putting at risk all those hundreds of thousands of people who were already in existing superannuation schemes is, of course, palpable nonsense. If they had looked at or taken the trouble to examine the statements that were made when this legislation was last before the Parliament in June of last year, when it was handled by the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), they would have seen that he made it perfectly clear, at page 3834 of Hansard of 2 June 1987, that the legislation, which is in precisely the same form as it comes before the House now, had been the subject of extensive consultation and discussions with the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia. Let me inform the House that that consultation and those discussions are continuing. I am advised by officers of the Department that once this legislation has gone through it is not the end of the matter; there is more legislation in course of preparation and discussion are continuing with the industry on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us now move to the substantive concerns of my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who felt that what was really needed was basically a legislative set of provisions which set out, as it were, the principles under which these superannuation schemes would work. That was a position that was put to the Government and, on a range of advice, was rejected. The advice did not come from the Australian Council of Trade Unions or Mr Kelty-I suspect they had their own positions. It came from no less a person than the President of the Institute of Actuaries of Australia, Mr J. H. Pollard, who is also President of the School of Economics and Financial Studies at Macquarie University. Let me quote what seems to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table the letter?

—I am perfectly happy to table the letter. Let me quote the very basis of the position of this independent expert which blows out of the water all of the hysterics and histrionics of the honourable member for Richmond and perhaps at the same time blows out of the water the more restrained comments of the honourable member for Bradfield. The President of the Institute of Actuaries raises quite specifically why the use of regulations would be more satisfactory. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are two main reasons for the Institute's belief that a regulatory approach is appropriate.
Under the heading `Range of Plans Designs, Structures etc.' he says:

The superannuation industry does not consist of relatively few plans, nor of plans of fairly standardised design. Rather there are at least 200,000 plans, established over many years, each against a background of the local needs, practice of the time, cost constraints, negotiations, etc., etc. The variety of plans in existence is therefore huge, and the task of drafting legislation to set out standards that will satisfactorily address that variety is commensurately large.

There is no doubt that, even with the best advice possible from the industry, some plans that are reasonable per se in all respects, albeit unusual in design, will be subject to unintended effects of any legislated standards. While legislated changes could cope with such problems, clearly it will always be much more difficult to achieve necessary or desirable change in a timely fashion through this route, as opposed to changing regulations.
Under the heading `Pace of Change' he says:

In recent years the pace of change in the superannuation industry has been very high. Indeed, much of the impetus for the occupational superannuation standards stems from a need to ensure that those changes occur in ways that meet community expectations.

The Institute expects that the pace of change will continue to be high for the next few years. The Institute itself has suggested further changes and we hope that these will occur, as the economy and practical realities allow. Other changes will no doubt become desirable reaction to particular events on the industrial front, and particularly in the Arbitration Commission.

In many instances planned trustees are likely to find the terms of their deeds at odds with conditions imposed upon or accepted by plan sponsors, and which place trustees in an invidious position. While government announcements can indicate how such problems will eventually be solved e.g. by legislative change, this is no substitute for the clear, legal authority trustees need in order to meet changing circumstances.
Ordering change by altering regulations is likely to be much more timely than what is possible by legislative change, and would therefore be welcome by most trustees.
Therefore, from the Institute view it is much more appropriate that the proposed occupational superannuation standards be regulated rather than legislated.

That is a clear, objective view of someone who I think commands the respect and authority of people both in the industry and, I would hope, in this House. On the basis of that information, would it have been responsible for the Government, realising the need to establish a structure, having involved itself in consultation with the industry, having received a great deal of advice, and having advice as strongly argued and as rational as that, to turn its back on it and say, `Although it is much more complicated we will legislate now and repent in the future if it creates too many problems.'? That is the thrust of a compelling argument.

If any regulations are promulgated as a result of the rapid changes that take place in this industry and the particular problems that arise in the course of what is a fairly dynamic industry, and regulations are designed to meet that, and if members of the Opposition in another place feel constrained to raise objections to that, there is a process which can be followed. For those reasons there is no way in which we can accept the recommendations of the honourable member for Bradfield on behalf of the Opposition. I am certain that the honourable member for Bradfield, having been fully informed of the reasons for the Government's position and understanding that that position arises as a result of the kinds of expressions of opinion that have come from within the industry itself, he will feel constrained not to press these arguments, which I accept were put in good faith but he was not fully aware of the range of consultation and advice that the Government has had on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 3, at the end of the definition of ``superannuation fund'' add the following words and paragraph:

``(4) Where the Commissioner does not confirm, revoke or vary a decision before the expiration of the period of 60 days after the day on which the Commissioner received the request under subsection (1) to reconsider the decision, the Commissioner shall, upon the expiration of that period, be deemed to have revoked the decision under subsection (3).''.

In view of the lateness of the hour, I shall not delay the Committee unduly, but I wish to make a number of points in relation to the amendments which I have moved and which have been circulated to honourable members. One of the strange elements of this legislation is the title, which, in many respects, is nothing less than a misnomer. We are told that it is a Bill for an Act to provide operating standards for superannuation funds and approved deposit funds. It does not provide operating standards for anything. In fact, part II of the Bill again uses the term `operating standards for superannuation funds'. Clause 7 (1) states that the regulations may prescribe standards applicable to the operation of superannuation funds; in other words, it is the regulations which this Act permits to be carried through in accordance with the provisions. However, the Bill does not provide anything except, as I said, the mechanism for the subsequent passage of regulations at some future date.

The Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding), in his summing up of the second reading debate, referred to Professor Pollard, the head of the Institute of Actuaries of Australia. He is, of course, a man of substantial eminence and is no doubt respected by members on both sides of the chamber. The essence of our primary amendment was that we believed that the legislation should have contained the basic principles set out in the Press release of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 11 June 1986. A study of that document makes it quite clear that there are ample opportunities for the statement of a set of basic principles against which future regulations or legislative changes can be tested. The problem we have with the legislation in its present form is that no serious attempt was made to offer to the industry, the consumers or the Parliament a statement of clear intent. I made it clear in my speech during the second reading debate that too many opportunities have recently been taken by the Treasurer deliberately to avoid bringing legislation before the Parliament; rather, he has tried to build up his legislative program using regulations or, worse still, in this case no less than three Press releases as the basis for Government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through the newspapers.

—Yes. Is it any wonder, therefore, that the Opposition asserts its right to be able to debate in this chamber precisely what the Government's policies are in relation to superannuation? Whether the advice comes from Professor Pollard, the National Mutual, the AMP Society, or anyone else, the fundamental fact is that as an Opposition it is our role and responsibility to protect the interests of a very wide range of groups in this community, including people who actually sell the policies, the agents on the ground, the actuarial companies and all of the other groups in this industry. A very large and complex body of people has access to enormous funds which in turn have a major impact on the social and economic future of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, we are seeking to make a fundamental amendment to clause 3 on page 3 of the Bill. This matter was brought forward by my good colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who raised with us, I believe quite correctly, the question of freedom of choice. As the putative regulations stand as contained in the Minister's Press release, the fact of the matter is that many workers are effectively forced to join trade union managed or controlled superannuation funds. We believe that superannuation is too important for this to happen.

We accept without reservation the basic principles which I presume the Government is accepting-namely, that one must have full vesting preservation of interests of individuals in a case such as this. However, there is an equally strong case to be made in a society such as Australia for workers to have the opportunity to join a union managed fund if they so wish, to join an employers managed fund if they so wish, or, as a third alternative, to join a 23 FB fund or take out any other arrangements they may so wish. In other words, the essential element has to be that we want maximum coverage of superannuation, but let it be on the basis of freedom of choice as to what mechanism the individual may wish to enter into because of his own particular circumstances. One can never expect that one will get from a socialist dominated government such as this a package of proposals which will do anything more than meet the requirements of those who have the loudest voices and, in this case, the biggest pockets. A whole range of trade unions are doing extremely well on the one per cent to 1 1/4 per cent commission that they are getting from the members who are joining the funds over which they have considerable control.

I would like to refer to some of the other amendments that we have put forward. We take great exception to the fact that there is still reference in the Act to the financial year 1986-87. We have moved on from there now. We have moved to the next financial year. We are surprised that no attempt has been made to amend the Act to make it more up to date. If it remains as it is, there will be an element of retrospectivity in this legislation, which, as I explained in my speech during the second reading debate, opens up another set of very real problems in relating to the rights of fund managers to be able to operate under conditions similar to those contained in the taxation Act.

Prior to the passage of this legislation, superannuation, insofar as accessibility to tax deductibility was concerned, was related to the taxation Act. One of the elements in this proposal is to take it out of that and place it under the control of the new Commissioner. Clearly, therefore, there is a case that one should have access on a similar basis to the taxation Act. Therefore, the concept of using 1986-87 as the basis for the legislation is basically wrong. It should be related to the date of the passage of the Act and not before.

Many of my colleagues have spoken about legislation by Press release. I spoke about this as well during the second reading debate. We want legislation as the basis of policy, not regulations as the basis of policy. We do not believe that that is an unreasonable request to make as an Opposition. This Government is now too often using this as an excuse for not putting the full story before the Parliament. The realities of regulations in an area as complex as superannuation are simply this: if one cannot set one's principles out clearly in advance, no parliament, no chamber of a parliament and no members within it will be able to make a total judgment as to whether proposed regulations coming through are fully in accordance with the principles against which they must be tested. One of the old tricks of the trade in politics is to bring legislation through with no clarion calls and no beating of breasts or drums. All of a sudden the thing is through and the first one knows about it is when an industry starts complaining. We do not want that situation. We do not regard that as the basis of sound legislative practice. That is why we do not think that legislation by Press release or regulations in the first instance should be the principle against which this Government introduces legislation.

There are a number of relatively minor amendments; nevertheless, they are of considerable significance. For example, there is evidence that some funds-again, regrettably, they are trade union funds-can exploit the power to seek administration fees which they may negotiate with the managers of the funds. We believe that regulations on that matter should be contained in the Act. The Minister said that that is not to be the case. However, I trust that in the next amending legislation attempts will be made to overcome that quite serious problem. Finally, I refer again to the question of regulation. People have the right to some degree of certainty in relation to the time within--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to add to answers given at Question Time. I have sought further responses. I promised honourable members that I would do that before the House rose. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) asked me at Question Time whether I would table a memorandum relating to the Australia Card prepared by Parliamentary Counsel for the legislation committee. However, the document concerned is a Cabinet document which quotes other Cabinet documents. As honourable members will know, it has been the practice of all governments not to divulge Cabinet papers and I do not propose to part from that practice. I regret that in my initial response to the honourable member's request I overlooked the fact that it was a Cabinet paper. However, having reread the memorandum by Parliamentary Counsel, I can confirm that there are not references in the document to the specific clauses or to the issue of proclamation versus regulation, which were the subjects of the question.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to a question asked earlier today by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) I undertook to take up with my colleague Senator Ryan the question of whether any drafting instructions had been given to Parliamentary Counsel to redraft the Australia Card legislation to accommodate a number of amendments to the existing legislation. I have discussed this matter with Senator Ryan. As I indicated to the House, no drafting instructions have been issued to Parliamentary Counsel since the 11 July election in relation to amendments to the Australia Card Bill 1986. As announced by Senator Ryan and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), officials within the Department of Community Services and Health have been instructed to recommence discussions with private sector organisations and civil liberties groups and to advise on possible amendments for later consideration by the Government.

In my answer to the Parliament today I was of course referring to this post-election process. It should be noted that in late February 1987 a number of amendments were suggested and I publicly announced that they were under consideration. They were referred to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for drafting. This work ceased with the announcement in March this year that the Australia Card Bill would be reintroduced unamended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to address this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving:

That this House censures the Minister for Community Services and Health for his failure to fulfil the undertaking given earlier today to table the memorandum relating to the Australia Card Bill prepared by the Parliamentary Counsel for the Australia Card legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

—As I said a moment ago by indulgence, there is no more important issue in Australian politics at present than the lamentable display of incompetence by this Government over the identity card legislation. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who has just resumed his seat, the man who has had ministerial responsibility for this legislation for over 18 months has, over the last 48 hours, not only demonstrated his total ministerial incompetence in relation to this legislation but has failed the most elementary Westminster test of the competence and ability of a Minister. Moreover, he has today compounded that inability and failure of his ministerial duties by one of the most bumbling, inept performances at Question Time that this Parliament has seen in the lifetime of the Hawke Government. He could not get one answer right. He had to come back to correct just about every answer that he gave at Question Time today. I asked the Minister a simple question-whether he would table the advice of Parliamentary Counsel in relation to the indentity card legislation. Anybody who has been a Minister for six months, let alone somebody who has been a Minister for 4 1/2 years, ought to know what is the advice in the memorandum of a parliamentary counsel on a piece of legislation. It is a memorandum from Parliamentary Counsel addressed to the legislation committee of Cabinet which does a number of things. One of those things is to advise the legislation committee whether the legislation is in accordance with the Cabinet decision on which the legislation is based. I would have thought that it is a fairly fundamental thing-whether the Bill actually reflects the will of the Government as contained in the Cabinet decision. So it is a fairly important document.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the memorandum draws to the attention of the legislation committee any matters that Parliamentary Counsel properly believed ought to be drawn to the attention of Ministers who constitute the legislation committee. The Opposition's belief is that at least at one stage of the approval procedure within the ranks of the governing Party on this legislation there was quite intensive debate as to whether the commencement date, the relevant dates, ought to be the subject of regulation or of proclamation. It was only after the Minister had intervened and decided it should be by way of regulation that that is how it proceeded. On the basis of that, it is not surprising that a number of people on this side of the House believe that contained within the memorandum of Parliamentary Counsel is a comment from Parliamentary Counsel as to the significance of doing this by regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been told that there was not.

—With the track record of the Hawke Government we do not believe it. It is as simple as that. The only way that the Australian public will be satisfied that the Minister is not covering up the fact that he knew that the Bill was defective is for him to table all the relevant documents. The Australian people will go on believing that both he and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) knew that the Bill was defective until the Minister comes clean and tables all the relevant documents.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister had plenty of opportunity today to handle this matter in a different fashion. I asked him twice what he was going to do with the Parliamentary Counsel's memorandum and he freely said that he was going to table the document. Later, in answer to a question as to the timing of that tabling, he said that he would endeavour to do it today. I ask the Minister, the House, and the Australian people: what happened between those two affirmative answers and five past 10 tonight to change the Minister's mind? Did he go to have a look at the memorandum and find out that it contained some embarrassing material? Did he get heavied by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young)? Did the court jester come along and say to him, `Hey, hang on, Neal, you shouldn't have done that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will refer to members by their title.

—Was he heavied by the Leader of the House (Mr Young), the Prime Minister or the Attorney-General? What happened between Question Time today and five past 10 tonight to change the minister's mind? He was perfectly happy to say to me that he would table it. He looked a bit tentative as he walked past the Prime Minister, but the Prime Minister's gaze was fixed on the ground. That is not surprising, the way his front bench has been performing over the last week. If I were in his position I would have my gaze fixed to the ground, too. The Minister is supposed to be a member of the most talented Ministry since Federation, of this tremendously talented Ministry. This Minister today has given the most pathetic performance of a senior Minister that this country has seen over the last 30 years. Not only has he embarrassed the Government and mortally wounded it on a fundamental piece of legislation, but also he is now engaged in a giant cover-up involving a Parliamentary Counsel memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Community Services and Health is into the politics of deception. He wanted to table the document; he did not have any worry about tabling it but no doubt he has gone back to his office and had a look at it. He has been in meetings ever since Question Time ended. It has not been possible to get the Minister's office on the telephone. Everyone has been tied up in this or that meeting. There is no doubt that they have looked at the documents and decided, `If we table this document, the Opposition will ask a whole lot more questions'. I say to the House: this Minister has embarrassed this Government as much as it has been embarrassed since the Leader of the House leaked national security information in a Canberra carpark. He had the honour of being the only Minister in the Hawke Government to have been condemned openly by a royal commissioner appointed by this Government, but since that embarrassment the worst embarrassment this Government has suffered has been as a result of the lamentable performance of this Minister over the identity card legislation.

The Minister knows, and there are people on the back bench of the Labor Government who know, that the question of whether a regulation or proclamation should be used to determine the relevant dates under the legislation was debated within Government ranks when the legislation was being approved. Twenty or 30 members of the Labor Party know that and know that this issue was, or should have been, brought to the attention of the Minister. That only increases the suspicion on this side of the House and within the ranks of the public about this Minister who has refused to table the document. He promised twice this afternoon to table it, so what happened between 2 o'clock and 10 o'clock? What happened in that eight hours? Who leant on him? What did he see? What was contained in the document? What cover-up is he engaged in? What further inquiries would result from the documents being tabled? The reality is that this Minister has compounded the sin of ministerial incompetence with the sin of misleading this House. He has broken his word to the Parliament. He told us that he would table this document. Now, eight hours later, he comes in and says, `Oh, no, I cannot table it because it happens to be a Cabinet document'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—Honourable members on the other side say, `That is right'. I have news for all those on the other side who bellow: there are many precedents on both sides of the House for the tabling of Cabinet documents. There is no iron-clad rule of our parliamentary system that says a Cabinet document shall not be tabled. The only reason that this document is not being tabled, the only reason the Minister is breaking his word and will not come clean, the only reason he does not have the guts to observe the word he gave in Question Time is that he is engaged in a cover-up and he knows that the tabling of this document would further deepen the embarrassment of the Government on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Every Australian should know that no longer can anyone believe the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). He came into the House today on two occasions and committed himself to producing not truly a Cabinet paper but the brief provided for the legislation committee of Cabinet. Unlike most other members of this place I have chaired a legislation committee of Cabinet, and I have done so for a good many years. Within the advice of Parliamentary Counsel there is always advice about the character and the nature of the legislation. Unless we suspend Standing Orders so that we can censure the Minister, the people of Australia will be misled into believing the Minister who twice now has denied the House the production of the legislation committee papers and then has the effrontery to come into the House and say that there was no reference to how the measures of that legislation would come into being. We just cannot believe him. The character of the Parliamentary Counsel's advice I would trust, but I would not trust that man. The point is that Parliamentary Counsel, like Mr Ewart Smith, is a man of propriety, a man of honour, a man of integrity and a man whose word we would believe.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Community Services and Health has come into this place tonight and said that there is no reference in the advice to the legislation committee of Cabinet as to how the legislation is to be brought into effect. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker: Is the Government that incompetent; is it so naive as to think that we believe that a Bill brought in to the legislation committee of Cabinet has no advice to how it is to come into being? We do not have a bit of legislation that is automatically law-it goes through Parliament, it goes to the Governor-General and it is then introduced by a date that is included in the legislation, it is introduced by proclamation or it is introduced by regulation. We all know that within the left wing of the Australian Labor Party members such as the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) have been concerned about this legislation. Does the Minister really expect us to believe that members such as the honourable member for Hotham did not ask him how and in what way this legislation is going to come into being? His story does not add up. It is impossible for anybody on this side of the House to believe the rhetoric that came from the Minister's lips this evening.

The second question worries me just as much. In answer to my colleague the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the Minister has said that there have been no drafting amendments issued to Parliamentary Counsel. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) earlier today quoted from the Press conference of the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan). Honourable members will remember what she said. Either the Minister is misleading this House or Senator Susan Ryan is misleading not only the Parliament but the whole Australian electorate. Unless we suspend Standing Orders to censure the Minister, the people of Australia are in an impossible position. We believe that the Minister is misleading the House and the people of Australia on two fundamental issues. On the first we know that there have to be references in the legislation committee advice as to how the legislation comes into effect and, on the second, Senator Susan Ryan has already told us that those amendments have been drafted. It is not good enough. The Minister must go. The Government has finished up with a great deal of ignominy in this whole disgraceful affair. I suggest to the Minister that he now honestly accepts that the people of this place are not as gullible as apparently he expects us to be.

This is what Senator Ryan has said. None of these instructions have been given to counsel about the drafting of amendments'. Eight and a half hours after this, honourable members opposite sat in their dining room and asked themselves, `What will we do? We have lost another election; we have had the most monumental defeat the Liberal and National parties have ever had'. But honourable members opposite will keep the honourable member for Bennelong as their leader. Well, long live the honourable member for Bennelong.

I would like to know why the honourable member for Bennelong sacked his former Deputy Leader. Why is he sitting up the back? It is because he has no heart. The honourable member for Bennelong would not stand up for him. He sacked him and put him on the back bench. His former Deputy Leader is one of the most talented people for the Liberal Party of Australia in this Parliament and the honourable member for Bennelong put him on the back bench. He should tell us about that. Why does he have all these phonies and cronies on his front bench? It is because he is weak. He is a weak person. He has always been a weak person and we hope, from this side of the House, that he stays as Leader forever-that is all right. Sinkers can handle him. The night the honourable member for Bennelong went on television and said, `I'll stick with Sinkers', Sinkers said, `That'll do me'. He got the cheque book out and said, `That'll do me, I'll stick with John Howard', because John Howard had committed himself to sticking with the right honourable member for New England.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I take grave offence at the impudence--
—Order! I am having difficulty hearing the Leader of the National Party.
—I take grave offence at the statement by the Leader of the House and I request that he withdraw that remark. I think it belittles him and does little credit to this House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if the right honourable member for New England takes any offence at what I said, I withdraw it. I meant no personal offence. What I am saying is that the right honourable member for New England is too smart, too old and too tough for the honourable member for Bennelong. Honourable members opposite can keep the honourable member for Bennelong, but let me make a prediction, as I look at the faces of those sitting on the back benches. I have got a feeling that early in 1988, as part of our bicentennial celebrations, the honourable member for Bennelong will be given the trip, and I think the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is coming back.
