DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Timber Industry-Palau-Budget Deficit-Logan City Rugby League Football Club-Australian Tourist Industry Association Conference

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that quietness has returned to the chamber and the adjournment debate is on, I will speak very briefly about the timber industry in Australia. Over the years there has been a developing concern as to the future of the industry particularly because of the environmentalists' objections to logging and the cutting of timber generally in many of the forests on private property and elsewhere throughout Australia. Over the years the timber industry in Australia has become most important, firstly, because we have the soil to grow it-both the hardwoods and softwoods-and, secondly, because it employs approximately 100,000 people. It has been a source of great exports for Australia and has supplied our sawn timber and pulp requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Timber is a crop, a renewable resource that we Australians have a great responsibility to care for. In recent times, particularly in the last 10 to 15 years, governments have been inclined to make off the cuff decisions about the use of Australia's timber resource. Naturally, it is the responsibility of the various States concerned but time and again States have appealed to the Commonwealth to intervene and decide what the timber should be used for or whether it should be touched at all. This is what I am concerned about. We have an important industry in Australia that has been subject to off the cuff decisions and it is time that the States, perhaps in conjunction with the Commonwealth, planned and integrated the development, preservation and conservation of this very important resource.

As I come from an electorate that is very dependent upon the timber industry I appeal to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), the Government and the Parliament to do something to bring together the people who are responsible for this industry in Australia. Of course pressure groups would like to tie up the forest resource, a resource which affects Australia's jobs and exports. In 1986-87 we imported more timber, certainly in value, than we did in 1982-83. Today we are exporting less than we did in 1982-83. It is time that we recognised the excellent work that is being done by the forestry departments within Australia, particularly in New South Wales where our forests are being cared for. Trees are being planted where others have been cut down, roads are being constructed and tourists and the general population are able to look at the beauty of the forests. Year by year lots of areas are declared national parks and placed on the World Heritage List and the public is unable to enter them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—That is the case in many areas. When I was a member of the New South Wales Parliament, a Liberal-National Party team initiated the declaring of national parks in New South Wales. Tomorrow night I will go to a little place called Coopernook in my electorate where I will open a Church of England wild flower show. For 20 years I have opened the show and people will be waiting for me tomorrow night. There will be gorgeous bushes and flowers from the forests and private lands around that area. There is a beautiful native hardwood forest which has occasional patches of softwood rainforest. Here is an illustration of everyday Australians being able to come along to a flower show and enjoy something that we grow in the forests. Why should people not be able to go into the forests and why should they not be able, within limitations, to pick the flowers and enjoy the scenic beauty? This is so important.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I was so elated at being able to get the call in the adjournment debate the other day and also to be able to ask a question that I actually neglected to congratulate you on your election to your high office and I take this opportunity to do that.
—Thank you.

—I read with interest a recent speech by Senator Vallentine in the other place who was speaking about recent events in the Republic of Belau, more frequently known as the nation of Palau. Palau is situated some 2,500 kilometres north of Darwin and comprises roughly 200 islands inhabited by about 15,000 people. Palau is part of the United Nations Trust Territory of Micronesia which has been administered by the United States of America since 1947. It is necessary to read Senator Vallentine's speech of 17 September 1987 to obtain the historic background to the problems facing Palau and I will not go into those problems tonight. Suffice it to say that the United States of America is exerting all its influence to ensure that the Republic provides a military base for the United States in the South Pacific. The problem is a nuclear free constitution which includes this section:

SPEECH.PARA: Harmful substances such as nuclear, chemical, gas or biological weapons intended for use on warfare, nuclear power plants and waste materials therefrom, shall not be used, tested, stored, or disposed of within the territorial jurisdiction of Palau without the express approval of not less than three-fourths of the votes cast in a referendum submitted on this specific question.

This section was endorsed by a 92 per cent vote of the people in 1979. Since that time the United States has influenced the Palauan authorities to mount a series of referenda designed to change the constitution to allow the establishment of a United States base which could harbour nuclear warships. The obtrusive paternalism of the United States is not only abhorrent in itself but also has lately resulted in sinister events. In May 1983, International Power Systems Ltd (IPSECO), which is a British power firm, signed a contract with Palau to build a badly needed power plant and fuel farm in Palau. IPSECO's President,Gordon Mochrie, reportedly assured the Palauan National Congress that the project would pay for itself through sales of electricity and fuel. Instead, the Speaker of the House, Santos Olikong, said:
IPSECO is breaking my heart. It was supposed to be self-paying, but instead it costs Palau 15 cents per second.

As of September 1985 the cost of the project and interest payments have skyrocketed to over $35m. Funding for the IPSECO project was provided to Palau by the British Government and International Westminster Bank. The loans were guaranteed by a multinational consortium of banks. In April 1985, Palau defaulted on its foreign debt and in December the banking cartel sued Palau in a New York court for more than $35m.

Some Palaun leaders have argued that the whole power plant fiasco is part of a plot to force Palau to enter into a compact of free association with the United States. The theory of the plot is based on the view that there will be a legal challenge to Palau's proposed $1.38 billion treaty with the United States. Mr Bedor, a Palaun lawyer, stated that his father was murdered a number of weeks ago, allegedly by supporters of the treaty. He said, `This has scared us all and we are very worried about being able to make this challenge'.

The latest United States of America motivated plebiscite for a treaty with the United States was held on 21 August. But although more than half the people voted in favour it did not reach the necessary 75 per cent required by the constitution. The President has claimed that the majority vote is valid as the plebiscite has been approved by the Palaun Assembly and a majority of voters have been in favour. The problem with all this is that the sinister overtones that I talked about have now been realised in Palau and a number of anti-nuclear campaigners there have been threatened and their houses fire-bombed.

I think it is time for the Australian authorities to speak up in the struggle by the Palaun people for a nuclear free and independent nation. The intimidation by the United States is indefensible and our Government should continue to support a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the matter of the $9.6 billion deficit which the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) referred to in her speech during the Budget debate yesterday in this House. The Australian Labor Party, with its propaganda machine, has been peddling the myth that it was saddled with a $10 billion deficit when it came to power in March 1983. I will quote the words of the honourable member for Cowan so we can get the argument correct:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . ad hoc policies which originally led to the outrageous Budget deficit of almost $10,000m which was inherited by the Labor Government when it came to office in 1983.

This completely erroneous statement has been put forward by the Labor Party ever since that date. The position needs to be put clearly and truthfully. The facts are that the Budget Estimates were put forward on prospective bids in March 1983, on forward estimates of what revenue might be generated and what the costs might be in the next Budget. After the election in 1983 the drought broke, the world economy recovered and the wage pause instituted by the Fraser Government was an instrumental factor in turning around the economy at that time. During the next 12 months there was an economic growth rate of about 6 per cent. In 1982-83 the Budget deficit, about which the public is confused, was $4.4 billion and not the $9.6 billion which the Labor Party so often refers to in an attempt to confuse the public. During the 1983 year of victory for the Labor Party when it thought everything would be rosy in the garden not only did it end up with a total deficit of $7.9 billion but also in that deficit figure was $3 billion of extra expenditure. The present Treasurer (Mr Keating) does not even publish the figures because he does not regard them as being relevant or accurate. The four Hawke Budget deficits add up to $23 billion. The Budget deficit in 1983-84 was $7.9 billion. In 1984-85 it was $6.7 billion. In 1985-86 it was $5.7 billion. In the last year, 1986-87, it was $2.7 billion. That is a total of $23 billion.

I note that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in his speech on the Budget referred to the cumulative deficit of the Keating Budgets. On this occasion the deficit is $27m. Speakers on this side of the House have clearly indicated that the true deficit figure is in the order of $2.5 billion. We have had a sale of assets, selling part of the farm, part of Australia. We have also had windfall gains from the Reserve Bank of Australia in the region of $2.7 billion. So much for the myth that this Government inherited a Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. The reality is that the Keating Budgets have had a cumulative deficit of $25 billion.

Senator Walsh, in his recent famous remarks, indicated Australia's real position: we are on the Argentinean road because we have a national debt of $110 billion. This Government made a major contribution by way of its budgetary arrangements to produce this figure of $110 billion. So let us remove the myth that this Government came to office with a deficit of $9.6 billion. It came to office with everything going its way-with a booming economy and the breaking of the drought. Had it been a responsible government, it could have moved to a position of having a Budget surplus. It has managed to balance the current Budget only by selling off part of the farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I thank you for this opportunity to speak about a club of which I am a foundation member. That club is the Logan City Rugby League Football Club. It is known as the Scorpions and, let me tell you, it has plenty of bite. Indeed it is necessary for this club to have bite because it is situated in the most depressed area of Queensland. We have in that area the largest Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) office. Nine thousand unemployed people per month pass through that CES office. The Department of Social Security handles a mere 25,000 families. Indeed, our Government's family assistant package will have a great impact upon our area and the supporters of the Logan City Rugby League Football Club.

SPEECH.PARA: This football club is particularly important to me and to the electors of Forde because in our very first year of existence, while only in the third grade, we achieved the mighty effort of reaching the semi-finals. In fact, we even went on to reach the grand final. It is important not so much that we lost the grand final, but that we played in it at all. In an area which is so depressed, the Logan City Football Club has given to the community a great sense of identity and a great sense of purpose. Let me mention a number of people who have worked tirelessly-and voluntarily, I might add-for our club. The Secretary of the club, Barry Smith, has worked without pay for the last six months. In fact, he has worked all hours of the day for the club. He has worked from his home in a situation which other people would not envy. He fought to gain from the Logan City Council a block of land and he also negotiated a loan from the bank for the clubhouse, which was opened in June. The clubhouse has provided for people a very much needed community centre in an area which was bereft of any such facility.

Madam Speaker, let me tell you that this area has been a very real victim of circumstance. In the Queensland context it is unfortunate that it has a Labor State member of parliament, because that means it is outside those areas which the Queensland Government services. It has an independent local council, which means that it has no local government power or pressure group. However, Barry Smith and the club Chairman, Greg Sutherland, fought for and eventually were granted a block of land from the very same Logan City Council which initially rejected any notion that a rugby league football club could exist, let alone survive, in an area which it thought was not good for anything. The club was eventually granted a block of land at Meakin Park, upon which the clubhouse was built, and it was opened in June. The club, under the captainship of Greg Sutton and, of course, under the auspices of the coach, John Barber, who fought very hard and long for that club, went on to become part of the Brisbane rugby league group and participate in the third grade grand final. All of that hard work has been justified because in 1988 we, the Scorpions, will join the Brisbane first grade. We are seeking identity as a community. We will be able to identify as a group. We will also be able to work together as a community in a very real sense. Tonight I pay tribute to my very own club, the Logan City Rugby League Football Club, commonly know as the Scorpions. And let me tell honourable members, we have plenty of bite left in us for 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Tourist Industry Association is currently holding its annual conference in Hobart. At present a tremendous amount of concern is being expressed by the delegates at that conference about the credibility of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown). Those people are expressing that concern because of the broken promise that the Minister made to the tourist industry during the election campaign to continue the tourism overseas promotion scheme. This very important scheme has helped to promote the Australian tourist industry around the world and has helped to establish the infrastructure by which tourists are brought to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: On 4 June, at the beginning of the election campaign, the Minister stated not only that this scheme would continue but that its funding would be very nearly doubled in the 1987-88 Budget. It was revealed in last week's Budget that not only would this scheme not continue, not only would the funding for the scheme not be increased, but the whole scheme would be axed at the earliest possible opportunity. Of course, this has made the Minister look very poor in the eyes of the people in the tourism industry. I attended the conference yesterday. Having heard the Minister try to explain away in answer to a question in the House the reasons why the Government felt that this promise could be broken, I say to the House that there is no excuse for breaking a promise of this type. Many people in the industry went ahead on the basis that the Minister had credibility. They committed themselves to overseas promotions of their sporting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will be careful not to cast aspersions on any member of this House.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. The Minister made this promise during the election campaign and because of that many people in the industry were prepared to go ahead and spend money on the basis that the tourism overseas promotion scheme would continue in the 1987-88 Budget. Unfortunately, this has not been the case and those people now find themselves in a very embarrassing financial position. Many people in the industry have already been in touch with me and expressed their concern and their upset. They have said that they really believe that they have been led up the garden path by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the only issue that is causing concern at the conference. The Minister has also seen fit to reduce the special depreciation allowances for new projects for tourism facilities from 4 per cent to 2.5 per cent. This is going to have a serious impact on the industry. While a 1.5 per cent depreciation difference does not seem very much to many people, may I point out that 1.5 per cent makes a big difference in the tourist industry today. We are looking at developments that are in the $500m category and 1.5 per cent depreciation can make the difference between a project going ahead and not going ahead.

Another thing causing concern in the industry at present is the Government's decision to introduce a new tax; it is called an entry tax or an immigration tax. From now on, for the very first time, Australians returning home will have to pay a tax. The Government will be imposing a $5 tax on every person who arrives at Australian airports from overseas. This tax will be levied on the airline industry, which will have to collect it and pay the Government. This tax is going to be an administrative nightmare. It is going to be almost impossible to collect. How can this tax be collected in the case of a person who, after paying for his ticket, changes his flights around the world and in the process returns to Australia with an airline different from the one from which he originally bought his ticket? I make this prediction to the House and to the Minister, who I see has come back into the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until Tuesday, 6 October 1987, at 2 p.m., unless Madam Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting, in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many disabled persons receive a Commonwealth pension or benefit in each (a) State and (b) category of disability.
(2) How many persons receive a pension or benefit on behalf of a disabled person in each (a) State and (b) category of disability.
(3) How many of these disabled persons participate in the workforce, and for each (a) State and (b) category of disability how many are employed (i) full time and (ii) part time.
(4) What sum has been spent for employment assistance in each year since 1982.
(5) How has this money and assistance been distributed in each (a) State and (b) category of disability.

(6) Has his Department estimated the additional expense of employing disabled persons in both full and part-time employment; if so, what is the estimate for each (a) State and (b) category of disability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (6) The nature of the information sought is not clear.

My Department collects data on the number of invalid pensioners, sheltered employment allowance recipients and rehabilitation allowees, by State. These people are receiving entitlements in their own rights.
In addition I am able to provide data on handicapped child's allowance recipients by State. These allowances are paid to a parent or guardian of a severely or substantially handicapped child.
The data are as follows:

Information on categories of disability is not routinely collected for these groups of clients. Data on the major causes of invalidity and on impairments of invalid pensioners are available from a survey conducted in November 1979 by the Department of Social Security. That survey showed that the three most frequent causes of invalidity were mental retardation (13.1%), disorders of the back (9.3%) and neurotic and personality disorders (8.9%).

In addition, data on the morbidity characteristics of children receiving handicapped child's allowance are available from a survey conducted in March 1982 by the Department of Social Security. The survey found that the five most frequent major diagnoses of children receiving the allowance were mental retardation (37.7%), paralysis of limbs (14.6%), deafness (10.8%), blindness and low vision (4.0%) and cystic fibrosis (3.6%).

It should be noted, however, that the above information on the morbidity characteristics of invalid pensioners and handicapped children is now somewhat dated and may not reflect the range and prevalence of disabilities within the population of current clients.

It is not possible to identify disabled people who might be in receipt of other Department of Social Security payments. For example, information is not available on those with a disability who are in receipt of unemployment benefit, sickness benefit, widow's pension, supporting parent's benefit, age pension etc.
My Department does not collect data on the workforce participation of disabled people, on employment assistance provided to them or the costs of employing disabled people.
